Description: FY 2023 RREA GRANT PROPOSAL WITH BUDGET NARRATIVE PROJECT TITLE: SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT FOR SMALL-SCALE FARMERS AND WOODLAND OWNERS IN NORTH CAROLINA AND THE SOUTHERN USA ABSTRACT: CURRENT TRENDS SHOW THAT SMALL-SCALE FARMS AND LIMITED RESOURCE FARMS CARRY CRITICAL AND ESSENTIAL FAMILY ECONOMIC ASSETS TO NORTH CAROLINA AND IN THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES REGION. THESE LANDOWNERS (HAVING LANDHOLDING OF ~20 ACRES AND BELOW) GENERALLY DO NOT REALIZE THE FULL BENEFIT OF THEIR LANDS AND THEREFORE ARE UNABLE TO COMPETE WITH LARGE-SCALE FARMS AND WOOD LANDOWNERS. USING OUR CURRENT FIVE-YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN BY AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE UNIT AT NCAT (I.E. MISSION POSSIBLE), OUR PROGRAM IS GEARED AT PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS TO GUIDE AND MOTIVATE THESE SMALL-SCALE, LIMITED RESOURCES AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND WOODLAND OWNERS TO MAKE MORE SUSTAINABLE DECISIONS. IT WILL NOT ONLY IMPROVE THEIR ECONOMIC CONDITIONS BUT ALSO IMPROVE OVERALL LIFESTYLE WHILE GENERATING LONG-TERM STEWARDS OF THE ENVIRONMENT. IN ADDITION, THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND PRACTICES TOWARDS MANAGING SOIL, WATER, AGRICULTURAL, AND FOREST LAND WILL REDUCE ENVIRONMENTAL FOOTPRINTS. OUR PROGRAM WILL IMPLEMENT THE FOLLOWING SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES: I) BUILD A VERY STRONG PARTNERSHIP WITH FAITH-BASED ORGANIZATIONS AND OTHER NOT-FOR-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS TO IDENTIFY CLUSTERS OF LANDOWNERS (YOUTH, ADULT, NEW, BEGINNING, AND VETERANS) INTERESTED IN REALIZING THE FULL BENEFIT OF THEIR LANDS; II) CONDUCT IN- SERVICE TRAINING (~TRAIN THE TRAINER TYPE) WITH OUR COUNTY AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES EXTENSION AGENTS AND OTHER PARAPROFESSIONALS INTERESTED IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES-RELATED OPERATIONS (I.E. SOI, WATER AND ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY) AND ALSO, LAND-LOSS ISSUES; AND III) ASSIST SMALL-SCALE GROWERS AND LANDOWNERS TO APPLY AND COMPLETE COST-SHARE APPLICATIONS FROM THE USDA AND ALSO, APPLY FOR EXISTING GOVERNMENT LOANS AND GRANTS RELATEDTO SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. USING THE EXISTING EDUCATIONAL TRAINING MATERIALS THROUGH THE TRAIN-THE-TRAINER MODEL, THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO TRAIN COUNTY EXTENSION AGENTS, SMALL-SCALE FARMERS, WOODLAND, AND OTHER LANDOWNERS WITH AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND AGROFORESTRY SKILLS AND THEIR PROPERTY BASICS TO STEM THE LAND LOSS. FOR SMALL-SCALE FARMERS AND WOODLAND OWNERS IN NORTH CAROLINA AND THE SOUTHERN UNITED STATES REGION, AGROFORESTRY CAN CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE BY MINIMIZING INPUTS AND COSTS, REDUCING ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS, AND PROVIDING ADDITIONAL ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO THE FARMERS AND WOODLAND OWNERS.

THE RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR EXTENSION ACTIVITIES RELATED TO FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES AT LAND GRANT UNIVERSITIES. THE USDA RENEWABLE RESOURCE EXTENSION ACT (RREA), PASSED BY CONGRESS IN 1978, PROVIDES FUNDING TO EXPAND THE REACH OF FOREST AND RANGELAND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AT 73 LAND GRANT UNIVERSITIES THROUGH BETTER COORDINATION AND DELIVERY, USE OF INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGIES, AND DEVELOPMENT OF EASILY REPLICABLE PROGRAM MODELS. THE RREA AUTHORIZED ANNUAL FUNDING LEVEL IS $30,000,000; HOWEVER, ONLY ABOUT $4,000,000 IS APPROPRIATED EACH YEAR. (I) 92% APPORTIONED TO STATES THROUGH A FORMULA AND (II) 8% APPLIED TO NATIONAL FOCUSED FUND PROJECTS VIA A COMPETITIVE GRANT PROCESS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDING IS TO ASSIST STATES IN CARRYING OUT AN EXTENSION PROGRAM DESIGNED TO ASSIST FOREST AND RANGE LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS IN MAKING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BASED ON RESEARCH FINDINGS. FOREST AND RANGELAND RESOURCES INCLUDE VEGETATION, WATER, FISHERIES ANDWILDLIFE, SOIL, AND RECREATION. NINE CRITICAL ISSUES, RECOGNIZED IN THE 2018 2022 RREA STRATEGIC PLAN THAT ALL ARE AFFECTED AT SOME LEVEL BY CLIMATE CHANGE, RESTORATION, AND LAND CONVERSION AND FRAGMENTATION INCLUDE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, LANDOWNER ENGAGEMENT, WATER AND WETLANDS, INTERGENERATIONAL TRANSFER, PUBLIC AWARENESS, WILDFIRE, INVASIVE SPECIES, RURAL ECONOMICS, WILDLIFE HABITAT AND MANAGEMENT. IN SOUTH CAROLINA, OUR SCSU1890 RESEARCH AND EXTENSION RREA PROGRAM IS TARGETING UNDERSERVED AND LIMITED RESOURCES LANDOWNERS WHO OWN SMALL  TRACTS TO MIDSIZE HOLDINGS AND INCLUDE YOUTH, BEGINNING FARMERS, RANCHERS, AND VETERANS ACROSS SOUTH CAROLINA RACIAL GROUPS. A TEAM OF REGIONAL EXTENSION AGENTS WORKING FOR SCSU1890 EXTENSION AND CLEMSON UNIVERSITY ARE ENGAGING IN CONDUCING EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS AND HANDS ON DEMONSTRATIONS ACROSS THE STATE. OTHER PROFESSIONALS AND PARAPROFESSIONALS FROM LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL AGENCIES INCLUDING: THE SCDA FORESTRY RESOURCES AND USDA NATURAL RESOURCESCONSERVATION SERVICE, FARM SERVICES AGENCY, AND RURAL DEVELOPMENT BRING A SYNERGY THAT IS HIGHLY NEEDED TO MEET THE STRATEGIES IN THE 2018 2022 RREA STRATEGIC PLAN.

RREA PROJECT ABSTRACT THE MAIN PURPOSE OF TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY’S RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT (RREA) PROJECT IS TO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT THE BENEFITS OF URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTS IN TENNESSEE. TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES WILL BE PERFORMED: 1 ) COLLECTING INFORMATION AND SYNTHESIZING EXISTING STUDIES ON THE BENEFITS OF TENNESSEE’S URBAN FORESTS; 2) IDENTIFYING TENNESSEE’S KEY URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY STAKEHOLDERS; 3) MEETING WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS TO GET THEIR INPUT ABOUT THE FORMAT OF THE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS; 4) DEVELOPING EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ACCORDINGLY AND DISSEMINATING THEM TO DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS VIA VARIOUS OUTREACH ACTIVITIES; AND 5) ENGAGING INTERESTED MINORITY COLLEGE GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AT TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY IN THE WHOLE PROCESS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 1) A BRIEF SUMMARY REPORT OF THE BENEFITS OF TENNESSEE’S URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTS; 2) EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ON THE BENEFITS OF URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY IN TENNESSEE; 3) A LIST OF TENNESSEE’S KEY URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY STAKEHOLDERS; 3) VARIOUS OUTREACH ACTIVITIES TAILORED TO DIFFERENT AUDIENCES; AND 4) EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING EXPERIENCE FOR MINORITY COLLEGE GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN AN HBCU-TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, URBAN FORESTS AND ARBORISTS, MINORITY COLLEGE GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, EXTENSION AGENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THEY WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT BY BETTER UNDERSTANDING THE BENEFITS OF TREES IN URBAN AREAS AND THEY CAN ALSO USE THE INFORMATION AND MATERIALS TO MAKE BETTER-INFORMED DECISIONS WHEN IT COMES TO URBAN AND COMMUNITY FOREST MANAGEMENT OR OTHER RELATED ISSUES.

VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY PROJECT ABSTRACT THE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE EXTENSION PROGRAMS THROUGH VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY (VSU) HAVE TRADITIONALLY FOCUSED ON LIMITED-RESOURCE LANDOWNERS. THE VSU RREA 2023 PROGRAM WILL BUILD ON THIS APPROACH BY CONTINUING SUPPORT FOR PROGRAMS, WORKSHOPS, AND DEMONSTRATIONS ABOUT PRODUCTION OF NON-TIMBER FOREST PRODUCTS, AS IN THE PAST, AND ALSO INCLUDING DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION ABOUT MANAGEMENT FOR TIMBER ON SMALL WOODLOTS AND ABOUT AGROFORESTRY AND NON-TIMBER SYSTEMS. SMALL WOODLOT MANAGEMENT AND MARKETING PROGRAMS WILL LARGELY FOCUS ON FORESTRY BASICS, INCLUDING PLANNING, SELLING TIMBER, AND BASIC SILVICULTURE. WITH REGARDS TO ALTERNATIVE FOREST PRODUCTION SYSTEMS, EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON GETTING LANDOWNERS THE MOST RELEVANT INFORMATION, AND ENCOURAGING THEM TO INNOVATE AND EXPLORE. GOALS / OBJECTIVES THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO ENHANCE ECONOMIC BENEFITS AND ENHANCE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT THAT WILL ADDRESS THE CROSS-CUTTING ISSUES OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, FOREST FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY AND URBANIZATION. THE RREA-SUPPORTED PROGRAM WILL ALSO BUILD ON INTEREST IN LONGLEAF AND SHORTLEAF PINE BY HELPING LANDOWNERS EXPLORE THE POSSIBILITY OF GOOD TIMBER QUALITY AND NTFPS. IN ADDITION, THERE WILL BE COLLABORATION WITH OTHER AREAS OF EXTENSION, SUCH AS HELPING LANDOWNERS DEVELOP MARKETING PLANS, FINANCIAL LITERACY TRAINING FOR FOREST LANDOWNERS, AND ESTATE PLANNING. THESE AREAS IMPACT THE ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY OF FORESTLANDS. COMPONENTS 1 - MARKETING AND ALTERNATIVE FOREST PRODUCTION SYSTEMS: A SIGNIFICANT ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCE IS STANDING IN SMALL AREAS ON THE PROPERTIES OF PRIVATE LANDHOLDERS IN VIRGINIA (ROSE 2009). ALSO, 58% OF LIMITED-RESOURCE FARMERS OWN WOODLOTS, WITH AN AVERAGE SIZE OF 55 ACRES (USDA 2007). IF THESE FORESTLANDS CANNOT PROVIDE ECONOMIC BENEFITS, LANDOWNERS WILL BE ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED, AND SOCIETY AS A WHOLE MAY LOSE AN IMPORTANT RENEWABLE RESOURCE IF FORESTS ARE CONVERTED TO OTHER LAND USES. PRODUCTION AND SALE OF TIMBER IS AN ECONOMIC BENEFIT FOR LANDOWNERS; HOWEVER, SMALL AND LIMITED-RESOURCE LANDOWNERS ARE AT A DISADVANTAGE: (1) TIMBER DOES NOT HELP SMALL AND LIMITED-RESOURCE LANDOWNERS MEET YEARLY CASH NEEDS; (2) THERE IS A LARGE INFORMATION GAP BETWEEN MOST LANDOWNERS AND FOREST INDUSTRY WORKERS; AND (3) ECONOMIES OF SCALE CAN MAKE LOGGING FOR SOME TIMBER PRODUCTS ON SMALL TRACTS UNECONOMICAL. COMPONENT 2 - URBAN FORESTRY: A MAJOR NEW EMPHASIS IN VSU’S RREA PROGRAM WILL BE URBAN FORESTRY. URBAN FOREST MANAGEMENT CAN HELP MEET URGENT NEEDS IN THE US, AND THE COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA. FOR INSTANCE, WELL-SELECTED AND WELL-PLACED TREES AND OTHER PERENNIAL VEGETATION CAN: REDUCE ENERGY CONSUMPTION AND COSTS FROM HEATING AND COOLING BUILDINGS, THEREBY PROMOTING ENERGY INDEPENDENCE AND A REDUCED CARBON FOOTPRINT; ENCOURAGE HEALTHY OUTDOOR LIVING HABITS; IMPROVE STORMWATER MANAGEMENT THEREBY REDUCING COSTS OF STORMWATER ENGINEERING AND POTENTIALLY IMPROVING WATER QUALITY IN THE IMPAIRED CHESAPEAKE BAY; PROVIDE BIOREMEDIATION OF CONTAMINATED SOILS/GROUNDWATER IN URBAN BROWNFIELD SITES; AND CAPTURE CARBON DIOXIDE FROM THE ATMOSPHERE (BOLUND AND HUNHAMMAR 1999). THE VSU RREA PROGRAM WILL COMPLEMENT THE DEVELOPMENT OF RESEARCH AND TEACHING PROGRAMS IN URBAN FORESTRY AT VSU. THE PURPOSE OF THE EXTENSION COMPONENT WILL BE TO PROVIDE SUPPORT TO COMMUNITIES TO MAXIMIZE THE BENEFITS OF TREES. VSU OUTCOMES: COMPONENT 1. ALTERNATIVE FOREST PRODUCTION SYSTEMS: DEMONSTRATE THE POTENTIAL FOR ECONOMIC RETURNS FROM NON-TRADITIONAL FOREST-BASED SYSTEMS, SUCH AS AGROFORESTRY SYSTEMS (INCLUDING SI LVOPASTURE AND FOREST FARMING OF NON-TIMBER FOREST PRODUCTS). SUPPORT NIPF LANDOWNERS TO INNOVATE NON-TRADITIONAL FOREST-BASED SYSTEMS. OUTCOME TARGET 2.1: DEMONSTRATION PRODUCTS AT RESEARCH STATION AND PRIVATE LANDHOLDINGS ARE SHOWN TO BE FINANCIALLY VIABLE, THROUGH MEASUREMENT OF REAL-WORLD COSTS AND REVENUES. OUTCOME TARGET 2.2: AT LEAST 100 LANDOWNERS IN VIRGINIA ESTABLISH AT LEAST ONE NEW ALTERNATIVE FOREST PRODUCTION ENTERPRISE. OUTCOME TARGET 2.3: AT LEAST 20 LANDOWNERS EXPERIMENT WITH INNOVATIVE PRACTICES AS A RESULT OF CONCEPTS LEARNED AND CONTACTS MADE. COMPONENT 2. URBAN FOREST MANAGEMENT: INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES PROVIDED BY TREES. AID COMMUNITIES IN DEVELOPMENT OF URBAN/COMMUNITY FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS. OUTCOME TARGET 3.1: PARTICIPANTS IN RREA-SUPPORTED EVENTS INCREASE AWARENESS OF ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES RELATIVE TO THEIR BASELINE KN OWLEDGE. OUTCOME TARGET 3.2: AT LEAST TWO COMMUNITIES ADOPT OR IMPROVE URBAN/COMMUNITY FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS. PROJECT DELIVERY METHOD VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY IS ACTIVELY BUILDING AND STRENGTHENING ITS PROGRAM FOR FORESTRY EXTENSION. THIS PROGRAM BUILDS ON TRADITIONAL (E.G., NON-TIMBER FOREST PRODUCTS; SERVING SMALL AND LIMITED-RESOURCE LANDOWNERS) AND EMERGING (E.G., URBAN HORTICULTURE AND AGRICULTURE) AREAS OF FOCUS FOR VSU. VSU’S AND RREA-SUPPORTED PROGRAMS WILL PRIMARILY BE MARKETED TO UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS - SMALL AND LIMITED-RESOURCE LANDOWNERS, AS WELL AS MINORITY AND ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES. VSU TRADITIONALLY HAS HAD THE LARGEST IMPACT BY DIRECTLY TARGETING THOSE COMMUNITIES. VSU FORESTRY EXTENSION WILL WORK IN COORDINATION WITH THE VSU SMALL FARM OUTREACH PROGRAM TO REACH OUT TO THESE STAKEHOLDERS. FURTHERMORE, AN ONGOING SURVEY FUNDED BY MCINTIRE-STENNIS FUNDS WILL HELP IDENTIFY STAKEHOLDERS WHO HAVE NEVER HAD CONTACT WITH VCE IN THE PAST. WHILE VSU CAN HELP THE EXISTING FORESTRY EXTENSION PROGRAMS TO REACH NEW AUDIENCES, IT IS NOT THE INTENT OF VCE/VSU TO EXCLUDE OTHER INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS. VIRGINIA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION IS A SINGLE INSTITUTION, AND VSU AND VIRGINIA TECH WILL CONTINUE TO WORK TOGETHER TO IDENTIFY WAYS TO COMPLEMENT EFFORTS TO CREATE SYNERGIES. FURTHERMORE, VSU WILL WORK WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS TO IDENTIFY COMMON FOCUS AREAS AND NEEDS IN VIRGINIA. AREAS THAT ARE CURRENTLY RECEIVING ATTENTION FROM NUMEROUS VIRGINIA ORGANIZATIONS INCLUDE RESTORATION OF SHORTLEAF AND LONGLEAF PINE, AND WATER QUALITY IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY. EMERGING THEMES OF INTEREST IN VIRGINIA INCLUDE BIOENERGY AND MARKETS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES. IT WILL BE IMPORTANT FOR VSU TO STAY ABREAST OF THESE THEMES AND INTEGRATE THEM INTO THE THREE COMPONENTS DESCRIBED ABOVE BECAUSE THEY CAN HELP VSU COOPERATE WITH OTHER INSTITUTIONS, AND CAPTURE GREATER PUBLIC INTEREST. MONITORING AND EVALUATION: MONITORING AND EVALUATION ARE CRUCIAL ELEMENTS TO BE ABLE TO ADAPT AND IMPROVE PROGRAMS AND TO ENSURE LONG-TERM SUCCESS. WE INTEND TO MEASURE AND MONITOR THE OUTPUT AND OUTCOME TARGETS DESCRIBED ABOVE. OUTPUTS ARE MOST EASILY MEASURED: THEY CAN BE QUANTIFIED IN TERMS OF NUMBER OF WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS, NUMBER OF PUBLICATIONS, ETC. OUTCOMES, HOWEVER, IMPLY A CHANGE IN BEHAVIOR BY THE AUDIENCE, AND CAN BE SOMEWHAT MORE DIFFICULT TO MEASURE. EACH DELIVERY METHOD NECESSITATES DIFFERENT OUTCOME MONITORING AND EVALUATIONTOOLS, SOME OF WHICH REQUIRE SPECIFIC FUNDING. (A) DEM ONSTRATION SITES WILL HAVE LOGBOOKS FOR VISITOR INFORMATION AND SUGGESTIONS (COUNTS OF VISITORS MEASURE OUTPUT). (B) COSTS AND REVENUES OF DEMONSTRATION SITES WILL BE LOGGED TO ESTIMATE FINANCIAL RETURNS. (C) IN-EVENT QUESTIONNAIRES AND OCCASIONAL POST-EVENT SURVEYS. (D) REVIEW OF CONTINUANCE OF PRACTICES AFTER SUPPORT IS ENDED THROUGH FORMAL OR INFORMAL SURVEYS.

2022 DELAWARE RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION PROGRAM ABSTRACT DELAWARE HAS AN INCREASING NUMBER OF FOREST ACREAGE THAT IS BEING CONVERTED TO HOUSES AND PARKING LOTS. THE STATE IS ALSO LOSING MANY OF ITS NATURAL RESOURCE-BASED BUSINESSES, WHICH HAS A NEGATIVE IMPACT ON LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND FAMILIES. THE LAND CONVERSION PROBLEM CAN BE RESOLVED THROUGH EDUCATION AND AWARENESS OF THE PUBLIC THROUGH TOURS, WORKSHOPS, AND DEMONSTRATIONS IMPLEMENTED BY DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY. OUR STAFF WILL ALSO HELP TO EDUCATE CURRENT AND FUTURE NATURAL RESOURCE ENTREPRENEURS ABOUT THE EXISTING OR POTENTIAL NEW FORESTRY BUSINESSES AND PRACTICES IN AN ATTEMPT TO REVERSE THE CURRENT LOSS OF OPPORTUNITIES IN THIS HISTORIC INDUSTRY. THE MAIN OBJECTIVE OF THE RREA PROGRAM WILL BE TO FACILITATE FORESTRY-BASED ENTERPRISES “INCLUDING WOOD PRODUCTS AND NON-TIMBER FORE ST PRODUCTS” IN DELAWARE. DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION (DSU) WILL ADDRESS THIS OBJECTIVE BY PRESENTING WORKSHOPS, WHICH WILL GIVE OVER 150 PEOPLE IN THE STATE OF DELAWARE AWARENESS OF THE NEW AND EXISTING FORESTRY BUSINESS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INCREASE IN GENERAL KNOWLEDGE AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY IN DELAWARE BY DEVELOPING EDUCATIONAL AWARENESS PROGRAMS FOR YOUTH. TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, WE WILL DESIGN ON OUTDOOR TOURS TO REACH A DIVERSE AUDIENCE OF APPROXIMATELY 400 ADULTS AND SCHOOL-AGED CHILDREN IN ORDER TO STRENGTHEN THEIR KNOWLEDGE OF LAND AND FOREST CONSERVATION. THE RREA PROJECT IN DELAWARE WITH INCREASE THE NUMBER OF ACRES UNDER NEW MANAGEMENT PRACTICES BY 15% IN DELAWARE. DSU STAFF WILL WORK WITH 75 PROPERTY OWNERS THROUGH SITE VISITS TO INCREASE BOTH KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS OF THE OWNERS. THE GOAL IS TO DEVELOP SOME NEW PLANS FOR ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY PRACTICES IN DELAWARE. THE APPROACH WILL HAVE DELAWARE STATE UNIVERSITY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION (DSU) CONDUCTING THREE WORKSHOPS TO EDUCATE LANDOWNERS AND ENTREPRENEURS ABOUT OPPORTUNITIES THAT EXIST WITHIN THE FORESTRY INDUSTRY. DSU WILL ALSO DELIVER OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION TOURS TO GIVE YOUTH AND ADULTS HANDS-ON LEARNING ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENT AND OUR NATURAL RESOURCES. WORKSHOPS, EDUCATIONAL TOURS AND DEMONSTRATIONS WILL BE ASSESSED BY MEASURING PARTICIPANT NUMBERS FOR EACH EVENT AND THROUGH WRITTEN EVALUATION FORMS. EXTENSION AGENTS WILL BE PROVIDING PROPERTY OWNERS WITH ONE-ON-ONE STYLE EDUCATION ON FOREST HEALTH, WATER QUALITY, AND WILDLIFE HABITAT. THE QUALITY OF WORK PERFORMED BY DSU STAFF WILL BE MEASURED BY THE IMPACT OF CONSERVATION PLANS DEVELOPED ON EACH PROPERTY, THE NUMBER OF PERSONAL CONTACTS MADE, AND BY THE NUMBER OF ACRES ENHANCED THROUGH GOOD CONSERVATION PRACTICES.

FORESTS COVER 13.8 MILLION ACRES IN LOUISIANA (48% OF TOTAL LAND COVER) AND REPRESENT A CRITICALLY IMPORTANT ECONOMIC, ECOLOGICAL, AND CULTURAL RESOURCE TO THE STATE. FIFTY-NINE OF LOUISIANA’S 64 PARISHES CONTAIN LAND CAPABLE OF PRODUCING TIMBER TO SUPPORT THE FOREST PRODUCTS INDUSTRY, AND ~87% OF FORESTLAND AND ~88% OF TIMBERLAND IS PRIVATELY OWNED. AS ONE OF THE TOP AGRICULTURAL COMMODITIES, FORESTS SUPPORT MORE THAN 25,000 JOBS IN LOUISIANA. IN ADDITION, FOREST-BASED RECREATION CONTRIBUTES CONSIDERABLE INCOME TO THE STATE’S ECONOMY EACH YEAR (E.G. HUNTING LEASES, WILDLIFE VIEWING) AND ALL RESIDENTS BENEFIT FROM THE ECOLOGICAL SERVICES AND SCENIC BEAUTY OF LOUISIANA’S FORESTED SYSTEMS. THE RREA STRATEGIC PLAN FOR FY 2018–2022 IDENTIFIED NINE CRITICAL ISSUES FACED BY PRIVATE FOREST AND RANGELAND OWNERS/MANAGERS IN THE U.S., WHICH INCLUDED ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, LANDOWNER ENGAGEMENT, PUBLIC AWARENESS, INVASIVE SPECIES, WILDFIRE PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT, RURAL COMMUNITIES, WATER AND WETLANDS, GENERATIONAL SUCCESSION AND LAND OWNERSHIP CHANGES, AND FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT. THESE CHALLENGES ARE ECHOED BY SURVEYS DISTRIBUTED TO LOUISIANA’S FOREST LANDOWNERS BY THE LSU AGCENTER AND IN THE 2020 FOREST ACTION PLAN DEVELOPED BY THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY. FURTHER, OUR CLIENTS CONSISTENTLY REQUEST MORE INFORMATION ON MARKET TRENDS, TAX AND INCENTIVE PROGRAMS, PUBLIC POLICY, TECHNOLOGY, CARBON MARKETS, AMONG OTHERS. THE LSU AGCENTER’S FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE EXTENSION TEAM WILL (1) PROVIDE FOREST LANDOWNERS AND LAND MANAGERS WITH RESOURCES THAT PROMOTE PROFIT AND RESOURCE SUSTAINABILITY, INCLUDING INFORMATION ON THE TOPICS IDENTIFIED ABOVE; AND (2) INFORM OUR DIVERSE CLIENTS (E.G., ADULTS AND YOUTH FROM RURAL AND URBAN AREAS) ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF FORESTS TO LOUISIANA AND BEYOND. WE WILL DISSEMINATE THIS CRITICAL INFORMATION TO OUR CLIENTS USING A COMBINATION OF TRADITIONAL (E.G., PRINTED AND ON-LINE FACT SHEETS AND PUBLICATIONS; FIELD DAYS; DEMONSTRATIONS; FORUMS, SITE VISITS) AND NON-TRADITIONAL (E.G., WEBINARS, SOCIAL MEDIA) TECHNIQUES. WE WILL USE IN-PERSON SURVEYS, ON-LINE QUESTIONNAIRES, AND WEB-BASED ANALYTICS TO ASSESS THE OUTCOMES OF OUR PROGRAMS (E.G., INCREASE IN KNOWLEDGE, VALUE OF INFORMATION, SOCIAL MEDIA ENGAGEMENT). WE WILL USE THIS INFORMATION TO QUANTIFY THE IMPACT OF OUR PROGRAMS AND TO ADJUST FUTURE PROGRAMMING AS NEEDED.

RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT FUNDS ARE UTILIZED BY MSU EXTENSION FORESTRY FACULTY AND STAFF TO PROVIDE ASSISTANCE AND TRAINING TO PRIVATE FOREST LANDOWNERS, AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS AND THE COMMERCIAL WOOD PRODUCTS INFRASTRUCTURE TO CONSERVE AND IMPROVE FOREST, WINDBREAK AND BACKYARD TREE RESILIENCE AND PRODUCTIVITY ACROSS MONTANA. FORESTS AND TREES ARE A VITALLY IMPORTANT RESOURCE AS A SOURCE OF WOOD FIBER, ENVIRONMENTAL (AND WATER-WATERSHED) QUALITY AND ENERGY CONSERVATION AND PRODUCTION ACROSS THE STATE. THE HIGHLY VARIABLE CLIMATE OF THE NORTHERN ROCKIES THAT IS FURTHER AFFECTED BY CLIMATE-CHANGE, CREATES ANNUAL FLUCTUATIONS IN MOISTURE AND TEMPERATURE EXTREMES THAT AFFECT TREE GROWTH AND SURVIVAL. MSU EXTENSION FOCUSES ON TEACHING LANDOWNERS AND FOREST/TREE SERVICE PROVIDERS SCIENCE-BASED PRACTICES FOR ENHANCING TREE SURVIVAL, GROWTH AND RESILIENCE FROM PESTS AND NATURAL DISTURBANCES SUCH AS BARK BEETLE OUTBREAKS AND WILDFIRES. ANNUAL CORE KNOWLEDGE WORKSHOPS ARE DESIGNED ANDCONDUCTED FOR LANDOWNERS, LOGGERS AND PROFESSIONAL FORE STERS TO HELP PLAN BOTH SHORT AND LONG-TERM SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AND A SAFE WORKING ENVIRONMENT. ADDITIONAL WORKSHOPS, VIDEOS, RADIO PROGRAMS, NEWSLETTERS AND MULTIMEDIA PRESENTATIONS ARE OFFERED EVERY YEAR TO ADDRESS SPECIFIC SEASONAL AND EPISODIC ISSUES THAT THREATEN FOREST AND TREE VITALITY. AN ANNUAL WEEK-LONG “NATURAL RESOURCES YOUTH CAMP” THAT TARGETS 14–18-YEAR-OLD Y OUTH IS OFFERED TO PROVIDE A BASIC INTRODUCTION TO THE DIFFERENT ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES SUCH AS RANGE, FOREST, SOILS, RECREATION, WATER, AND GEOLOGY, AS WELL AS FUTURE CAREER OPPORTUNITIES. MSU EXTENSION FORESTRY ALSO HELPS COORDINATE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES WITH FEDERAL AND STATE LAND MANAGEMENT COST-SHARE ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS TO HELP LANDOWNERS IMPLEMENT NEW KNOWLEDGE.

RE: FFY23 COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAMS AT THE 1862 INSTITUTIONS = RREA COLORADO STATE UNIVERSITY (CSU) EXTENSION EMPOWERS COLORADANS TO ADDRESS IMPORTANT AND EMERGING COMMUNITY NEEDS USING DYNAMIC, SCIENCE-BASED EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES. FOR OVER 100 YEARS, CSU EXTENSION HAS HELPED PEOPLE IN COLORADO FIND THE ANSWERS THEY NEED FOR A HEALTHY HOME LIFE, SUCCESSFUL BUSINESS AND THRIVING COMMUNITY. OBJECTIVES FUNDS REQUESTED WILL BE USED TO DELIVER CSU EXTENSION’S RENEWABLE RESOURCES PROGRAMMING ACROSS THE STATE OF COLORADO AND BRING THE UNIVERSITY’S RESEARCH-BASED RESOURCES TO LOCAL COMMUNITIES. CSU EXTENSION’S RREA PROGRAM WILL ASSIST FOREST AND RANGE LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS IN MAKING THE BEST RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BASED ON RESEARCH FINDINGS. RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS WILL BE FOCUSED ON FOREST AND RANGELAND RESOURCES, INCLUDING VEGETATION, WATER, FISH AND WILDLIFE, AND SOIL. METHODS EMPLOYED CSU EXTENSION’S RENEWABLE RESOURCES PROGRAM WILL MEET THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT BY IMPARTING INFORMATION ON THESE SUBJECTS THROUGH RESEARCH-BASED DEMONSTRATIONS, PUBLICATIONS, AND INFORMATION IN CONNECTION WITH THESE SUBJECTS. CSU’S RREA PROGRAM COMBINES HANDS-ON LEARNING, APPLIED SCIENCE, AND PROGRAM DATA TO DELIVER LOCAL PROGRAMMING ACROSS 63 COLORADO COUNTIES. THIS EFFORT IS ACCOMPLISHED THRU IN-PERSON AND REMOTE INSTRUCTION TO FOREST AND RANGE LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS, THE DISSEMINATION OF PRINT AND ELECTRONIC MEDIA, AND ON-DEMAND ACCESS TO RENEWABLE RESOURCE SPECIALISTS. BY EMPLOYING THESE METHODS, CSU’S RREA PROGRAM SUPPORTS COLORADANS IN MAKING INFORMED MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BASED ON RESEARCH FINDINGS IN FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES.

MAPLE SYRUP PRODUCTION) • NEW AND IMPROVED NON‐FOOD PRODUCTS (I.E. CHRISTMAS TREES) THE PROGRAM UTILIZES FUNDS IN ORDER TO SUPPORT OUTREACH FOR OHIO’S WOODLAND OWNERS. THIS INCLUDES CLASSES, WORKSHOPS AND WEBINARS ON IMPORTANT TOPICS RELATED TO FOREST MANAGEMENT AND STEWARDSHIP. FUNDS ARE ALSO UTILIZED TO CREATE HANDS ON DEMONSTRATIONS AREAS FOR WOODLAND OWNERS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND PRACTICES THEY CAN IMPLEMENT ON THEIR OWN PROPERTIES TO ACCOMPLISH THEIR GOALS AND OBJECTIVES. THESE DEMONSTRATION AREAS WILL INCLUDE SITES WITH INTERPRETIVE SIGNAGE FOR PASSIVE WOODLAND OWNER ACCESS. THE CENTER FOCUS OF THESE FUNDS GOES TO IMPROVING WOODLAND OWNER EDUCATION IN OHIO AND STRIVING TO KEEP THEM UP TO DATE ON CURRENT ISSUES THAT WILL IMPACT THEIR FORESTS.

FEDERAL PURPOSE THE PURPOSE OF OUR RREA PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE EXTENSION PROGRAMMING DESIGNED TO ASSIST FOREST AND RANGE LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS IN MAKING SCIENCE-BASED RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS TO MEET THE FOREST AND RANGELAND SAFETY, PRODUCTION, PROTECTION, AND SUSTAINABILITY NEEDS OF THE OWNER AND SOCIETY. TOPICAL ISSUES INCLUDE: LANDOWNER ENGAGEMENT; PUBLIC AWARENESS AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT; INVASIVE SPECIES; WILDFIRE PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT; RURAL COMMUNITIES; WATER AND WETLANDS; GENERATIONAL SUCCESSION AND OTHER LAND-OWNERSHIP CHANGES; FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT; AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. WSUS RREA PROGRAM IS ALIGNED WITH THE USDA STRATEGIC GOAL #1, TO “COMBAT CLIMATE CHANGE TO SUPPORT AMERICA’S WORKING LANDS, NATURAL RESOURCES AND COMMUNITIES.” OF THE TOPICS WE ADDRESS, WE FOCUS ON THE RREA GOAL ENHANCING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON WORKING FORESTS AND RANGELANDS. OUR ISSUES AREAS ARE 1) FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH, AND 2) RANGELAND STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH. OUR FOCUS IS WATERSHED PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT, MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF FOREST AND RANGE FIRES, AND THE MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY OF FOREST AND RANGE RESOURCES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE WSU EXTENSION FORESTRY <(>&<)> RANGE TEAM WILL PROVIDE THE UNBIASED, RESEARCH-BASED EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO MEET THE NEEDS OF LANDOWNERS AND SOCIETY. THROUGH FACE-TO-FACE AND ONLINE DELIVERIES OF CLASSES, FIELD DAYS, WORKSHOPS, SEMINARS, CONFERENCES, PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT, SHORT COURSES, RECRUITMENT, TRAININGS, CONSULTATIONS, MEDIA WORK, AND EDUCATIONAL COUNSELING AND FACILITATION, LANDOWNERS WILL IMPROVE LEARNING AND APPLICATION OF NEW IDEAS THAT WILL LEAD TO DESIRABLE FUTURE CONDITIONS. THESE PROGRAMS WILL BE PROVIDED BOTH LIVE AND PRE-RECORDED, TO SUIT PREFERENCE AND CONVENIENCE FOR LANDOWNERS TO ACCESS NEEDED INFORMATION. WHEN NECESSARY, INFORMATION WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE IN SPANISH FOR THOSE WITH ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE. PHYSICAL ACCESS AND DISABILITIES WILL BE INQUIRED ABOUT FOLLOWED BY ADA STANDARDS. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES WSU EXPECTS TO DELIVER 100 ACTIVITIES (DESCRIBED ABOVE) REACHING 10,000 OWNERS AND MANAGERS AND POSITIVELY IMPACTING THE CONDITION OF ½-MILLION ACRES OF FOREST AND RANGELAND. COMPREHENSIVE ACHIEVEMENTS WILL 1) TO ENHANCE FOREST AND RANGE SUSTAINABILITY BY DEVELOPING OWNER/ MANAGER CAPACITIES TO IMPROVE VIGOR AND PRODUCTIVITY; 2) PROMOTE FOREST AND RANGE LAND RESILIENCE BY PREPARING OWNER/ MANAGER CAPACITIES TO RESPOND TO THE ABIOTIC AND BIOTIC IMPACTS CAUSED BY WILDFIRE, DROUGHT, WILDLIFE DAMAGE, INVASIVE SPECIES, HARMFUL INSECTS AND DISEASE, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS PERPETUATED BY CLIMATE CHANGE; AND 3) DIVERSITY FOREST AND RANGE LANDOWNERS/ MANAGERS STEWARDSHIP OPPORTUNITIES THAT LEAD TO MULTIPLE-USE BENEFITS. WE BASE THESE EXPECTATIONS ON ACCOMPLISHMENTS DERIVED BY THE PAST 15 YEARS OF PROGRAM EVALUATION DATA. THESE DATA REVEALED THAT LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS ENGAGED IN IN LEARNING-- CREATING AWARENESS AND CHANGES IN ATTITUDE, IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS, AND MOTIVATED THE APPLICATION AND/OR THE TRANSFER OF TECHNOLOGY TO PRACTICES  ON THE GROUND. WE EXPECT BEST PRACTICE DECISIONS AND BEHAVIORS EXECUTED WILL LEAD TO COMPREHENSIVE ACHIEVEMENTS AND IMPROVE THE ECONOMIC, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND ADD VALUE TO NATURAL RESOURCE CONDITIONS AND PRODUCTS. NOTEWORTHY IMPACTS WE EXPECT WILL: 1) IMPROVED FOREST <(>&<)> RANGELAND HEALTH; 2) DECREASE RISK FROM WILDFIRE; 3) IMPROVE HABITAT; 4) DECREASE RISKS FROM INSECT OR DISEASE; 5) IMPROVE PRODUCTIVITY FOR GROWING TREES AND FORAGE; 6) DECREASE RISK OF EROSION; 7) INCREASE FORAGE AND TREE COVER; 8) IMPROVE WOOD QUALITY; 9) IMPROVE INCOME OPPORTUNITY; 10) IMPROVE IDENTIFICATION AND PROTECTION OF CULTURAL RESOURCES AND SPECIAL SITES; 11) IMPROVE RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES; AND 12) DECREASE NOXIOUS WEEDS/ INVASIVE SPECIES. INDICATORS OF LEARNING (SHORT-TERM CHANGES) WILL BE ASSESSMENTS OF AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE, AND SKILLS. WE WILL NOT SEEK INFORMATION REGARDING MANAGEMENT OPINIONS, ASPIRATIONS,OR MOTIVATIONS, THOUGH WE RECOGNIZE THAT THESE ARE SOMETIMES USED FOR EVALUATION METRICS. INSTEAD, WE SEEK TO MEASURE CHANGES IN OWNER/MANAGER BEHAVIORS, PRACTICES, AND WHEN APPROPRIATE, DECISIONS (FOR EXAMPLE, ASKING FOR A FORESTER VISIT, OR, APPLYING FOR COST-SHARE ASSISTANCE TO IMPLEMENT A PLANNING CONTRACT). WSU WILL DISSEMINATE INFORMATION VIA PERSONAL CONNECTIONS AND AFFILIATIONS, PARTNER NETWORKS, AND THROUGH STAFF EMAIL LISTS. WE WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE NATIVE AMERICAN AGROFORESTRY ROUNDTABLE AND OTHER FORUMS THAT ENGAGE WSU WITH TRIBAL CONNECTIONS THROUGH THE EXTENSION SERVICE AND THROUGH TRIBAL NATURAL RESOURCE PROGRAMS. WE WILL CREATE ONLINE VIDEO CONTENT, CREATE POPULAR NEWSLETTERS AND RELEVANT MEDIA, AND WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE UNIVERSITY PRESS. MANY VIDEOS WILL BE HOSTED ON YOUTUBE AND INDEXED ON OUR WEBSITE. OTHER VECTORS OF DISSEMINATION WILL INCLUDE SOCIAL MEDIA PLATFORMS (TWITTER, FACEBOOK, INSTAGRAM). PROGRAMS AND PUBLICATIONS WILL BE IDENTIFIABLE FOR BOTH ACCESSIBILITIES, AND FOR BILINGUAL AVAILABILITY WHERE WE SEE MOST FIT (SPANISH VERSION WHERE USER IS EXPECTED TO SPEAK SPANISH AS A FIRST LANGUAGE). WE WILL LEVERAGE OUR OUTREACH BY UTILIZING PARTNERSHIPS SUCH AS THE WA ASSOCIATION OF CONSERVATION ASSOCIATIONS, WA FARM FORESTRY ASSOCIATION, WA SOCIETY OF AMERICAN FORESTERS, INLAND EMPIRE SOCIETY OF AMERICAN FORESTERS, FORESTRY COLLABORATIVES, AND COUNTY PARTNERSHIPS. WE WILL CONTRIBUTE TO NGO PURPOSES THAT HOLD COMMON CONSERVATION GOALS FOR INFORMING THEIR MEMBERSHIP AND THE PUBLIC, SUCH AS THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, AMERICAN TREE FARM SYSTEM, AMERICAN FOREST FOUNDATIONS, ROCKY MOUNTAIN ELK FOUNDATION, AND VARIOUS LAND TRUSTS. WE WILL CAPTURE BOTH DIRECT AND INDIRECT CONTACTS FOR EVALUATION AND IMPACT ASSESSMENT. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OUR RREA PROGRAM TARGETS NON-INDUSTRIAL PRIVATE LANDOWNERS (NIPF) AND PROFESSIONAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS (PRACTICING FORESTERS, LOGGERS, RANCHERS, SILVICULTURAL CONTRACTORS, AND TRIBAL NATURAL RESOURCE EMPLOYEES). WASHINGTON HAS 215,000 NIPF OWNERS THAT CONTROL 5.8 MILLION ACRES OF FORESTLAND, MAKING THIS THE LARGEST RURAL LAND USE GROUP IN THE STATE. ANOTHER 4.0 MILLION ACRES OF PRIVATE LAND IS GRAZED AS EITHER OPEN AND FORESTED OR TRANSITORY GRASS/ CROPLAND. MOST LANDOWNERS MANAGE FOR MULTIPLE OBJECTIVES, SUCH AS PRODUCTIVE TIMBER AND RANGE LAND, WILDLIFE HABITAT, AND RECREATION. HOWEVER, MOST NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS AGREE THAT MOST LANDOWNERS LACK THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILL TO ACCOMPLISH THEIR PERSONAL OBJECTIVES. THIS JEOPARDIZES THE HEALTH AND SAFETY OF THE LAND, THE ECONOMIC WELL-BEING OF THE LANDOWNER, AND THE PROTECTION OF PUBLIC RESOURCES SUCH AS WATER, AIR, AND WILDLIFE. MOST LANDOWNERS LACK A WRITTEN MANAGEMENT PLAN WHICH PROVIDES THE BIOLOGICAL, PHYSICAL, AND POLITICAL INFORMATION NECESSARY TO MAKE SOUND DECISIONS TO EXECUTE BEST PRACTICES IN A LOGICAL AND FEASIBLE MANNER. FOREST AND RANGE OWNERS NEED A SURROUND-SOUND APPROACH OF EDUCATIONAL DELIVERIES OF MANAGEMENT INFORMATIONTO PROTECT THEIR VALUES WITHOUT COMPROMISING THOSE AMENITY AND COMMODITY FOREST AND RANGE VALUES FOR THEMSELVES, SOCIETY, AND FUTURE FOR GENERATIONS.

THE WV STATE UNIVERSITY RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE BASIC INFORMATION TO THE CITIZENS OF WEST VIRGINIA THAT WILL ENABLE THEM TO BE STEWARDS OF OUR STATE’S NATURAL RESOURCES. THIS PROGRAM EQUIPS SMALL LANDOWNERS WITH BEST-PRACTICE INFORMATION REGARDING LAND AND WATER MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING HOW TO MANAGE FORESTS IN A CHANGING CLIMATE WITH ASSOCIATED FOREST THREATS, STREAMSIDE RESTORATION, AND NON-TIMBER FOREST PRODUCTS. LANDOWNERS ARE SUPPLIED WITH BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO DEVELOP ALTERNATIVE LAND MANAGEMENT ENTERPRISES BOTH IN URBAN AND RURAL AREAS TO EXPAND INCOME OPPORTUNITIES, AS WELL AS INFORMATION ON SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES REGARDING WATER RESOURCES. WVSU ALSO CONTINUES THE DEVELOPMENT OF SPATIAL SERVICES SUCH AS DRONE-CONDUCTED LAND AND FOREST MAPPING AND COLLECTION OF HYPERLOCAL WEATHER DATA.

WEST VIRGINIA UNIVERSITY RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM ABSTRACT WEST VIRGINIA HAS 12 MILLION ACRES OF DIVERSE AND VALUABLE FORESTLAND; NEARLY 80 PERCENT IS OWNED BY PRIVATE NONINDUSTRIAL FORESTLAND OWNERS (NIPFS). THESE NIPFS ARE ALSO KNOWN AS FAMILY FOREST OWNERS, CONVEYING BOTH THE PRIVATE NATURE OF THE OWNERSHIP AND THE POLITICAL AND ENVIRONMENT SIGNIFICANCE OF THESE DIVERSE BUT WIDESPREAD PROPERTIES. MOST OF THE OWNERS OF THESE WOODLANDS HAVE NEVER MET WITH A PROFESSIONAL FORESTER AND FEWER YET HAVE A WRITTEN PLAN FOR THEIR PROPERTIES. THE OPTIONS AVAILABLE TO THESE UNINFORMED WOODLAND OWNERS ARE FEW, WHICH PUTS THEM IN A NON-OPTIMAL SITUATION, ESPECIALLY IF THEY WOULD BE APPROACHED BY A TIMBER BUYER. LACKING INFORMATION ABOUT TIMBER MARKETING METHODS OR WHO THEY COULD CONTACT FOR ADVICE ON HOW TO BEST SELL THE TIMBER PUTS THEM AT A COMPETITIVE DISADVANTAGE. HENCE, THERE IS A CRUCIAL NEED FOR THESE WOODLAND OWNERS TO GET CONNECTED TO THEIR WOODLAND OWNING PEERS AND TONATURAL RESOURCES PROFESSIONALS. TRADITIONAL AND NOVEL APPROACHES RELATED TO BIOMASS ENERGY, ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, INVASIVE SPECIES, AND WATER AND WETLANDS WILL BE USED IN THE 2022-20257 WEST VIRGINIA RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAMMING TO REACH AND INFORM BROAD AUDIENCES. AUDIENCES WILL INCLUDE LANDOWNERS, YOUTH, NATURE ENTHUSIASTS, AND NATURAL RESOURCES PROFESSIONALS. EACH YEAR, THE WV RREA EXPECTS TO SEE OVER 1100 INDIVIDUALS AT RREA PROGRAMMING EVENTS AND WILL MULTIPLY THESE CONNECTIONS WITH PEER-TO-PEER AND ONLINE SOCIAL NETWORKS THAT ARE PART OF THE PROGRAM. EACH PROGRAM WILL BE EVALUATED USING PRE- AND/OR POST-WORKSHOP EVALUATIONS TO ASSESS THE EFFICACY OF THE RESPECTIVE TRAINING SESSIONS.

UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY USES EXTENSION CAPACITY FUNDS TO SUPPORT VARIOUS PROGRAMS. PROGRAMMATIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE WORKSHOPS, DEMONSTRATIONS, E-COURSES, IN-PERSON CLASSES, AS WELL AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF PRINT AND ELECTRONIC RESOURCES. THESE PROGRAMS, AND ASSOCIATED DELIVERABLES, OUTCOMES, AND BENEFICIARIES, INCLUDE: UTAH 4-H: POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT 4 H PROGRAMS ARE GROUNDED IN THE BELIEF THAT YOUTH LEARN BEST BY DOING. KIDS AND TEENS COMPLETE HANDS-ON PROJECTS IN MANY EDUCATIONAL AREAS INCLUDING SCIENCE, HEALTH, AGRICULTURE, AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT. 4-H ALLOWS YOUTH TO ENGAGE IN THEIR EDUCATIONAL INTERESTS IN A POSITIVE ENVIRONMENT WHERE THEY RECEIVE GUIDANCE FROM ADULT MENTORS, WHILE ALSO BEING ENCOURAGED TO TAKE ON PROACTIVE LEADERSHIP ROLES. KIDS CAN CONCENTRATE ON ONE FOCUS AREA OR THEY CAN TRY A VARIETY OF PROGRAMS THROUGHOUT THEIR 4 H EXPERIENCE. MAJOR EDUCATIONAL AREAS IN UTAH 4-H AT UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY (USU) EXTENSION INCLUDE 4-H STEM, 4-H HEALTHY LIVING, AND CIVIC ENGAGEMENT. 4-H STEM AND AGRICULTURE PROGRAMS EQUIP YOUNG PEOPLE WITH THE SKILLS THEY NEED TO FIND THEIR PASSION AND SUCCEED IN A CAREER. FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE COMPUTER SCIENCE, ROBOTICS, ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE, AGRI-SCIENCE, FINANCIAL LITERACY, ENTREPRENEURSHIP, AND VETERINARY SCIENCE. 4-H HEALTHY LIVING EMPOWERS YOUTH TO BE HEALTHY – BODY AND MIND – WITH THE SKILLS TO MAKE HEALTHY DECISIONS AND LEAD HEALTHY LIFESTYLES. HAVING THE CONFIDENCE AND SKILLS TO LEAD HEALTHY LIFESTYLES NOT ONLY IMPROVES OVERALL WELL-BEING BUT ALSO ENABLES YOUTH TO TACKLE LIFE’S CHALLENGES TODAY AND BECOME LEADERS IN THEIR LIVES, CAREERS, AND COMMUNITIES AS THEY GROW INTO RESPONSIBLE ADULTHOOD. 4-H CIVIC ENGAGEMENT EMPOWERS YOUTH TO BE WELL-INFORMED CITIZENS WHO ARE ACTIVELY ENGAGED IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND THE WORLD. RESEARCH SHOWS THAT THE 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM PLAYS A SPECIAL AND VITAL ROLE IN THE LIVES OF AMERICA’S YOUNG PEOPLE. YOUTH CAN THRIVE WHEN PRESENTED WITH RESOURCES FOR HEALTHY DEVELOPMENT FOUND IN FAMILIES, SCHOOLS, AND COMMUNITIES - REGARDLESS OF THEIR BACKGROUND, SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, RACE, AND GENDER. 4-H PROGRAMS LAUNCH YOUNG PEOPLE INTO HEALTHY AND PRODUCTIVE LIVES. THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF 4-H UTAH ARE TO (A) FACILITATE POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT THROUGH EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES THAT FOSTER YOUTH COMPETENCE, CHARACTER, CONNECTION, CARING, CONFIDENCE, AND CONTRIBUTION, AND (B) EMPOWER YOUTH TO PURSUE THEIR PASSION FOR A SUCCESSFUL CAREER AND HEALTHY LIFE. FACULTY INVOLVED IN UTAH 4-H ACTIVELY CONDUCTS RESEARCH IN EARLY EDUCATION, POSITIVE YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, YOUTH LEAD ERSHIP, AND CAREER READINESS. ALL RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN UTAH 4-H INCLUDE FIELD DAYS, AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMMING, AND PROJECTS FOCUSING ON TOPICS RELATED TO AGRICULTURE, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND ANIMAL SCIENCE, ART AND CRAFTS, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES, HEALTHY LIVING, AND SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATHEMATICS (STEM). AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES: AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY UTAH HAS OVER 18,000 FARMS AND RANCHES SPANNING 11 MILLION ACRES, WHICH GENERATE MORE THAN $21 BILLION IN TOTAL ECONOMIC OUTPUT (AFTER ADJUSTING FOR THE MULTIPLIER EFFECT). WHILE IT IS TRUE THAT UTAH BECOMES MORE URBANIZED EACH YEAR, IT IS ALSO TRUE THAT AGRICULTURE CONTINUES TO PLAY A VITAL PART IN OUR STATE. AS THE POPULATION OF UTAH AND THE UNITED STATES CONTINUES TO GROW, FOOD PRODUCTION IS MORE IMPORTANT THAN EVER BEFORE. UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY (USU) EXTENSION HAS LED THE WAY FOR 105 YEARS IN PROVIDING NON-BIASED, RESEARCH-BASED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRODUCERS AND THE UTAH AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY. USU EXTENSION HAS NATIONALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY RECOGNIZED FACULTY WITH EXPERTISE IN ALL AREAS OF AGRICULTURE PRODUCTION AND SCIENCE. OUR ON-CAMPUS AND COUNTY FACULTY CONDUCT CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH THAT IS DISSEMINATED TO PRODUCERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH METHODS SUCH AS FIELD DAYS, WORKSHOPS, PRINTED AND ONLINE PUBLICATIONS, CLASSES, ONLINE COURSES, AND SOCIAL MEDIA OUTLETS. EXTENSION CONTINUES TO MEET THE NEEDS OF TRADITIONAL AGRICULTURE WHILE EVOLVING TO MEET THE NEEDS OF DEVELOPING AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRIES. AS WE FOCUS OUR EFFORTS ON PERSISTENT AND EMERGING NEEDS, WE RECOGNIZE UTAH IS THE SECOND DRIEST STATE IN THE NATION, SO IRRIGATION EFFICIENCY, WATER CONSERVATION, AND IMPROVED WATER-EFFICIENT CROP VARIETIES CONTINUE TO BE FOCUS AREAS FOR OUR FACULTY AND RESEARCHERS. WITH URBAN AND SMALL FARMS BECOMING MORE POPULAR, EXTENSION FACULTY ARE WORKING WITH PRODUCERS TO FIND INNOVATIVE WAYS TO PRODUCE FOOD ON MINIMAL ACREAGE. THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF THE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE (AG/NR) PROGRAM ARE TO (A) INCREASE THE PRODUCTIVITY AND EFFICIENCY OF UTAH AGRICULTURAL OPERATIONS, AND (B) PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCE USE THROUGH RELEVANT EDUCATION ON CONSERVATION PRACTICES. FACULTY INVOLVED IN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROGRAM ACTIVELY CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON A WIDE VARIETY OF TOPICS INCLUDING CROP AND LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION, RANGELAND MANAGEMENT, FORESTRY, AND AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS. ALL RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, DEMONSTRATIONS, CONFERENCES, FIELD VISITS, AND CONSULTATIONS ON TOPICS RELATED TO (BUT NOT LIMITED TO) AGRONOMY, LIVESTOCK SCIENCE, DROUGHT, FORESTRY, RANGELAND, AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS, MENTAL HEALTH IN AGRICULTURE, PEST MANAGEMENT, AND WETLANDS. CLIMATE CHANGE AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES THE WESTERN U.S. CONTAINS STATES WITH VAST TRACTS OF PUBLIC LAND SURROUNDING SMALLER AREAS THAT ARE PRIVATELY OWNED, MOSTLY ADJACENT TO WATER. THE NATURAL RESOURCE BASE OF ANY ECONOMY IS CRITICALLY IMPORTANT TO THE ECONOMIC AND AESTHETIC ENVIRONMENTS FOR THAT AREA. CHANGES IN THE NATURAL RESOURCE BASE BRING VARIATION IN THE UNDERLYING ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL STRUCTURE. CRITICAL ISSUES AFFECTING NATURAL RESOURCE CHARACTERISTICS ARE FOUND IN SOILS, WATER, RANGE, FOREST, ANIMALS, AND AIR RESOURCES. THE PROPER AND EFFICIENT MANAGEMENT OF THESE RESOURCES IS A PRIMARY CONCERN, PARTICULARLY FOR ENVIRONMENTS AS VARIED AND UNIQUE AS IN THE WEST. THIS CRITICAL ISSUE INVOLVES IMPROVING DECISION-MAKING RELATIVE TO ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP IN AN ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND BIOLOGICAL SENSE. USU EXTENSION ADDRESSES THE CRITICAL ISSUE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND THE MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES THROUGH THE SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM. THE GOAL OF THIS EXTENSION PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE NON-FORMAL EDUCATION TO RESIDENTS, STAKEHOLDERS, AND ORGANIZATIONS TO PROMOTE, FACILITATE, AND STRENGTHEN ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIPAND SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCE USE IN UTAH. THIS PROJECT PRIMARILY FOCUSES ON FOREST MANAGEMENT, WATER CONSERVATION, AND STEWARDSHIP OF PUBLIC LANDS. THE PROJECT TARGETS ADULTS AND YOUTH, AND THE DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES ARE TO (A) EQUIP RESIDENTS WITH THE COMPETENCY TO EFFECTIVELY ENGAGE IN NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION, AND (B) FACILITATE PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND PUBLIC AND PRIVATE STAKEHOLDERS TO STRENGTHEN NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND ENABLE SUSTAINABLE RESOURCE USE. FACULTY INVOLVED IN THE SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM ACTIVELY CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON A WIDE VARIETY OF TOPICS INCLUDING WATER MANAGEMENT, IRRIGATION TECHNOLOGIES, AND TOURISM. ALL RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN CLIMATE CHANGE AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, DEMONSTRATIONS, CONFERENCES, AND FIELD VISITS ON TOPICS RELATED TO WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY, CLIMATE SCIENCE, BIOMASS, PERMACULTURE, OUTDOOR RECREATION, AND RESOURCE CONSERVATION. FOOD SAFETY WITH A LARGE VARIETY OF FOOD PRODUCTS MOVING THROUGH COMPLEX DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS, FOOD SAFETY IS A CRITICAL ISSUE FOR PRODUCERS, PR OCESSORS, DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS, AND THE FINAL CONSUMER. FOODBORNE ILLNESS IS A MAJOR CAUSE OF DEATH, CLAIMING THE LIVES OF OUR MOST VULNERABLE POPULATIONS; THE ELDERLY, YOUNG, PREGNANT WOMEN, PEOPLE WITH IMPAIRED IMMUNE FUNCTION, AND THE CHRONICALLY ILL. IMPROPER FOOD HANDLING AND PREPARATION OF FOOD IN FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS AND THE HOME CONTRIBUTE TO FOOD-BORNE ILLNESSES. THE PUBLIC FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION PROGRAM AT USU EXTENSION AIMS TO PROVIDE RELEVANT RESEARCH-BASED EDUCATION TO UTAH RESIDENTS ON BEST PRACTICES TO REDUCE THE RISK OF FOOD CONTAMINATION AND FOODBORNE ILLNESSES. THE MAJOR FOCUS AREAS OF THIS PROGRAM ARE FOOD PRESERVATION TECHNIQUES AND HOUSEHOLD FOOD STORAGE. THE DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES OF THE PUBLIC FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION PROGRAM ARE TO (A) REDUCE THE OCCURRENCES OF FOODBORNE ILLNESSES IN UTAH THROUGH RESEARCH-BASED EDUCATION ON FOOD SAFETY PRACTICES IN HOUSEHOLDS, AND (B) TO REDUCE FOOD CONTAMINATION IN THE FOOD SUPPLY CHAIN BY PROVIDING RELEVANT EDUCATION ON BEST PRACTICES TO PROCESSORS AND PRODUCERS. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN FOOD SAFETY INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, CONSULTATIONS, AND (VIRTUAL AND FACE-TO-FACE) DEMONSTRATIONS TARGETED AT RESIDENTS AND SMALL BUSINESSES ON FOOD PRESERVATION, CANNING, PRESSURE TESTING, FOOD PRODUCT TESTING, AND FOODBORNE ILLNESSES. NUTRITION AND HEALTH THERE IS A NEED TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE NUTRITION INFORMATION AND EDUCATION TO THE PUBLIC TO ENABLE CONSUMERS TO MAKE WISE DIETARY CHOICES. AS THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN DIET, PHYSICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH, AND DISEASE PREVENTION BECOME CLEARER, THE PROMOTION OF HEALTHY EATING BEHAVIORS AND LIFESTYLES FOR BOTH YOUTH AND ADULTS HAS RECEIVED INCREASED ATTENTION IN RECENT YEARS. WITH HIGH LEVELS OF OBESITY, CHRONIC DISEASE, AND POOR DIETARY HABITS, THERE IS A NEED FOR NON-FORMAL NUTRITION EDUCATION THAT ADDRESSES INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY HEALTH AND WELLNESS. THE PUBLIC NUTRITION AND HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAM AT USU EXTENSION SEEKS TO DECREASE THE INCIDENCES OF CHRONIC DISEASES AND OTHER NUTRITION-RELATED HEALTH ISSUES AMONG RESIDENTS THROUGH NON-FORMAL NUTRITION EDUCATION. THE PRIORITIES FOR THIS PROGRAM ARE TO EXPAND NUTRITIONAL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION, AND TO PROMOTE HEALTHY DIETARY HABITS. THEREFORE, THE DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES ARE THE PUBLIC NUTRITION AND HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAM ARE TO (A) EMPOWER RESIDENTS TO MAKE HEALTHY FOOD CHOICES AND IMPROVE THEIR NUTRITIONAL INTAKE, AND (B) REDUCE THE ECONOMIC COST OF CHRONIC DISEASES IN UTAH THROUGH ONGOING NUTRITION EDUCATION TO YOUTH AND ADULTS. FACULTY INVOLVED IN PUBLIC NUTRITION AND HEALTH EDUCATION PROGRAM ACTIVELY CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON A WIDE VARIETY OF TOPICS INCLUDING N UTRITION, OBESITY, CHRONIC DISEASES, AND FOOD SCIENCE. RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN NUTRITION AND HEALTH INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS AND CONSULTATIONS ON TOPICS RELATED TO CHRONIC DISEASES, NUTRITION EDUCATION, HEALTHY AND AFFORDABLE RECIPES, DIET BEHAVIOR CHANGES, AND YOUTH NUTRITION. COMMUNITY RESILIENCE UTAH CONSISTS OF MANY RURAL COUNTIES SPREAD OUT OVER VAST AREAS OF LAND, AND ONLY A FEW URBAN COUNTIES IN CENTRALIZED LOCATIONS. AS A RESULT, THERE IS AN INCREASING DISPARITY IN ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS IN RURAL COUNTIES. THE MAJORITY OF CURRENT AND NEW JOBS ARE LOCATED ALONG THE URBAN COUNTIES IN THE WASATCH FRONT, INCLUDING JOBS IN THE GROWING TECHNOLOGY SECTOR IN UTAH'S "SILICON SLOPES." IN CONTRAST, RURAL RESIDENTS STRUGGLE TO FIND WELL-PAYING AND STABLE WORK IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND ARE OFTEN FACED WITH THE DECISION TO RELOCATE TO URBAN CENTERS. THIS EXACERBATES THE PROBLEM OF ECONOMIC DEPRESSION IN RURAL COUNTIES SINCE RURAL-URBAN MIGRATION LEADS TO LOW PRODUCTIVITY IN THESE COUNTIES. THERE IS A NEED TO SUPPORT RURAL COMMUNITIES THROUGH COMMUNITY AND CAPACITY-BUILDING INITIATIVES. IN ADDITION TO ECONOMIC HARDSHIPS, INDIVIDUALS IN RURAL COUNTIES SUFFER FROM RELATIVELY HIGH RATES OF SUBSTANCE ABUSE DISORDERS. THE RATES OF OPIOID OVERDOSES IN RURAL UTAH HAVE CONSISTENTLY BEEN HIGHER THAN THE NATIONAL AVERAGE. UTAH HAD EIGHT (8) OUT OF 10 ADULT OVERDOSE DEATHS EACH WEEK DUE TO OPIOIDS IN 2019, AND HALF OF THOSE WERE SPECIFICALLY DUE TO PRESCRIPTION OPIOIDS (UTAH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH [UDOH] INDICATOR-BASED SYSTEM FOR PUBLIC HEALTH [IBIS], 2021). IN 2020, THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC CREATED ADDITIONAL CHALLENGES, INCLUDING INCREASES IN OPIOID-RELATED DEATHS DUE TO FENTANYL. THEREFORE, THE AIM OF THE VIBRANT COMMUNITIES PROGRAM AT USU EXTENSION IS TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITIES ACROSS UTAH THROUGH FACILITATED COMMUNITY-FOCUSED COALITIONS AND PARTNERSHIPS, ENTREPRENEURSHIP EDUCATION, AND STRATEGIC INITIATIVES TO FACILITATE ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL WELL-BEING. THE DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES OF THE VIBRANT COMMUNITIES PROGRAM ARE TO (A) CONNECT RURAL COMMUNITIES TO ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES IN URBAN CENTERS THROUGH INNOVATIVE WORKPLACE PRACTICES (E.G., REMOTE WORKING ARRANGEMENTS), AND (B) FACILITATE EDUCATIONAL INTERVENTIONS, AND COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS AND COALITIONS TO REDUCE SUBSTANCE ABUSE DISORDERS IN RURAL COUNTIES. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN COMMUNITY RESILIENCE INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS AND INTERVENTIONS ON TOPICS RELATED TO RURAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, RURAL EMPLOYMENT, REMOTE WORKING, BUILDING COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS AND COALITIONS, AND TRIBAL INITIATIVES. INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT UTAH IS IN THE TOP 5 U.S. STATES WITH BANKRUPTCY, AND THERE IS A NEED FOR OUTREACH EDUCATION TO FACILITATE IMPROVED FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AMONG INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES. BECAUSE OF UTAH'S TYPICALLY LARGER FAMILY SIZE, THE AMOUNT OF INCOME AVAILABLE FOR BASIC FAMILY NEEDS SLIPS BELOW THE MEAN FOR THE REST OF THE UNITED STATES. UTAH FAMILIES ALREADY FACE HIGH DEBT LOADS LEADING TO BANKRUPTCY, LOW SAVINGS, AND A LACK OF LIQUID ASSETS. HENCE, THE MAJOR GOAL OF THIS PLANNED EXTENSION PROGRAM IS TO ENHANCE INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT (FRM). FRM, WHICH RELATES TO FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, ALSO TIES TO OTHER ASPECTS OF FAMILY HEALTH, SUCH AS HEALTHY MARITAL AND FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, AND MENTAL HEALTH AND WELLBEING. AS A BROAD PROGRAM AREA, THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDES YOUTH, ADULTS, AND FAMILIES IN UTAH. DESIRED LONG-TERM OUTCOMES ARE TO; (A) STRENGTHEN FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, AND (B) IMPROVE THE ECONOMIC WELL-BEING OF INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES. FACULTY INVOLVED IN THIS PROGRAM ACTIVELY CONDUCT RESEARCH IN FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, MENTAL HEALTH AND WELLBEING, RELATIONSHIPS, AND HUMAN DEVELOPMENT. THE RESEARCH IS INCORPORATED INTO EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO INFORM BEST PRACTICES, BEHAVIOR CHANGE, AND EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT. MAJOR ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN COMMUNITY RESILIENCE INCLUDE EDUCATIONAL WORKSHOPS, CONFERENCES, AND CONSULTATIONS ON TOPICS RELATED TO INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, HOMEOWNER AND HOMEBUYER EDUCATION, FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, COUPLES, AND FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, AND MENTAL WELLNESS.

RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM TUSKEGEE UNIVERSITY HOLDS A HISTORIC CONNECTION TO LANDOWNERS IN THE BLACK BELT OF ALABAMA, AS WELL AS ACROSS THE STATE FOR PROVIDING SUPPORT AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR LAND MANAGEMENT FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY. WITH GROWING CONCERNS IN CLIMATE CHANGE, AND GROWING NEEDS TO ACQUIRE AND RETAIN LAND IT IS THE FOCUS OF TUCE’S RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT CAPACITY FUNDING TO SUPPORT PROGRAMS THAT EDUCATE LANDOWNERS IN SOME OF THESE MORE PERTINENT AREAS OF RESEARCH. THROUGH PROGRAMS DELIVERED AS WORKSHOPS, FIELD DAYS, HANDS ON DEMONSTRATIONS, WEBINARS, INTERNSHIPS, AND CONFERENCES IT IS THE INTENTION FOR THE FOCUS OF THIS YEAR’S WORK TO FOCUS ON 1) HEIR PROPERTY; 2) CLIMATE CHANGE <(>&<)> FORESTRY MANAGEMENT (SOCIAL SCIENCE); 3) AGRITOURISM -RECREATION; 4) FERAL HOGS <(>&<)> FORESTRY MANAGEMENT; AND 5) POTENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICE MARKETS. ALL PLANNED PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS CONTAINED IN THE TUCE INTEGRATED EXTENSION AND RESEARCH PLAN OF WORK WERE DEVELOPED WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF RESEARCH AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT OF RELEVANCE TO ALL RESIDENTS OF ALABAMA WHO MAY BENEFIT FROM THE LOCAL KNOWLEDGE BASE OR SERVICE. THIS COMMITMENT IS WITHOUT REGARD TO ANY PERSONAL CHARACTERISTICS, TO INCLUDE AGE, ETHNIC ORIGIN, GENDER, RELIGION, SEXUAL ORIENTATION, OR GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION. ALABAMA POPULATIONS ARE INCLUDED, AS APPROPRIATE, IN THE PROJECT AND PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT PROCESS. AS A PART OF THE DEVELOPMENT PROCESS, EACH PROJECT OR PROGRAM THAT WAS IDENTIFIED AND DEVELOPED FOR GRASSROOTS PROGRAM DELIVERY, DETAILS THE INTENDED AUDIENCE(S) TO BE SERVED. AS A PART OF THE REVIEW PROCESS, THE RESPECTIVE ASSISTANT/ASSOCIATE DIRECTORS AND ADMINISTRATORS ARE CHARGED WITH ENSURING THAT THE INTENDED AUDIENCE(S) FOR EACH PROJECT OR PROGRAM INCLUDES THE SPECTRUM OF POTENTIAL RECIPIENTS OF THE ALABAMA POPULATION.

FY2023 RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM (RREA) PROJECT SUMMARY HELPING URBAN COMMUNITIES LEARN ABOUT THEIR ENVIRONMENT THROUGH A WIDE RANGE OF SUSTAINABILITY PROGRAMS INCLUDING MASTER NATURALIST PROGRAM AS WELL AS URBAN FORESTRY EDUCATION PROGRAM IS THE MAIN GOAL OF RREA PROGRAM AT UDC. IT IS VERY IMPORTANT THAT CURRENT EXTENSION ACTIVITIES FOCUS ON THE SOCIAL AND ECOLOGICAL PROCESSES PRESSURING THE ENVIRONMENT, AT MULTIPLE TEMPORAL AND SPATIAL SCALES, TO BETTER PREDICT THE INFLUENCES THAT INCREASING POPULATION, ECONOMIC GROWTH, AND LAND USE POLICES HAVE ON URBAN FORESTS FUNCTION, COMMUNITY HEALTH DYNAMIC, AND SPECIES DISTRIBUTION. OVER THE NEXT 3 YEARS, THE URBAN FORESTRY EXTENSION PROGRAM IN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE URBAN SUSTAINABILITY, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES AT THE UNIVERSITY OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA WILL IMPLEMENT AN URBAN FORESTRY EXTENSION PLAN OF ACTION, THAT IS INCLUSIVE OF ACADEMIC COURSE OFFERINGS, CITIZEN SCIENCE CAPACITY BUILDING, EXTENSION OUTREACH, AND KNOWLEDGE ACQUISITION. URBAN FORESTS PLAY AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION AND ADAPTATION. ACTIVE STEWARDSHIP OF A COMMUNITY'S FORESTRY ASSETS CAN STRENGTHEN LOCAL RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE CHANGE WHILE CREATING MORE SUSTAINABLE AND DESIRABLE PLACES TO LIVE. THE RREA IS ALIGNED WITH THE FOLLOWING USDA STRATEGIC GOALS FOR 2022‐2026: 1. STRATEGIC GOAL 1 COMBAT CLIMATE CHANGE TO SUPPORT AMERICA’S WORKING LANDS, NATURAL RESOURCES AND COMMUNITIES. 2. STRATEGIC GOAL 2 ENSURE AMERICA’S AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM IS EQUITABLE, RESILIENT, AND PROSPEROUS. 3. STRATEGIC GOAL 3 FOSTER AN EQUITABLE AND COMPETITIVE MARKETPLACE FOR ALL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS. 4. STRATEGIC GOAL 5 EXPAND OPPORTUNITIES FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVE QUALITY OF LIFE IN RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES.

REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROJECT ABSTRACT IMPROVING ECOSYSTEM HEALTH THROUGH COORDINATED EXTENSION LEARNING, MONITORING, AND MANAGEMENT INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES CONTROL THE LARGEST AGGREGATE SHARE OF MINNESOTA’S 17 MILLION ACRES OF FOREST LAND, AT ABOUT 33%. THE LAND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS MADE BY THIS GROUP ARE TREMENDOUSLY IMPORTANT TO THE STATE’S RURAL ECONOMIES, WILDLIFE HABITAT, WOOD PRODUCTS SUPPLY, AND WATER QUALITY. THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA EXTENSION NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAMS PROMOTE LEARNING AND LAND MANAGEMENT ACTION CONSISTENT WITH CONSERVATION AND PROACTIVE MANAGEMENT TO FOSTER HEALTHY, PRODUCTIVE, AND RESILIENT FORESTS. IN FY2023, CONSISTENT WITH OUR APPROVED RREA PLAN OF WORK, UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA INVESTMENT OF RREA FUNDS WILL ALIGN WITH THE FOLLOWING USDA STRATEGIC GOALS FOR 2022‐2026: 1. STRATEGIC GOAL 1 COMBAT CLIMATE CHANGE TO SUPPORT AMERICA’S WORKING LANDS, NATURAL RESOURCES AND COMMUNITIES. 2. STRATEGIC GOAL 2 ENSURE AMERICA’S AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM IS EQUITABLE, RESILIENT, AND PROSPEROUS. THESE FUNDS WILL BE INVESTED IN EXTENSION PROGRAMMING TO ENGAGE NEW WOODLAND OWNERS, MITIGATE INVASIVE SPECIES THREATS, AND RESPOND TO CLIMATE VARIABILITY. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE HYBRID DELIVERY OF OUR PROVEN MASTER WOODLAND OWNER PROGRAM, DEVELOPMENT AND DELIVERY OF AN EMERGING TERRESTRIAL INVASIVE SPECIES PROGRAM, APPLIED RESEARCH INTO TECHNIQUES TO ENGAGE NEW LANDOWNERS IN LAND STEWARDSHIP LEARNING AND ACTIVE MANAGEMENT, AND NEW WEB‐BASED CONTENT FOR LANDOWNERS AND PROFESSIONALS ON MANAGING FOR HEALTHY PRIVATE FORESTLAND.

UC ANR RREA PROGRAM ABSTRACT DESCRIPTION <(>&<)> BENEFICIARIES THE RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT OF 1978 (RREA) SUPPORTS AN EXPANDED AND COMPREHENSIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM FOR FOREST AND RANGELAND RENEWABLE RESOURCES. RREA SUPPORTS FOREST AND RANGELAND OWNERS AND MANAGERS IN THE SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF WOOD PRODUCTS, FORAGE AND LIVESTOCK, FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND DEVELOPING OUTDOOR RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES. UC AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES OVERSEES THE UC RREA PROGRAM WHICH FOCUSES ON EIGHT ISSUE AREAS, LISTED BELOW WITH THEIR RESPECTIVE GOAL: (1) PUBLIC AWARENESS AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT: ENGAGING YOUTH AND ADULTS ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF FOREST AND RANGELAND RESOURCES, PARTICULARLY HOW FOREST LANDS AND RANGELANDS AFFECT RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES AND THE NEED TO USE SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION WHEN MAKING DECISIONS ABOUT THESE RESOURCES. (2) ECOSYSTEM SERVICES: ASSISTING FOREST AND RANGELAND OWNERS AND MANAGERS IN ACTIVELY MANAGING THEIR LANDS WITH KNOWLEDGE OF FOREST ANDRANGELAND ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES AND HOW SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES PRODUCE DIFFERENT COMBINATIONS OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES; AND ASSISTING FOREST AND RANGELAND USERS IN UNDERSTANDING THE ROLE DIFFERENT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES HAVE ON COMMUNITY WELL-BEING. (3) FISH AND WILDLIFE HABITAT: ENSURING THAT PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS HAVE THE BEST AVAILABLE INFORMATION ABOUT FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT HABITAT MANAGEMENT IN FOREST AND RANGELAND ECOSYSTEMS. (4) GENERATIONAL SUCCESSION AND OTHER LANDOWNERSHIP CHANGES: ENHANCING THE DECISION-MAKING ABILITY OF RANCH AND FOREST LANDOWNER FAMILIES FOR GENERATIONAL SUCCESSION BY PROVIDING INFORMATION ON AND FACILITATING COMMUNICATION ABOUT SUCH PLANNING OPTIONS AS CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, COMMUNITY-BASED NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT OR OTHER NON-TRADITIONAL SUCCESSION MODELS; TRAINING AND LINKING INTERESTED PARTIES IN COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIPS THAT WILL AUGMENT GENERATIONAL TRANSFER OF FOREST AND RANGELAND ENTERPRISES. (5) INVASIVE SPECIES: INCREASING THE CAPACITY OF LANDOWNERS, MANAGERS, AND PROFESSIONALS TO ASSESS THE THREAT OF INVASIVE SPECIES; DEVELOPING INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT PLANS; IMPLEMENTING EFFECTIVE INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL STRATEGIES TO PROTECT FOREST AND RANGELAND ECOSYSTEMS; PROVIDING MEANS FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC (INCLUDING ABSENTEE LANDOWNERS), YOUTH, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS FOR THEIR INTERACTION AND PARTICIPATION IN MONITORING AND CONTROLLING INVASIVE SPECIES. (6) RURAL COMMUNITIES: WORKING WITH RURAL COMMUNITIES TO ASSESS NEEDS AND DETERMINE HOW TO SUSTAINABLY ENHANCE LOCAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT THROUGH A FOCUS ON FOREST AND RANGELAND INDUSTRIES, INFRASTRUCTURE, AND EXPERTISE; CREATING A STRONGER RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN HEALTHY FORESTS AND RANGELANDS AND THE SOCIAL AND SUSTAINABLE ECONOMIC BASES OF RURAL COMMUNITIES; ASSESSING NEEDS AND DETERMINING HOW TO ENHANCE LOCAL LANDSCAPE ECONOMICS. (7) WATER AND WETLANDS: ENCOURAGING MANAGEMENT OF FORESTS AND RANGELANDS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY. (8) WILDFIRE PREVENTION AND MANAGEMENT: ENGAGING FOREST AND RANGELAND COMMUNITIES WITH RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION ON WILDFIRE RISK-MANAGEMENT AND POST-FIRE RECOVERY STRATEGIES; INCREASING THE CAPACITY OF COMMUNITY, COUNTY, AND STATE EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS/CIVIL DEFENSE AUTHORITIES TO COMMUNICATE COMMUNITY NEEDS AND INFORM COMMUNITY-DEVELOPMENT POLICIES, CODES, AND ORDINANCES THAT PROTECT COMMUNITIES FROM WILDFIRE; DEVELOPING OUTREACH EFFORTS THAT INCLUDE CURRENT AND EMERGING RESEARCH ON IMPACTS OF WILDFIRE ON FOREST AND RANGELAND ECOLOGY AND ECONOMICS, FUELS MANAGEMENT, AND PRESCRIBED FIRE TO CREATE APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES; INCREASING CAPACITY FOR COMMUNITY ACTION, EMPOWER LANDOWNERS TO ENGAGE IN PRESCRIBED FIRE, AND PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR TRAINING AND CAPACITY IN FUELS REDUCTION.

KNOWLEDGE EMPOWERS PEOPLE TO MAKE CHANGES BY ENABLING THEM TO DEVELOP INFORMATION-BASED OPINIONS AND DEVELOP ETHICAL STANDARDS BY WHICH THEY WILL ACT. ATTITUDES ABOUT NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUES ARE OFTEN COUNTER INDICATIVE TO ESTABLISHED SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE. BY NOT HAVING ACCESS TO FACTUAL INFORMATION, PEOPLE DEVELOP OPINIONS AND BASE THEIR ACTIONS ON INFORMATION GLEANED FROM THE MEDIA AND OTHER NON-SCIENTIFIC SOURCES. POOR NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND POLICIES ARE OFTEN THE RESULT, IMPACTING IDAHO'S RURAL COMMUNITIES. THESE DECISIONS AND POLICIES HAVE PROVEN DETRIMENTAL TO THE HEALTH IDAHO'S FORESTS AND RANGELANDS, RESULTING IN WIDESPREAD INSECT AND DISEASE OUTBREAKS AND HIGH CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE RISK. GOALS HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED BY IDENTIFYING AND PRIORITIZING CRITICAL ISSUES AND ECOLOGICAL DRIVERS THAT INFLUENCE FOREST AND RANGELAND MANAGEMENT IN IDAHO. THE IDENTIFIED ISSUES WHICH WILL BE THE MAIN FOCUS OF THE RREA PROGRAM IN IDAHO ARE HIGH TO MODERATELY HIGH FOREST HEALTH THREATS FROM INSECTS AND DISEASES IN IDENTIFIED PRIORITY LANDSCAPE AREAS; A HIGH THREAT OF UNCHARACTERISTIC WILDFIRE IN ALL WILDLAND/INTERFACE AREAS OF IDAHO AS WELL IN IDENTIFIED PRIORITY WILDLAND AREAS; AND A RELATIVELY HIGH POTENTIAL FOR DEVELOPING SUSTAINABLE FOREST-BASED INDUSTRIES UTILIZING FOREST BIOMASS. BY UTILIZING NEWER TECHNOLOGIES, AUDIENCES WILL BE ABLE TO RECEIVE INFORMATION USING A WIDER VARIETY OF DELIVERY METHODS THAT ARE MORE ALIGNED WITH THEIR INDIVIDUAL LEARNING PREFERENCES.

PURDUE RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT ABSTRACT: THE RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT (RREA) PROGRAM IN INDIANA IS ADMINISTERED BY PURDUE UNIVERSITY’S DEPARTMENT OF FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES. THE RREA PROGRAM IN INDIANA WILL FOCUS ON FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH, FOREST AND RANGELAND WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES RESOURCES, AND INVASIVE SPECIES. WE WILL COLLABORATE WITH MANY PRIVATE AND PUBLIC AGENCIES AND LEVERAGE RREA DOLLARS AGAINST OTHER FUNDING TO MAXIMIZE PROGRAM IMPACT AND REACH. FORESTS PROVIDE A MULTITUDE OF ENVIRONMENTAL (E.G., CARBON SEQUESTRATION, ENHANCED WATER QUALITY, WILDLIFE HABITAT), ECONOMIC (E.G., TIMBER, WOOD PRODUCTS MANUFACTURING, TOURISM), AND SOCIAL (E.G., RECREATION, AESTHETICS) BENEFITS TO SOCIETY. IN INDIANA, 86 PERCENT OF THE 4.65 MILLION ACRES OF FORESTLAND IS PRIVATELY OWNED BY AN ESTIMATED 180,000 PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. MAINTAINING THE MANY BENEFITS THAT WORKING FORESTS PROVIDE ALL CITIZENS OF INDIANA IS DEPENDENT UPON THE LAND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS MADEBY FOREST LANDOWNERS AND THE PROFESSIONALS WHO ADVISE THEM. THE RREA PROGRAM IN INDIANA WILL UTILIZE DEMONSTRATION FORESTS AND ONLINE RESOURCES TO TRAIN PRIVATE WOODLAND OWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, FOCUSING ON THE ESTABLISHMENT OF STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES AND PLANS THAT RESULT IN ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS. THESE BENEFITS ARE ACCOMPLISHED IN THREE MAJOR PROGRAMS. WE ANNUALLY PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE 3 ISSUES OF THE WOODLAND STEWARD TO OVER 27,000 FOREST LANDOWNERS WHO OWN AN ESTIMATED 1.04 MILLION ACRES OF WOODLANDS. THE WOODLAND STEWARD IS A 16-PAGE, FULL-COLOR PUBLICATION THAT INCLUDES IN-DEPTH ARTICLES ON FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH, INVASIVE SPECIES AND PESTS, WILDLIFE HABITAT MANAGEMENT, ECONOMICS, AND MORE. BASED ON READER SURVEYS, WE EXPECT MORE THAN HALF OF THE READERS WILL SAVE OR EARN MONEY, AND IMPLEMENT AT LEAST ONE PRACTICE BECAUSE OF WHAT THEY LEARNED FROM THE INFORMATION THEY READ. THE NATURAL RESOURCES EXTENSION INTERNSHIP PROGRAM IS A COST-EFFECTIVE PROGRAM THAT ENHANCES STUDENT CAREER POTENTIAL THROUGH PRACTICAL, HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE WHILE INCREASING OUR CAPACITY WITHIN SELECTED RREA ISSUE AREAS. EACH YEAR, UP TO THREE STUDENTS WORK WITH MENTORS TO TAILOR THEIR INTERNSHIP PROGRAM. DURING THIS TIME, INTERNS WILL IMPROVE THEIR COMMUNICATION SKILLS FOR REACHING NON-SCIENTIFIC AUDIENCES, LEARN ABOUT EXTENSION, AND GAIN CAREER EXPERIENCE WHILE PRODUCING PRODUCTS THAT SUPPORT OUR EXTENSION PROGRAM INCLUDING PUBLICATIONS, VIDEOS, PRESENTATIONS, OR HABITAT DEMONSTRATIONS. LASTLY, COMMUNITY PLANNING IS AN IMPORTANT LINK IN PRESERVING AND ENHANCING WOODLANDS AND THE BENEFITS THEY PROVIDE ALL OF SOCIETY. THE CONSERVATION THROUGH COMMUNITY LEADERSHIP (CCL) PROGRAM TARGETS NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AND COMMUNITY GROUPS INTERESTED IN CONDUCTING STRATEGIC PLANNING IN THE AREAS OF NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, WATERSHED MANAGEMENT, OR INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. THE CCL TEAM COMBINES COMMUNITY ACTION PLANNING WITH A TRAIN-THE-TRAINER APPROACH TO GIVE CONSERVATION PROFESSIONALS THE TOOLS THEY NEED TO ADDRESS THE COMPLEX NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND LAND USE PLANNING ISSUES FACED BY THEIR COMMUNITY. PARTICIPANTS IN THE COMMUNITY ACTION PLANNING PROGRAM WILL LEAVE WITH A HIGH-QUALITY ACTION PLAN TAILORED TO LOCAL INITIATIVES WHILE THOSE ENROLLED IN THE TRAIN-THE-TRAINER WORKSHOP WILL DEVELOP THE SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE NEEDED TO CONDUCT THEIR OWN ACTION PLANNING PROGRAM AS PART OF A TEAM.

CARING FOR PUERTO RICO’S URBAN TREES THE ISLAND OF PUERTO RICO IS LOCATED IN THE CARIBBEAN AREA. ITS CLIMATE VARIABILITY PRINCIPALLY DEPENDS ON ITS TOPOGRAPHY AND THE NORTHEASTERLY TRADE WINDS THAT RECEIVES YEARLY (USGS, 2016). THROUGH EACH YEAR IS SUBJECT TO “VAGUADAS”, WHICH ARE HEAVY RAIN EVENTS, BUT DURING JUNE 1ST TO NOVEMBER 30TH, WE HAVE TO BE PREPARED BECAUSE IT IS THE HURRICANE SEASON (NMEAD, 2022). THIS NATURAL EVENTS IMPACT THE ISLAND, INCLUDING THE FORESTS AND URBAN FORESTS. IN SEPTEMBER OF 2017, CATEGORY 4 HURRICANE MARÍA HIT THE ISLAND, WITH SUSTAINED WINDS OF 155 MILES PER HOUR (THE WEATHER CHANNEL, 2017), THAT DESTROYED AND UPROOTED TREES AND, THOSE THAT STILL STANDING, WERE WITHOUT ANY LEAVES, AND ITS 15-20 INCHES OF RAIN, CAUSED FLOODS AND LANDSLIDES THAT ALSO AFFECTED THE TREES (SCOTT, 2018). ON SEPTEMBER OF 2022, THE ISLAND WAS IMPACTED AGAIN BY HURRICANE FIONA, WITH 85 MILES PER HOUR WINDS AND 30-60 INCHES OF RAIN. AGAIN, THE FORESTS AND URBAN FORESTS TREES WERE DAMAGED BY THE WINDS OR BY THE LANDSLIDES. THESE EVENTS ALSO CREATE ANOTHER PROBLEM, WHICH IS THE DAMAGE FALLING TREES CAN CAUSE TO INFRASTRUCTURE, LIKE ELECTRICITY AND COMMUNICATIONS LINES, TO BUILDINGS AND TO HOUSES AND CARS. AND, AS CLIMATE CHANGE AFFECTS THE PLANET, FOR PUERTO RICO THE EFFECTS INCLUDE AN INCREASE IN THE FREQUENCY OF EXTREME EVENTS AND, THOSE WILL HAVE AN INCREASE IN THE AMOUNT OF RAIN (WATER ENVIRONMENT FEDERATION, 2021). FOR THIS, IT IS NECESSARY TO EDUCATE THE PUERTO RICO AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION SERVICE (PRAES) AGRICULTURAL AGENTS IN TOPICS RELATED TO GREEN SPACES EMERGENCY PLAN PREPARATION, DAMAGE EVALUATION, TREES PRUNING AND PROTECTION, AND CONSIDERATIONS FOR TREE SELECTION IN URBAN AREAS. THIS CAN BE DELIVERED AS A SHORT COURSE, THAT THEY CAN THEN OFFER TO THE COMMUNITY LEADERS. WE EXPECT THAT THIS WILL HELP REDUCE THE IMPACT OF EXTREME EVENTS IN, AT LEAST, THE URBAN TREES AND THE STRUCTURES AROUND THEM. REFERENCES: NATIONAL AERONAUTICS AND SPACE ADMINISTRATION (NASA).
