THE PURPOSE OF THE RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT FUNDING RECEIVED BY THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA WARNELL SCHOOL OF FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES IS TO SUPPORT THE OUTREACH EFFORTS OF OUR EXTENSION FACULTY. WE BRING SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION TO OUR TARGET AUDIENCES, SUCH AS GEORGIA FOREST LANDOWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, TO HELP THEM MAKE CRITICAL MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. WE EDUCATE GEORGIA CITIZENS ABOUT HOW AND WHY NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES ARE PRESCRIBED AND CONDUCTED. WE PROVIDE CONTINUING EDUCATION CREDIT COURSES REQUIRED TO MAINTAIN PROFESSIONAL CREDENTIALS. THE WARNELL OUTREACH TEAM WILL APPROACH OUR EFFORTS LIKE WE ALWAYS DO: 1) DETERMINE NEEDS WITH INPUT FROM OUR TARGET AUDIENCES AND KEY STAKEHOLDERS; 2) DEVELOP MEASURABLE OBJECTIVES (TEMPORAL AND SPECIAL); 3) CREATE APPROPRIATE PRODUCT(S) THAT ADDRESS IDENTIFIED NEEDS; 4) EVALUATE IMPACT/EFFECTIVENESS; AND 5) REPEAT PROCESS UNTIL NEEDS ARE SATISFIED. THE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED IN THE COMING YEAR INCLUDE: 1) WORKSHOPS; 2) APPLIED RESEARCH; 3) PEER REVIEWED AND EXTENSION PUBLICATIONS; 4) PRESENTATIONS; 5) PARTNER COLLABORATION; AND 6) WEB-BASED PRODUCTS. THE DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE: 1. WORKSHOPS: THE WARNELL OUTREACH TEAM WILL PLAN, ORGANIZE AND DELIVER WORKSHOPS COVERING TOPICS THAT INCLUDE THE DISTRIBUTION AND CONTROL OF INVASIVE SPECIES, FIRESCAPING, TIMBER TAXATION, INTENSIVE FOREST MANAGEMENT, FOREST HEALTH, URBAN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, EXTENSION TEACHING ACADEMY, ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CERTIFICATION, AND MANAGING FISHPONDS. WORKSHOPS WILL BE PLANNED AND DELIVERED THAT ARE BOTH PROACTIVE AND REACTIVE. ALL WORKSHOPS WILL BE DESIGNED AND CONDUCTED WITH THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES THAT PARTICIPANTS WILL INCREASE THEIR WORKING KNOWLEDGE, CHANGE THEIR ATTITUDE TOWARD ADOPTION OF NEW MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES OR REMOVAL OF AN INVASIVE SPECIES, AND DEVELOP NEW BEHAVIORS THAT SATISFIES A PERSONAL INTEREST OR HELPS THEM MEET THEIR OBJECTIVES. OUR ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION SPECIALISTSWILL OFFER EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING EVENTS FOR STUDENTS AND TEACHERS USING INTERNATIONALLY RECOGNIZED CURRICULA (PROJECT LEARNING TREE, PROJECT WILD, AND PROJECT WET). AS TEACHERS GAIN MORE FREEDOM TO PLAN AND CARRY-OUT FIELD TRIPS, WE HOPE TO SEE AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF CLASSES COMING TO OUR EDUCATION FOREST FACILITIES. 2. APPLIED RESEARCH: ACTIVITIES WILL INVOLVE MAINTAINING EXISTING AND DEVELOPING NEW SITES TO EVALUATE AND SERVE AS DEMONSTRATIONS OF FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. THESE EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON SITE PREPARATION TECHNIQUES, FOREST HERBICIDE TRIALS, AND HERBICIDE APPLICATION TIMING. THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOME OF APPLIED RESEARCH EFFORTS IS TO STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION WITH STATE/FEDERAL AGENCY PARTNERS AND PRIVATE INDUSTRY SPONSORS, AND AS DATA CONTINUES TO BE GATHERED AND ANALYZED, AN INCREASED USE OF THESE SITES AS EFFECTIVE DEMONSTRATION SITES FOR FIELD DAYS AND WORKSHOPS. 3. PUBLICATIONS: WE WILL CONTINUE TO PRODUCE PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL MANUSCRIPTS AND EXTENSION PUBLICATIONS. TOPICS TO BE COVERED INCLUDE FIRESCAPING, WILD HARVESTING PRACTICES, WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, COMMUNITY FORESTRY, INTENSIVE FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES (HERBICIDE APPLICATION AND SITE PREPARATION). ALL PUBLICATIONS WILL BE PRODUCED WITH THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOME OF SPREADING TRUSTED INFORMATION AND INCREASING THE NUMBER OF PUBLICATIONS POSTED ON OUR NEW WARNELL OUTREACH WEBSITE WHERE WE CAN TRACK THE NUMBER OF VIEWS AND DOWNLOADS. 4. PRESENTATIONS: OUR TEAM WILL CONTINUE TO DELIVER PRESENTATIONS IN-PERSON AND UTILIZING THE AFFORDANCES OF VIRTUAL DELIVERY SUCH AS ZOOM AND WEBINARS. WE HAVE PLANS TO COVER MANY TOPICS INCLUDING URBAN WILDLIFE ISSUES, FIRESCAPING, COMMUNITY FORESTRY, FOREST MANAGEMENT, EXTENSION TEACHING ACADEMY, ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION, AQUATIC RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, WOOD PLANT ID, AND OTHER TOPICS AS IDENTIFIED. THE OUTCOME OF OUR EFFORTS IS TO SHARE QUALITY UP-TO-DATE INFORMATION WITH GEORGIA CITIZENS THAT HELP THEM MAKE INFORMED NATURAL RESOURCE RELATED DECISIONS. 5. PARTNER COLLABORATION: OUR TEAM WILL CONTINUE TO NURTURE EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS WITH STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, EDUCATORS (K-16), AND INDUSTRY. WE ANTICIPATE THE OUTCOME OF THESE PARTNERSHIPS TO BE SUSTAINED SUPPORT AND COLLABORATION. WE ARE VERY AWARE OF THE IMPORTANCE OF PARTNERSHIPS WHEN IT COMES TO LENDING VALIDITY TO OUR WORK. FOR EXAMPLE, WHEN WE COLLABORATE WITH A STATE AGENCY OR A NATIONAL TREE FARMER OF THE YEAR THAT HOSTS A WORKSHOP OR FIELD DAY ON THEIR PROPERTY, OUR EFFORTS ARE REWARDED WITH A STRONG TURNOUT OF PARTICIPANTS AND THE TECHNICAL CONTENT WE DELIVER IS BACKED WITH EXAMPLES IN THE FIELD. 6. WEB BASED PRODUCTS: WE WILL CONTINUE TO REVIEW, UPDATE AND MODIFY OUR NEWLY CREATED WARNELL OUTREACH WEB PAGE. OUR WEB DEVELOPMENT TEAM WILL EVALUATE AND RETIRE SMARTPHONE APPS AND WEBSITES THAT HAVE LIMITED DOWNLOADS/HITS OR LIMITED FUNDING TO MAINTAIN. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF OUR EFFORT WILL BE TO OFFER WEB-BASED TOOLS THAT INCREASE INFORMATION SHARING AND DATA COLLECTION, AND PROVIDE EXPERIENCES THAT BUILD NEW SKILLS AND BENEFIT OUR TARGET AUDIENCES. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE WARNELL OUTREACH TEAM ARE FOREST LANDOWNERS, PROFESSIONAL NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, PRIVATE CONSULTANTS, COUNTY EXTENSION ANR AGENTS, CITY/COUNTY GOVERNMENT STAFF, K-12 TEACHERS AND STUDENTS, SPECIAL INTEREST GROUPS, ASSOCIATIONS, NGOS AND NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, AND ALL CITIZENS OF GEORGIA. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES PLANNED AT THE TIME OF THIS AWARD.

TITLE: RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT CAPACITY GRANT PD: WIECZOREK, ANIA INSTITUTION: UHM CTAHR THE COLLEGE OF TROPICAL AGRICULTURE AND HUMAN RESOURCES (CTAHR) AT THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAIʻI AT MANOA (UHM) OVERSEES A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF 22 RESEARCH AND EXTENSION STATIONS ON FIVE HAWAIIAN ISLANDS. CTAHR, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS THE STATE, IS ACTIVELY SEARCHING FOR OPPORTUNITIES TO INCREASE LOCAL FOOD PRODUCTION IN A SUSTAINABLE WAY WHILE ALSO MAKING IT MORE PROFITABLE. WHILE THERE ARE OPPORTUNITIES, THERE ARE ALSO SUBSTANTIAL CONSTRAINTS. THE COSTS OF LAND, LABOR, AND ENERGY EXCEED THOSE FOUND IN MOST OTHER STATES. AGROCHEMICALS AND ANIMAL FEED ARE MOSTLY IMPORTED AND EXPORTING PRODUCTS TO DISTANT MARKETS REDUCES THE FARMERS’ COMPETITIVE ABILITY. THE HIGH COSTS OF ENERGY, LACK OF SKILLED LABOR, AND REDUCED INTEREST IN FARMING ARE MAJOR CHALLENGES. CTAHR UNDERSTANDS THESE CHALLENGES AND ENGAGES IN A BROAD SPECTRUM OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING: MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES THAT CONSTANTLY THREATEN THE "GATEWAY" STATE OF HAWAI’I; IMPROVED CULTIVATION AND PROCESSING OF SPECIALTY CROPS; AGRICULTURAL ADVANCED TECHNOLOGY; DEVELOPMENT OF VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS; INCREASING FOREST PRODUCTIVITY; PROTECTION OF FORESTS, WATERSHEDS AND COASTAL R ESOURCES; PLANT AND ANIMAL BREEDING AND GENETIC IMPROVEMENT; BIOFUEL DEVELOPMENT TO ADDRESS SOARING ENERGY COSTS AND FOSSIL FUEL DEPLETION; PLANT STRESSES RELATED TO DROUGHT AND CLIMATE CHANGE; FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY; THE HEALTH (MENTAL, PHYSICAL, AND FINANCIAL) OF HAWAI'I'S CITIZENS AND COMMUNITIES; AND HUMAN NUTRITION PROGRAMS. CTAHR WORKS WITHIN THE FRAMEWORK OF FIVE CRITICAL ISSUES: BIOENGINEERING FOR AGRICULTURE/NATURAL RESOURCES/HEALTH; BIOSECURITY OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES; DIVERSIFIED TROPICAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS; PROTECT AND MANAGE NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE ENVIRONMENT; AND YOUTH/FAMILY/COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND HEALTH.

LEVERAGING ILLINOIS EXTENSION FORESTRY PROGRAMMING TO PROMOTE POSITIVE CHANGE FOR WOOLDLAND OWNERS THROUGHOUT THE PRAIRIE STATE PROJECT ABSTRACT FEDERAL AWARD PURPOSE: ILLINOIS EXTENSION FORESTRY WISHES TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF WOODLAND OWNERS WITH A FOREST MANAGEMENT PLAN ON FILE GIVEN LESS THAN 10% OF THE ILLINOIS WOODLAND OWNERS (126,000) CURRENTLY HAVE A FORESTRY PLAN ON FILE WITH THEIR STATE AGENCY. IT IS WELL DOCUMENTED THAT MANAGED “WORKING” FORESTS ARE MORE PRODUCTIVE, PROVIDE MORE BIODIVERSITY, ARE MORE RESILIENT TO CLIMATE CHANGE, AND ARE MORE CAPABLE OF PRODUCING FUTURE INCOME STREAMS AND STORING VALUABLE CARBON. EXTENSION FORESTRY WANTS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF LANDOWNERS SEEKING PROFESSIONAL FORESTRY GUIDANCE WHEN CONDUCTING A TIMBER SALE IN ORDER TO INCREASE LANDOWNER PROFITS WHILE MAINTAINING THE SUSTAINABILITY AND QUALITY OF OUR VALUABLE HARDWOOD TIMBER RESOURCE AND WOOD PRODUCTS INDUSTRIES. EXTENSION FORESTRY ALSO WISHES TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF CHAINSAW-RELATED INJURIES IN ILLINOIS WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY PREPARING A CADRE OF TRAINED LANDOWNERS, PROFESSIONALS, AND COLLEGE STUDENTS CAPABLE OF SAFELY TENDING TO THEIR LAND AND RESPONDING TO NATURAL DISASTERS SUCH AS TORNADOES, STRAIGHT-LINE WINDS, AND ICE GLAZING EVENTS. THE PREVALENCE AND SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES ON ILLINOIS FORESTED LAND HAS A SUBSTANTIAL NEGATIVE IMPACT ON ECONOMIC, CONSERVATION, WILDLIFE, AND SOCIAL ISSUES. THEREFORE, EXTENSION FORESTRY WISHES TO REMAIN A LEADING VOICE AND SOURCE OF EXPERT GUIDANCE REGARDING THE MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL OF INVASIVE SPECIES ON ILLINOIS FOREST LAND AND CONSERVATION AREAS. STEWARDSHIP OF PRIVATE FOREST LANDOWNERS AND SMALL-LOT PROPERTY OWNERS FOR THE SEGMENT UNINTERESTED IN TRADITIONAL FOREST MANAGEMENT OPPORTUNITIES PRESENTS AN OPPORTUNITY TO HIGHLIGHT THE MYRIAD OF BENEFITS PROVIDED BY ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL CONNECT WITH THESE INDIVIDUALS THROUGH THE MARKETING AND AWARENESS OF AGROFORESTRY PRACTICES AND USDA COST-SHARE PROGRAM AVAILABILITY. ACTIVITIES <(>&<)> DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: ILLINOIS EXTENSION FORESTRY WILL ENGAGE IN THE FOLLOWING EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND PROGRAMMING MODALITIES TO ACHIEVE OUR DESIRED GOALS AND OBJECTIVES LISTED IN OUR NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: IN-PERSON WORKSHOPS, TRAININGS, CONFERENCES, AND FIELD DAYS; ONLINE WEBINARS, CONFERENCES, AND SYMPOSIA; WEBSITES, SOCIAL MEDIA, VIDEOS, ARCGIS STORYMAPS, AND BLOG POSTS; PRINT AND ONLINE PUBLICATIONS; FIELDING PHONE CALLS AND EMAILS DIRECTLY; AND OCCASIONAL LANDOWNER SITE VISITS WHEN TIME AND TRAVEL FUNDS PERMIT. ESTABLISHMENT OF BASELINE DATA (ACQUIRED INTERNALLY AND VIA (STATE OF ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES) IDNR-FORESTRY, USDA-NRCS (NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE), AND USDA FOREST SERVICE) AND PROJECT OUTCOMES AND IMPACT WILL BE TRACKED AND MONITORED USING A COMBINATION OF TRADITIONAL METRIC GATHERING SOFTWARE, PROGRAM ATTENDEE EVALUATIONS, LIMITED FOLLOW-UP SURVEYS/QUESTIONNAIRES, AND THE NOVEL DEVELOPMENT OF A NEW "ILLINOIS FORESTRY DATA DASHBOARD" TOOL ACCESSIBLE IN REAL-TIME VIA OUR ILLINOIS EXTENSION FORESTRY WEBSITE.

UNIVERSITY OF MAINE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION, RREA PROJECT ABSTRACT FORM, FY 2023 RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT (RREA) PURPOSE THE LAND BASE OF MAINE IS 89% FORESTED, WITH 69% OF THAT AREA (>12 MILLION ACRES) BEING NONINDUSTRIAL PRIVATE FOREST LAND. RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT (RREA) FUNDED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WILL SUPPORT UMAINE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION STAFF AND FACULTY TO EDUCATE THESE LANDOWNERS ABOUT THE VALUE OF THE FORESTS. THESE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WILL FOCUS ON THE ECONOMIC AND ECOSYSTEM BENEFITS OF SUSTAINABLY MANAGED FORESTS, AND OPPORTUNITIES RELATED TO SUSTAINABLY HARVESTED TIMBER AND NON-TIMBER FOREST PRODUCTS. MAINE ACTIVITIES SUPPORTED BY RREA UMAINE EXTENSION WILL DEVELOP AND DELIVER WORKSHOPS AND RESOURCES TO THE FOREST LANDOWNERS OF MAINE. THESE PROGRAMS INCLUDE;  A SUSTAINABLE SUGARBUSH MANAGEMENT FULL DAY CONFERENCE  MAPLE GRADING SCHOOL: QUALITY CONTROL IN THE SUGARHOUSE  VARIOUS MAPLE FOCUSED FIELD DAYS  TRAINING FOR BACKYARD MAPLE SYRUP PRODUCTION  MONEY CAN GROW ON TREES: NON-TIMBER FOREST PRODUCT (NTFP) ENTERPRISE EXPLORATION  MAINE WOODS AND ME: SERIES FOR YOUTH ON CAREERS AND THE VARIOUS WAYS THAT WE RELY ON THE FOREST AND FOREST PRODUCTS. BENEFICIARIES, DELIVERABLES, AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES AN EXPECTED 252 LAND MANAGERS, POTENTIAL LAND MANAGERS, OR YOUTH FROM RURAL AREAS WILL RECEIVE DIRECT TRAINING AS A RESULT OF THESE PROGRAMS. 9,500 PEOPLE WILL RECEIVE NEWSLETTER UPDATES AND RESOURCES ABOUT FOREST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. OF THE ABOVE BENEFICIARIES, 45 EXISTING BUSINESSES WILL NOTE AN INCREASE IN PRODUCT QUALITY AND PROFITABILITY, AND 12 WILL LAUNCH NEW BUSINESS ENTERPRISES. 65 WILL NOTE ENHANCED MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY OF THE LAND. FOOD PRODUCTION, QUALITY, AND SAFETY IS EXPECTED TO BE NOTED BY 45.

UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY FORESTRY EXTENSION FY 23 PROJECT ABSTRACT PROJECT TITLE UTILIZING NEW AND OLD PLATFORMS TO IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS FOR FORESTS, WILDLIFE, AND ASSOCIATED BUSINESSES IN KENTUCKY. PROJECT NUMBER - FOREXT1 DATES OCTOBER 1, 2022 - SEPTEMBER 30, 2023 GOALS THE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE PROGRAMS OUTLINED IN THIS PROJECT ARE DESIGNED TO ADDRESS THREE RREA GOALS INCLUDING ENSURING HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS, ENHANCING ECONOMIC BENEFITS, AND ENHANCING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON WORKING FORESTS AND RANGELANDS. SPECIFICALLY THE PROGRAMS ADDRESS ONE OR MORE OF THREE RREA STRATEGIC ISSUES; FOREST WATER RESOURCES, ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES, AND FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH. THE PROGRAMS SUPPORTED BY THIS PROJECT HAVE BEEN SELECTED AND DEVELOPED TO ENSURE THE EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE LEVERAGING OF RESOURCES TO ACHIEVE DESIRED OUTCOMES AND TO FACILITATE BROAD DELIVERY OF PROGRAMS. FURTHER THE PROGRAMS DEVELOPED WILL FACILITATE A WIDE RANGE OF PARTNERS THAT WILL BE USED TO ENHANCE PROGRAM DELIVERY AND LEVERAGE PROJECT FUNDS. THE PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE CROSSCUTTING ISSUES SUCH AS FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. TO FACILITATE OUR CONNECTIONS WITH OUR CLIENT GROUPS WE WILL CONTINUE TO ENHANCE OUR ELECTRONIC DELIVERY OF PROGRAMS, INFORMATION, AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES INCLUDING THE USE OF WEB SITES, WEBINARS AND WEBCASTS, BLOGS, AND CONSTANT CONTACT NEWSLETTERS. THE ULTIMATE GOAL IS TO PROVIDE AWARENESS, EDUCATION, TOOLS AND SOLUTIONS TO THOSE DIRECTLY BENEFITING FROM AND INVOLVED IN OWNING OR MANAGING FOREST AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES. PRODUCTS THERE ARE A NUMBER OF PROGRAMMATIC EFFORTS THAT WILL BE STRATEGICALLY DEVELOPED TO ENCOMPASS THE THREE GOALS AND STRATEGIC ISSUES. SOME PROGRAMMATIC EFFORTS WILL BE ISSUE SPECIFIC AND SOME PROVIDE THE ABILITY TO SERVE TWO OR THREE OF THE ISSUE AREAS AS WELL AS ENCOMPASS CROSSCUTTING ISSUES. PROGRAMMING SUPPORTED BY THIS PROJECT THAT FITS THE LATTER INCLUDES THE PRODUCTION THE KENTUCKY WOODLANDS MAGAZINE, A FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCE BASED MAGAZINE SPECIFICALLY TARGETED FOR FAMILY FOREST OWNERS (NON-INDUSTRIAL PRIVATE FOREST OWNERS); FOREST AND WILDLIFE EXTENSION PUBLICATIONS; FOREST SECTOR ECONOMIC REPORTING, BIMONTHLY ELECTRONIC DELIVERY OF SEVERAL CONSTANT CONTACT NEWSLETTERS FOCUSED ON FAMILY FOREST MANAGEMENT AND CERTIFICATION, AND FOREST HEALTH; STATEWIDE FORESTRY WORKSHOPS FOR FAMILY FOREST OWNERS; ELECTRONICALLY AVAILABLE INFORMATION THROUGH WEBSITES, FACEBOOK PAGES AND BLOGS; AN ANNUAL WEBINAR PROGRAM FOR FAMILY FOREST OWNERS DELIVERED THROUGH COUNTY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE OFFICES. CONSULTATION, PROBLEM SOLVING AND SUPPORT FOR FAMILY FOREST OWNERS WILL BE PROVIDED THROUGH COUNTY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE AGENTS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ENCOMPASS PROGRAMS THAT ARE SINGLE ISSUE FOCUSED AND EDUCATION AND TRAINING EVENTS FOR FOREST INDUSTRY SECTORS PROVIDING DIRECT ECONOMIC BENEFITS TO FAMILY FOREST OWNERS INCLUDING WORKSHOPS AND INDIVIDUAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR WOOD ENTREPRENEURS AND FOREST INDUSTRIES AND EL ECTRONIC DATA BASE MANAGEMENT FOR FOREST PRODUCTS THAT ENHANCE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE FORESTRY SECTOR. OUTCOMES THE PROJECT EXPECTS TO RESULT IN QUANTIFIABLE INCREASES IN AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE AND EXPECTED BEHAVIORAL CHANGES LEADING TO IMPROVED FOREST AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES. SPECIFICALLY THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE ACREAGE UNDER FOREST AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, INCREASE USE OF PRACTICES TO IMPROVE FORESTS AND WILDLIFE HABITAT AND POPULATIONS, INCREASED USE OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN FOREST OPERATIONS, REDUCE LOSSES FROM WILDLIFE DAMAGE, AND IMPROVE DOLLARS SAVED/EARNED FOR FOREST OWNERS AND FOREST INDUSTRIES. IMPROVED FOREST AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PRACTICE WILL RESULT IN HEALTHIER AND MORE RESILIENT FORESTS AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. USE OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES WILL PROVIDE PROTECTION OF WATER RESOURCES DECREASING COSTS OF DRINKING WATER AND IMPROVEMENT IN AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS. IMPROVING DOLLARS SAVED AND EARNED AND REDUCING WILDLIFE DAMAGE RESULTS IN INCREASED ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL WELL-BEING OF SUPPORTED COMMUNITIES AND THE ABILITY TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT AND STEWARDSHIP OF FOREST AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES OVER TIME. AUDIENCE AND BENEFICIARIES AUDIENCES INCLUDE FOREST OWNERS WITH A FOCUS ON FAMILY FOREST OWNERS, FARMERS, FOREST CONTRACTORS AND INDUSTRIES ENGAGED IN FOREST PRODUCT UTILIZATION, ELECTED OFFICIALS, THE GENERAL PUBLIC ENGAGED IN FOREST HEALTH ISSUES, AND FORESTRY, WILDLIFE AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS. METHODS THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO STRATEGICALLY PROVIDE PROGRAMMING AND RESOURCES FOR FAMILY FOREST OWNERS AND ASSOCIATED FOREST CONTRACTORS, PROFESSIONALS, AND DECISION MAKERS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS A RANGE OF INFORMATION DELIVERY PROGRAMS INCLUDING THE WEB SHOW AND ASSOCIATED PODCASTS, YOUTUBE CHANNEL, AND WEBSITE FOR “FROM THE WOODS TODAY”, VIEWED OVER 180,000 TIMES IN 2020-2021, KENTUCKY WOODLANDS MAGAZINE WITH BOTH HARDCOPY AND WEB DELIVERY TO 10,500 FAMILY FOREST OWNERS, PUBLICATION (WEB AND HARDCOPY) OF EXTENSION PUBLICATIONS, FOUR BIMONTHLY CONSTANT CONTACT NEWSLETTERS, TWO WEB SITES PROVIDING FAMILY FOREST ORIENTED RESOURCES AND PROGRAM INFORMATION, AND EIGHT SOCIAL MEDIA SITES INCLUDING FACEBOOK PAGES. WEBCASTS WILL BE PROVIDED TO INDIVIDUALS AS WELL AS GROUPS THROUGH COUNTY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE OFFICES ON FOREST AND WILDLIFE TOPICS. FINALLY, OVER 100 FACE-TO-FACE PROGRAMS WILL BE CONDUCTED ANNUALLY. THE MAJORITY OF FAMILY FOREST OWNERS USE PROFESSIONAL CONTRACTORS TO PROVIDE SERVICES AND FORESTERS (AGENCY, INDUSTRY AND CONSULTING) TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS EDUCATION AND TRAINING OF THESE PROFESSIONAL CONTRACTORS (EXAMPLE: KENTUCKY MASTER LOGGER PROGRAM) AND TECHNICAL SERVICE PROVIDERS THROUGH THE PROFESSIONAL FORESTRY WORKSHOPS PROGRAM AND AGENCY AND ORGANIZATION TRAINING PROGRAMS INCLUDING ASSOCIATIONS AND STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES. EDUCATION AND TRAINING PROGRAMS FOR ENTREPRENEURS AND INDUSTRY WILL BE ALSO BE INCORPORATED INTO THIS PROJECT INCLUDING ONE-ON-ONE ENTREPRENEURIAL AND SMALL GROUP PROGRAMS AT UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY’S WOOD UTILIZATION CENTER TO ASSIST IN REALIZING ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES ASSOCIATED WITH WOOD. MAJOR PROJECTS WILL INCORPORATE PRE- AND POST-PROGRAM TESTING, SURVEYS, AND/OR PARTICIPANT FEEDBACK OPPORTUNITIES TO DETERMINE KNOWLEDGE CHANGE, GAUGE IMPACTS, AND PROVIDE INFORMATION USED TO EVALUATE AND ADJUST PROGRAM DELIVERY. WHERE APPROPRIATE SURVEY AND STATE AND REGULATORY DATA WILL BE COLLECTED AND ANALYZED TO DETERMINE KNOWLEDGE AND BEHAVIORAL CHANGE, IMPLEMENTATION RATES, AND DOLLARS SAVED OR EARNED. TRACKING OF WEB USERS HITS AND DOWNLOADS WILL BE MAINTAINED AND ONLINE SURVEY FORMS AND WEB PORTALS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO USERS TO OBTAIN FEEDBACK. IN SUMMARY ALL OF THE PROGRAM SPECIFIC SURVEYS WILL BE ANALYZED TO DETERMINE OVERALL PROJECT IMPACTS AND EFFECTIVENESS. THIS INFORMATION WILL ALSO BE USED TO ASSESS THE DISTRIBUTION OF RESOURCES TO INDIVIDUAL PROGRAMS ACROSS THE PROJECT AND ALLOW FOR ADJUSTMENTS IN PROGRAM EMPHASIS. SUMMARY THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO REDUCE THE DISCREPANCY BETWEEN THE POTENTIAL ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL ATTRIBUTES THAT FOREST AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES CAN PROVIDED TO THE CITIZENS OF KENTUCKY AND WHAT IS CURRENTLY REALIZED FROM THESE RESOURCES. THIS PROJECT WORKS TO INCREASE THE AWARENESS OF CRITICAL FOREST AND WILDLIFE HEALTH AND MANAGEMENT ISSUES. IT ALSO PROVIDES EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND MATERIALS, TOOLS, AND SOLUTIONS FOR FOREST OWNERS, CONTRACTORS, FORESTRY, WILDLIFE, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS AND ELECTED OFFICIALS ALLOWING THEM TO MAKE KNOWLEDGEABLE DECISIONS. THE PROGRAMS INVOLVED IN THIS PROJECT ARE STRATEGICALLY COORDINATED TO BUILD CAPACITY AMONGST ALL CRITICAL GROUPS INVOLVED IN FOREST AND WILDLIFE ISSUES TO ENSURE EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE BEHAVIORAL CHANGES TO IMPROVE FOREST AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES IN KENTUCKY.

UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, COLLEGE AGNR RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT CAPACITY GRANT (RREA), FY 2023 ABSTRACT PROJECT DESCRIPTION: WITH A POPULATION OF OVER 6 MILLION PEOPLE, MARYLAND CONTINUES TO BE A RAPIDLY GROWING URBANIZING STATE WITNESSING CHANGES IN DEMOGRAPHICS, ECONOMIC AND POLITICAL PATTERNS THAT AFFECT FOREST OWNERSHIP, MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY. ACCORDING TO DATA FROM THE USDA FOREST SERVICE, THE MARYLAND DNR FOREST SERVICE ESTIMATES THAT THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 2.44 MILLION ACRES OF FOREST LAND IN MARYLAND WHICH COVERS ABOUT 39% OF THE TOTAL LAND AREA IN THE STATE. FIFTY THREE PERCENT OF THE STATE’S FORESTS ARE FAMILY-OWNED COVERING MORE THAN 1.3 MILLION ACRES. THE NUMBER OF FAMILY OWNERSHIPS 1-9 ACRES HAS CONTINUED TO INCREASE FROM 55% IN 1976, TO 65% IN 1989, AND STABILIZING AT ABOUT 85% SINCE 2006. THIS TREND REQUIRES DEVELOPING PROGRAMS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF FAMILY OWNERSHIPS WITH DIFFERENT OBJECTIVES AND INTERESTS. THESE PRIVATE FOREST LANDS PROTECT AND SUPPLY MORE THAN 2/3 OF MARYLAND'S DRINKING WATER, PROVIDE CARBON SEQUESTRATION OPTIONS, AND ARE THE SOURCE FOR UNCOUNTABLE OTHER PUBLIC BENEFITS LIKE CLEAN AIR, RECREATIONAL AREAS, AND BIODIVERSITY TO NAME BUT A FEW. OBJECTIVES: UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND COLLEGE PARK'S (UMCP) OVERALL PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION THAT WILL EDUCATE DIVERSE FOREST LANDOWNERS ABOUT THE VALUES OF THE FOREST LAND; HOW TO MANAGE THEIR FOREST IN A PROFITABLE AND SUSTAINABLE MANNER IN THE FACE OF CHANGING ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC FORCES; UNDERSTAND ECOSYSTEM SERVICE VALUES; BENEFITS OF BIOMASS AS AN ALTERNATIVE FUEL SOURCE; HOW TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITAT; AND SUSTAINABLE LOGGING PRACTICES. THE PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON SMALL FOREST LANDOWNERS (10 ACRES OR LESS), UNDERSERVED AND/OR MINORITY LANDOWNERS, AS WELL AS LARGER PRIVATE OWNERSHIPS OF ALL SIZES TO MEET THE DIVERSE NEEDS OF THE STATE, ALONG WITH THE ORGANIZATIONS THAT SERVICE THE LAND, AND THE FOREST INDUSTRY THAT PROCESS AND HARVEST THE TIMBER. THE OVERRIDING GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO EDUCATE FOREST LANDOWNERS, LOGGERS, UNDERSERVED AND/OR MINORITY LANDOWNERS WHO OWN FARM OR FORESTLAND, AND POLICY MAKERS OF THE VALUE OF MANAGING FOREST RESOURCES USING SUSTAINABLE FORESTRY PRACTICES THAT WILL ENSURE A SUSTAINABLE SOURCE OF FOREST PRODUCTS, WILDLIFE, WATER QUALITY AND AESTHETICS FOR THAT CONTRIBUTE TO THE QUALITY OF LIFE OF ALL MARYLAND CITIZENS, AND PROVIDE FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS. METHODS: UMCP WILL ACCOMPLISH ITS GOALS THROUGH A COOPERATIVE AND COLLABORATIVE PROGRAM DELIVERY, EVALUATION AND REPORTING SYSTEM. PROGRAM DELIVERY WILL BE THROUGH A VARIETY OF METHODS INCLUDING GENERAL FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE CORRESPONDENCE COURSES; THE STATEWIDE WOODLAND STEWARDS PROGRAM; THE MD/DEL MASTER LOGGER PROGRAM; THE WOODS IN YOUR BACKYARD COURSE AND PROGRAM, WOOD ENERGY EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS; FORESTRY FIELD DEMONSTRATION TOURS, FARM AND FORESTS FIELD DAYS, FACE-TO-FACE, TELEPHONE AND EMAIL CONSULTATIONS, AND FORESTRY SEMINARS AND WORKSHOPS. FOR THE GENERAL FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE COURSES - EVALUATION WILL TAKE SEVERAL APPROACHES, WITH END-OF-LESSON QUIZZES AND THE FINAL EVALUATION OF THEIR FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PLANS. THE SECOND COMPONENT OF THE EVALUATION PROCESS WILL BE FOLLOW-UP SURVEYS AT ONE YEAR AND 5 YEARS AFTER COMPLETION OF THE COURSE TO MEASURE BEHAVIORAL CHANGES SUCH AS IMPLEMENTATION OF PRACTICES OR MONEY SAVED/EARNED.

RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT (RREA) PROGRAM OF WORK ABSTRACT THE UMES RREA PROGRAM IS FOCUSED ON DEVELOPMENT OF EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS TO HELP ALL OWNERS WITH FORESTLAND OF ANY SIZE TO UNDERSTAND THE VALUE OF THEIR FORESTLAND AND TO MANAGE THEIR LAND FOLLOWING SUSTAINABLE FOREST STEWARDSHIP TECHNIQUES. THERE ARE 2.4 MILLION ACRES OF FORESTLAND IN MARYLAND, COVERING ALMOST 43% OF THE TOTAL LAND AREA, WITH 75% BEING FAMILY‐OWNED AND COVERING MORE THAN 1.8 MILLION ACRES. THERE ARE 130,800 PRIVATE FOREST LANDOWNERS IN MARYLAND THAT OWN 78% OF THE FORESTLAND. SINCE JULY 1, 2018, EXTENSION ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED BY UMES ARE EXECUTED UNDER THE UMBRELLA OF THE UMES EXTENSION PROGRAM. WHILE SERVING ALL MARYLANDERS, THE PROGRAM PLACES AN EMPHASIS ON HELPING THE UNDERSERVED AND/OR MINORITY FORESTLAND OWNERS. THE UMES PROGRAM HAS A SPECIFIC FOCUS ON PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AND EVALUATION AND EDUCATION OF FORESTLAND OWNERS ABOUT THE FOLLOWING: THE VALUE OF FORESTLAND; HOW TO MANAGE FORESTLAND IN A PROFITABLE AND SUSTAINABLE MANNER; ECOSYSTEM SERVICE VALUES; THE BENEFITS OF BIOMASS AS AN ALTERNATIVE FUEL SOURCE; HOW TO IMPROVE WILDLIFE HABITATS; AND SUSTAINABLE LOGGING PRACTICES. A NEW AREA OF FOCUS IS THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN AGRITOURISM EDUCATION PROGRAM.

RREA PROJECT ABSTRACT - MISSOURI WHILE 94 PERCENT OF THE STATE'S LAND BASE (41+MILLION ACRES) IS PRIVATELY OWNED, LESS THAN 10 PERCENT OF THESE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AC TIVELY MANAGE THEIR FORESTS, WOODLANDS, AND NON-AGRICULTURAL FIELDS. THIS TRANSLATES DIRECTLY INTO LOST, VALUE-ADDED FOREST PRODUCTS AND INDIRECTLY INTO DIMINISHED ABILITY OF OUR FOREST AND WOODLANDS IN PROVIDING VALUABLE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, SUCH AS CLEAN AIR AND WATER. THIS LACK OF MANAGEMENT IS ALSO RESULTING IN LOST WILDLIFE HABITAT IN OUR WOODLANDS, ON OUR FARMS, AND IN OUR COMMUNITIES. THUS, THERE IS A CRITICAL NEED FOR EXPANDED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS THAT WILL ENABLE ALL MISSOURI CITIZENS TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS REGARDING THE WISE STEWARDSHIP AND CONSERVATION OF THE STATE'S FORESTS AND WOODLANDS, GRASSLANDS AND FIELDS, AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPES AND THE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS WHICH DEPEND UPON THESE ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON DEVELOPING AND DELIVERING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS SO THAT A GREATER NUMBER OF CLIENTELE WILL RECONNECT WITH MISSOURI'S NATURAL RESOURCES, INCLUDING THE FOREST AND WILDLIFE RESOURCE, BECOME ACTIVE LAND STEWARDS SUPPORTING CONSERVATION GOALS AND OBJECTIVES. PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES GOALS: A. INCREASE AND ENHANCE NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN BOTH RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES, INCLUDING ON PRIVATE LANDS FEATURING WORKING FORESTS, WOODLANDS, GRASSLANDS AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION WITHIN MISSOURI AND B. BUILDING CAPACITY THROUGH ENHANCED CONNECTIONS. ISSUE: FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH ACTION: DEVELOP AND DELIVER EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS THAT INCREASE THE LEVEL OF ACTIVE FOREST AND WOODLAND MANAGEMENT BY MISSOURI’S FAMILY FOREST LANDOWNERS. PRODUCTS: 1.CONDUCT A MINIMUM OF 10 FOREST-RELATED EDUCATIONAL EVENTS UNDER THE “MISSOURI WOODLAND STEWARD” AND “WOMEN OWNING WOODLANDS” PROGRAMS. 2.CREATE AND/OR REVISE A MINIMUM OF 5 PEER-REVIEWED, MU EXTENSION GUIDES AND 12NEWSLETTERS. 3.DEVELOP A MINIMUM OF FOUR, 10- TO 15-MINUTE FOREST AND WILDLIFE RELATED VIDEO SEGMENTS. ISSUE: ENHANCING FOREST AND RANGELAND WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES RESOURCES ON PRIVATE LANDS ACTION: DEVELOP AND DELIVER EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS THAT SERVE TO INCREASE THE LEVEL OF ACTIVE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES CONDUCTED BY MISSOURI'S PRIVATE LANDOWNERS. PRODUCTS: 1.CREATE 6 NEW MISSOURI MASTER NATURALIST PROGRAM VOLUNTEER COHORTS EITHER THROUGH EXISTING CHAPTERS OR THE CREATION OF NEW CHAPTERS. OVER 150 MU EXTENSION MASTER NATURALIST VOLUNTEERS WILL BE TRAINED AND CERTIFIED AND CONDUCT VOLUNTEER SERVICE PROJECTS FEATURING NATURAL RESOURCES. 2.CONDUCT 10 WILDLIFE-RELATED EDUCATIONAL EVENTS UNDER THEMES IDENTIFIED WITHIN THE“METHODOLOGY” SECTION OF THE FY22-24 RREA PLAN OF WORK AND 3 MASTER POLLINATOR STEWARD PROGRAMS. 3.CREATE/REVISE A MINIMUM OF 6 PEER-REVIEWED, MU EXTENSION GUIDES FEATURING WILDLIFE AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT THEMES, TARGETING PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND DEVELOP VIDEO SEGMENTS FOR USE. ISSUE: EXPAND, CREATE AND SUSTAIN EFFECTIVE PROGRAM COLLABORATIONS AND PARTNERSHIPS. TARGET AUDIENCES: PRIVATE LANDOWNERS, BOTH RESIDENT AND ABSENTEE, WISHING TO IMPROVE THE NATURAL RESOURCE BASE ON THEIR PROPERTY; EDUCATORS WISHING TO INCORPORATE SCIENCE-BASED FOREST AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT PRINCIPLES AND PRACTICES INTO THEIR CURRICULUM AND WITH NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS REPRESENTING STATE, FEDERAL AND NON-PROFIT CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS WISHING TO COLLABORATE IN DELIVERING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WITH A DIVERSE CLIENTELE ACROSS THE STATE.

PROJECT ABSTRACT RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM THE MASSACHUSETTS RREA PROGRAM REPRESENTS THE COORDINATED EFFORTS OF EXTENSION FACULTY, PROFESSIONAL STAFF, AND EXTERNAL PARTNERS TO IDENTIFY AND CONSERVE CRITICAL FOREST RESOURCES OF MASSACHUSETTS. THE PROGRAM FOCUSES ON IMPORTANT RESOURCES AND SERVICES THAT FORESTED ECOSYSTEMS PROVIDE AND PURSUES ECOSYSTEM AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES PROMOTING THE SUSTAINABLE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND MAINTENANCE OF ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY. WE FOCUS ON RESEARCH-BASED OUTREACH STRATEGIES AND KEY TARGET AUDIENCES THAT CAN AMPLIFY OUR EFFORTS AND ACHIEVE OUR GOALS, INCLUDING LANDOWNERS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, LAND MANAGERS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, MUNICIPAL OFFICIALS, CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS, REGIONAL PLANNING AGENCIES AND STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCY PERSONNEL. GOALS OF THE MA RREA PROGRAM ARE: •FACILITATE ECOLOGICAL ASSESSMENT AND CONSERVATION PRIORITY SETTING TO PROMOTE STRATEGIC LAND CONSERVATION, SUSTAINABLE USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES, AND MANAGEMENT TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE NATURAL RESOURCES AND ECOLOGICAL INTEGRITY, •INFORM THE CONSERVATION-BASED ESTATE PLANNING DECISIONS OF LANDOWNERS TO REDUCE FOREST CONVERSION AND PARCELIZATION, •INCREASE ADOPTION OF FOREST STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES TO INCREASE FOREST CARBON SEQUESTRATION AND STORAGE TO MITIGATE CLIMATE CHANGE, •INCREASE ADOPTION OF SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES BY FOREST LANDOWNERS, INCLUDING CONSERVATION-BASED ESTATE PLANNING, AND •INCREASE THE ENGAGEMENT OF BIPOC LANDOWNERS WITH THE STEWARDSHIP OF THEIR LAND.

ABSTRACT FOR RENEWABLE RESOURCES NDSU EXTENSION THE MISSION OF NDSU EXTENSION IS TO CREATE LEARNING PARTNERSHIPS THAT HELP ADULTS AND YOUTH ENHANCE THEIR LIVES AND COMMUNITIES. NDSU EXTENSION ACTIVITIES CONTRIBUTE TO IMPROVING CROP PRODUCTIVITY, ADAPTING NEW CROPS; ADAPTING CROPPING SYSTEMS, RESPONDING TO EVOLVING PEST ISSUES, IMPROVING SOIL MANAGEMENT; ASSISTING WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF BIOFUELS AS SUSTAINABLE ENERGY SOURCES; AND TRAINING FAMILIES ON NUTRITION AND WELLNESS TO ADDRESS CHILDHOOD OBESITY. EXTENSION ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO CONTINUE TO FOCUS ON STATE IDENTIFIED NEEDS IN THE AREAS OF AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES; 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT; FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES; AND COMMUNITY, LEADERSHIP, AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT. NDSU EXTENSION CONTRIBUTES TO THESE AREAS BY PROVIDING TRANSFORMATIONAL EDUCATION AND CREATING/MAINTAINING PARTNERSHIPS WITH OTHER ORGANIZATIONS ACROSS THE STATE, REGION, AND NATION. NDSU EXTENSION IS COMMITTED TO THE CREATION OF AN INCLUSIVE AND MULTICULTURAL ORGANIZATION THAT SERVES APPROPRIATELY ALL THE PEOPLE OF THIS STATE. EXTENSION INCORPORATES A RECOGNITION AND APPRECIATION OF THE VALUES AND BENEFITS THAT DIVERSITY CONTRIBUTES TO OUR ORGANIZATION'S LIFE AND MISSION. NDSU EXTENSION PROVIDES EQUAL ACCESS AND SERVICE TO DIVERSE AUDIENCES, A CORE VALUES OF OUR WORK. OUR GOAL IS TO BE THE PREMIER LIFETIME EDUCATION NETWORK THAT HELPS NORTH DAKOTANS IMPROVE THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE. AS THE ISSUES FACING THEM BECOME INCREASINGLY COMPLEX, NDSU EXTENSION WILL CONTINUE TO MEET PEOPLE’S NEEDS AS THEY ADAPT TO THIS CHANGING ENVIRONMENT. BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE OF NDSU EXTENSION PROGRAM - THE HARSH CLIMATE AND SHORT GROWING SEASON OF THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS ARE STRESSFUL TO TREES, LIMIT FORAGE PRODUCTION AND RANGE HEALTH, AND CAN LIMIT WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. THE FORESTS OF THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS REGION PROVIDE POCKETS OF DIVERSITY IN A BROADER AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPE, CREATING SHELTER IN A HARSH ENVIRONMENT WHILE ADDING BEAUTY TO THE LANDSCAPE.RANGE AND PASTURELAND COMPRISE OVER 30% OF NORTH DAKOTA AND ALMOST 50% OF THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS, PROVIDING THE FUNDAMENTAL FORAGE BASE TO THE COW/CALF INDUSTRY AND PRIMARY HABITAT FOR MOST WILDLIFE SPECIES IN THE REGION. SPECIES DIVERSITY IN THIS REGION IS OFTEN LIMITED, ESPECIALLY IN THE PRESENCE OF INVASIVE SPECIES. THE EXTENSION FORESTRY AND RANGE PROGRAM AT NORTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY WILL RESPOND TO THESE PROBLEMS BY FOCUSING ON TWO PRIMARY AREAS – FOREST HEALTH (IN A BROAD SENSE) AND INVASIVE SPECIES OF RANGELANDS. TWO SPECIFIC PROGRAMS WILL BE EMPHASIZED: (1) FOREST SPECIES DIVERSITY, AND (2) RANGE ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION. THE GOALS OF EACH OF THESE PROGRAMS ALL RELATE TO THE BROADER FIELD OF FOREST AND RANGE HEALTH AND FALL WITHIN THE RREA 2018-2022 STRATEGIC PLAN GOALS. FORESTRY PROGRAMS WILL FOCUS FIRST ON SOIL CONSERVATION DISTRICT (SCD) PERSONNEL, WHO DESIGN AND PLANT MOST OF THE CONSERVATION (WINDBREAK) PLANTINGS IN NORTH DAKOTA. WE WILL DETERMINE HOW THE DIVERSITY OF THOSE PLANTING PLANS CHANGES OVER THE COURSE OF THIS RREA PROJECT. A SECOND AUDIENCE IS THE MANAGERS OF THE VARIOUS ARBORETA AROUND THE STATE. MOST OF THESE ARBORETA ARE SMALL AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS ARE PASSIVE, NOT ACTIVE. WE WILL WORK WITH THOSE INDIVIDUALS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF THEIR ACTIVE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AT THE ARBORETA. FOR THE RANGE PROGRAM, WE WILL IMPROVE ECOSYSTEM HEALTH BY INCREASING THE CAPACITY OF INDIVIDUALS, AGENCIES, AND COMMUNITIES TO RESPOND TO THREATS TO THESE RESOURCES, OR SIMPLY THE CHALLENGE OF PROVIDING RANGELANDS THAT ARE RICH IN DIVERSITY. ACTIVITIES INCREASING TREE SPECIES DIVERSITY IN NORTH DAKOTA IS CHALLENGING. WHILE THE REGIONAL CLIMATE AND SOIL TYPES LIMIT THE NUMBER OF SPECIES AND CULTIVARS THAT CAN GROW AND THRIVE HERE, CONSUMERS OFTEN HESITATE TO TRY NEW SPECIES. ONE APPROACH TO INCREASING SPECIES DIVERSITY IS TO PROVIDE IN-THE-FIELD EDUCATION AT THE VARIOUS ARBORETA FOUND THROUGHOUT THE STATE. A PROJECT WAS BEGUN IN 2020 TO LOCATE AND INVENTORY THOSE ARBORETA. SECONDARILY, WE HAVE BEGUN TO WORK WITH THOSE ARBORETUM MANAGERS TO INCREASE THEIR CAPACITY FOR ACTIVE EDUCATION WITH THEIR CLIENTELE. THAT IS, WE HOPE THAT THEY WILL UTILIZE THEIR ARBORETA TO HOST WORKSHOPS OR EVEN JUST TO PROVIDE INDIVIDUALIZED TOURS TO INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS. THE WORK WITH ARBORETUM MANAGERS WILL PROVIDE A FOUNDATION FOR THE FORESTRY PORTION OF OUR RREA PROJECT. THIS WILL INVOLVE A COMBINATION OF ONE-ON-ONE TRAINING AND REGIONAL WORKSHOPS. ALSO, WE ARE WORKING WITH COUNTY-LEVEL PERSONNEL (EXTENSION AGENTS AND SCD PERSONNEL) TO INCREASE THEIR AWARENESS AND USE OF THEIR LOCAL/REGIONAL ARBORETUM RESOURCES. THESE EFFORTS WILL BE EVALUATED AT THE END OF THE PROJECT WITH A SIMPLE SURVEY. ADDITIONAL WORK WITH SCD PERSONNEL WILL OCCUR THROUGH A SERIES OF TRAINING COURSES THAT WILL FOCUS ON SPECIES DIVERSITY IN THEIR PLANTING PLANS. THOUGH THERE ARE RESTRICTIONS ON ALLOWABLE TREE SPECIES IN CONSERVATION PLANS, DEPENDING ON SOIL TYPES, THERE ARE CERTAIN SPECIES THAT ARE FAVORED OR PREFERRED FOR PLANTING. THIS COMPONENT OF THE PROJECT WILL FIRST INVOLVE A REVIEW OF SPECIES DIVERSITY IN PREVIOUS YEARS (APPROXIMATELY 5 YEARS AGO), FOLLOWED BY A REVIEW OF SPECIES IN THE MOST-RECENT YEAR’S PLANTINGS. EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WILL BE OFFERED IN THE FIRST TWO YEARS OF THE RREA PROGRAM, AND THEN FOLLOWED WITH A REVIEW OF PLANTING PLANS TO DETERMINE IF THERE HAS BEEN AN INCREASE IN SPECIES DIVERSITY IN WINDBREAKS AND OTHER CONSERVATION PLANTINGS. METHODS TO EVALUATE THE EDUCATIONAL TRAINING IMPACTS OF RANGELAND TECHNICAL SERVICE PROVIDERS WILL INCLUDE TWO TO THREE WORKSHOPS PER YEAR ON NOXIOUS AND INVASIVE PLANTS WITH PRE- AND POST-SURVEYS. FOLLOW-UP SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE DIRECT IMPACT ON ACRES WITH ECONOMIC AND ECOLOGICAL PARAMETERS CALCULATED. DEMONSTRATION AND RESEARCH PROJECTS (DEVELOPED WITH NON-RREA FUNDING) WILL BE DEVELOPED ON PRIVATE AND PUBLIC LANDS TO EVALUATE DIFFERENT MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, WHICH WILL PROVIDE THE FOUNDATION TO CREATE NEW EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND POTENTIAL OUTCOMES FOR LAND MANAGERS. TWO BULLETINS, ONE ON MANAGEMENT OF WINDBREAKS AND ANOTHER ON FUNCTIONS OF WINDBREAKS, WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR EXTENSION AGENTS AND CLIENTELE. OUTCOMES AND INDICATORS • SHORT TERM OUTCOME – INCREASED AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF FOREST SPECIES DIVERSITY AND CONTROL STRATEGIES FOR THE PROTECTION OF RANGELAND O INDICATORS - NUMBER OF DIRECT CONTACTS; NUMBER OF EDUCATIONAL EVENTS; NUMBER OF TOURS AND DEMONSTRATIONS; NUMBER OF BULLETINS COMPLETED • MEDIUM TERM OUTCOME - INCREASED CAPACITY OF SCD PERSONNEL, LANDOWNERS, FARMERS, AND RANCHERS TO DEVELOP A RANGELAND STEWARDSHIP PLAN AND CONSERVATION (WINDBREAK) DIVERSIFIED PLAN O INDICATORS - NUMBER OF RANGELAND STEWARDSHIP PLANS DEVELOPED; NUMBER OF CONSERVATION PLANS DEVELOPED WITH DIVERSIFIED TREE SPECIES; CHANGES IN SPECIES DIVERSITY FROM FIVE YEARS PRIOR; INCREASED COLLABORATION AMONG SCD PERSONNEL, ARBORETA MANAGERS, EXTENSION PERSONNEL, AND LANDOWNERS TO IMPLEMENT DIVERSIFICATION OF SPECIES AND APPROPRIATE STEWARDSHIP AND CONSERVATION PLANS • LONG TERM OUTCOME – IMPROVED CAPACITY OF THE ECOSYSTEM THAT INCLUDES DIVERSIFIED RANGELAND AND TREE SPECIES O INDICATORS – POSITIVE ECONOMIC AND ECOLOGICAL DIRECT IMPACT ON ACRES INVOLVED INTENDED BENEFICIARIES – LANDOWNERS, FARMERS, RANCHERS, HOMEOWNERS, SOIL CONSERVATION DISTRICT PERSONNEL, ARBORETA MANAGERS AND NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE.

TITLE: ENHANCING CITYSCAPES AND LANDSCAPES: PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN LANGSTON UNIVERSITY AND TRIBAL AND MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENTS PD: GIPSON, TERRY, A. INSTITUTION: LANGSTON UNIVERSITY THE USE OF GOATS FOR VEGETATION MANAGEMENT IS GAINING IN POPULARITY IN MANY RURAL SETTINGS; HOWEVER, THE USES OF GOATS AS AN ECO-FRIENDLY METHOD TO CONTROL INVASIVE SPECIES OR BRUSH IN URBAN AND SUBURBAN LOCATIONS IS NOW JUST BEING INVESTIGATED. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO 1) INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF LANDOWNERS, MANAGERS, AND PROFESSIONALS TO ASSESS THE THREAT OF INVASIVE SPECIES; DEVELOP INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT PLANS; AND IMPLEMENT EFFECTIVE INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL STRATEGIES TO PROTECT THE NATION’S FOREST AND RANGELAND ECOSYSTEMS. LANGSTON UNIVERSITY WILL DEVELOP NEW PARTNERSHIPS AND ESTABLISH DEMONSTRATION SITES. CURRENT DEMONSTRATION SITES EXIST IN LUTHER AND TATUMS, OK. ONGOING DISCUSSIONS WITH THE CITY OF TAFT AND THE CITY OF FORT COFFEE ARE ONGOING AND DEMONSTRATION SITE WILLBE ESTABLISHED IN THESE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. AS THE PROJECT PROGRESSES, OTHER PARTNERSHIPS WITH UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES WILL BE SOUGHT; AND 2) INCREASE THE AWARENESS OF THE GENERAL PUBLIC, K-COLLEGE STUDENTS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS OF THE THREAT OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND PROVIDE MEANS FOR THEIR INTERACTION AND PARTICIPATION IN MONITORING AND CONTROLLING INVASIVE SPECIES. IN DISCUSSION WITH BOTH THE CITY OF TAFT AND THE CITY OF FORT COFFEE, PLANS WERE DEVELOPED TO INCLUDE HIGH SCHOOL VOCATIONAL AGRICULTURE AND BIOLOGY STUDENTS IN THE PROPOSED PROJECT. WORKSHOPS AT THE END OF THE GRAZING SEASON WILL BE HELD TO HIGHLIGHT THE IMPACT OF USING GOATS TO CONTROL INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES.

ABSTRACT THE PROTECTION OF THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE SUSTAINABILITY OF ITS RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES ARE CRITICAL ISSUES. NEVERTHELESS, MAJOR SEGMENTS OF SOCIETY REMAIN UNENTHUSIASTIC ABOUT NATURE AND THE BENEFITS GAINED FROM IT. AS URBAN COMMUNITIES CONTINUE TO GROW, ISSUES LIKE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, DEFORESTATION, AND NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION ARE BECOMING PRIMARY CONCERNS FOR MANY COMMUNITIES. DRASTIC CHANGES IN CLIMATE AND WEATHER PATTERNS ONLY PERPETUATE THESE PROBLEMS, WARRANTING INCREASED OUTREACH BY EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS. NOTABLY, THE FUTURE LIES IN OUR CITIZENS' HANDS, AND THEIR ABILITY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS IS VITAL. THEY MUST BE PREPARED TO MAKE A CONSCIOUS EFFORT TO PROTECT NATURAL RESOURCES WHENEVER POSSIBLE. EXTENSION AND OUTREACH ARE IDEAL TOOLS FOR GARNERING SUCH IN-DEPTH INVOLVEMENT AND ENSURING INCREASED ADOPTION OF THE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES REQUIRED TO MANAGE AND PROTECT THESE RESOURCES. THIS PROJECT OFFERS INTEGRATED, RESEARCH-BASED OUTREACH EDUCATION FOCUSED ON NATURAL RESOURCES, FORESTRY, AND WILDLIFE. ITS PRIMARY OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) IMPROVE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND 2) PROMOTE POSITIVE BEHAVIOR CHANGES AMONG ALABAMA'S URBAN POPULATION.

PROJECT ABSTRACT OUR PORTFOLIOS OF SOLUTIONDRIVEN, CUTTINGEDGE RESEARCH IS CREATING NEW KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY WHICH IS THEN EXTENDED TO ALL NORTH CAROLINIANS THROUGH NC COOPERATIVE EXTENSION. WE ARE TRANSFORMING SCIENCE INTO EVERYDAY SOLUTIONS THAT IMPROVE LIVES AND ALLOW NORTH CAROLINIANS TO LEAD PROSPEROUS, HEALTHY LIVES. A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF EXTENSION AGENTS SERVES AS THE CONDUIT THROUGH WHICH THE NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY ARE COMMUNICATED TO UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS WHO THEN CONDUCT RESEARCH AND FORMULATE SOLUTIONS. EXTENSION AGENTS THEN DELIVER ESSENTIAL INFORMATION INTO THE HANDS OF GROWERS, INDUSTRY, AND MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS AT NC STATE FOCUS ON ADDRESSING FOUR IDENTIFIED STATEWIDE CRITICAL ISSUES: IMPROVING PLANT AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS; PROTECTING ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES, ENRICHING YOUTH, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY WELLBEING; AND ENHANCING FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH. THROUGH INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS, NC STATE IS SOLVING CHALLENGES RELATED TO THE PRODUCTIVITY AND PROFITABILITY OF BOTH LARGE AND SMALL SCALE FARMS. RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION EDUCATORS ARE ALSO DEVELOPING AND DISSEMINATING KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY TO IMPROVE LANDSCAPING AND GARDENING. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS IN ANIMAL SYSTEMS ARE FOCUSED ON DEVELOPING AND DISSEMINATING KNOWLEDGE AND METHODS FOR ANIMAL BREEDING, REPRODUCTION, NUTRITION, GENETICS AND GENOMICS, PHYSIOLOGY, ENVIRONMENTAL STRESS, PRODUCT QUALITY, AND HEALTH AND WELLBEING. THESE INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS ALSO AIM TO TACKLE THE CRITICAL ISSUES IMPACTING THE QUALITY OF OUR SOIL, WATER AND AIR BY PROVIDING SCIENTIFIC SOLUTIONS FOR ANIMAL WASTE MANAGEMENT, WASTEWATER TREATMENT, NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT, SEPTIC SYSTEMS, WETLAND MANAGEMENT, SOIL PROPERTIES, AND FISHERY AND POND MANAGEMENT. NC STATE EXTENSION CONTINUES TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES TO ENRICH YOUTH, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY WELL BEING THROUGH THE 4H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. 4H PROGRAMS INCREASE OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH TO DEVELOP LIFE SKILLS, GROW CONFIDENCE, INDEPENDENCE, RESILIENCE, AND STEM SKILLS THROUGH FUN HANDS ON LEARNING IN SAFE, HEALTHY, AND ENRICHING ENVIRONMENTS. EXTENSION PROGRAMS ALSO ADDRESS CRITICAL CHALLENGES AFFECTING CONSUMER AND FAMILY WELLBEING. IN ADDITION TO YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, OTHER FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE PARENTING, CHILDCARE, FAMILY RELATIONSHIPS, FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT, AGING, HEALTHY HOMES, AND DISASTER READINESS, RESPONSE, AND RECOVERY. AT THE COMMUNITY LEVEL, EXTENSION WORKS WITH INDIVIDUALS, COMMUNITY GROUPS AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS ON LEADERSHIP SKILLS, WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT, ENTREPRENEURSHIP, CIVIC ENGAGEMENT, VOLUNTEERISM, COMMUNITY PLANNING, AND DISASTER PREPAREDNESS NC STATES RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS TO ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH AND TO KEEP AMERICANS HEALTHY AND FREE FROM FOODBORNE ILLNESS NECESSITATE A FOCUS ON PREVENTING FOOD SAFETY PROBLEMS RATHER THAN TAKING A REACTIONARY APPROACH. NC STATES INTEGRATED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION EFFORTS FOCUS ON PROTECTING THE SAFETY OF FOODS ALONG THE ENTIRE SUPPLY CHAIN, FROM PRODUCTION TO CONSUMPTION. TO MEET THE GROWING NEED FOR HEALTHY FOOD, RESEARCHERS ARE DEVELOPING AND PRODUCING NEW FOOD PRODUCTS THAT PROMOTE HEALTH AND PREVENT DISEASE. AT THE SAME TIME, EXTENSION PROVIDES NUTRITION EDUCATION PROGRAMMING TO ENSURE THAT INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE THEY NEED TO MAKE INFORMED CHOICES ABOUT FOOD AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLES. IMPROVING PLANT AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS: WITHIN THIS AREA, WE WILL WORK TO ADDRESS CROSSCUTTING AND EMERGING ISSUES OF ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH AND PRODUCTION. IN ANIMAL SYSTEM, RESEARCHERS WILL STUDY THE EFFICIENCY OF DIFFERENT FEEDING SOURCES TO IMPROVE ANIMAL PRODUCTIVITY AND GUT HEALTH. IN PLANT SYSTEMS, THE FOCUS WILL BE IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE, ALTERNATIVE AND HIGH VALUE CROP PRODUCTION, SEASON EXTENSION, CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION, VALUE ADDED AGRICULTURE, DIGITAL AGRICULTURE, SOIL HEALTH, PEST CONTROL, AND AGRO ECONOMICS. EXTENSION WILL CONTINUE TO EXPAND ITS WORK WITH LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS, PLACING SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON LIMITED RESOURCES, SMALL SCALE MINORITY FARMERS. THE FARM PAVILION WILL FOCUS ON SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND LOCAL AND COMMUNITY FOOD SYSTEMS, HOUSING ITS APPLIED RESEARCH AND DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS STAFF AND PROVIDING SPACE FOR MEETINGS, FORUMS AND CONFERENCES. ENHANCING FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH: WITHIN THIS AREA BOTH RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WILL WORK TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF HUMAN HEALTH, FOOD SAFETY AND HEALTHY LIVING HABITS. THE RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON WHOLE GRAIN CEREALS, HUMAN HEALTH AND HUMAN NUTRITION, PROBIOTICS STRAINS, FOOD ALLERGY, FOOD PRODUCTION PROCESS, BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS OF FOOD, POSTHARVEST TECHNOLOGY AND FOOD SECURITY. COOPERATIVE EXTENSION AND RESEARCHERS AT NCA<(>&<)>T WILL WORK TOGETHER IN A CONCERTED EFFORT TO INCREASE INFORMATION AND RESOURCES FOR AFRICAN AMERICAN FAMILIES AND CHILDREN IN RURAL COMMUNITIES WHO ARE OFTEN POOR AND DISPROPORNCIALLY VULNERABLE ARE WELL EQUIPPED TO MAKE SOUND FINANCIAL DECISIONS FOR THEMSELVES AND THEIR FAMILIES. 4-H PROGRAMMING WILL FOCUS ON AREAS SUCH AS STEM (SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH), LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT, AND AGRISCIENCE. INNOVATION STATION, THE CUTTING-EDGE MOBILE LEARNING EXPERIENCE, WILL CONTINUE TRAVELING TO COUNTIES THROUGHOUT NORTH CAROLINA, PROVIDING INTRODUCTORY AND ADVANCED STEM CURRICULA FOR CHILDREN IN GRADES K-12. ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES: IN THIS AREA WE WILL WORK TO PROTECT THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT, PROVIDE THE SOLUTION FOR WASTE MA NAGEMENT AND CONVENTIONAL ENERGY. CAES RESEARCHERS WILL INVESTIGATE AN ADVANCED BIOLOGICAL SYSTEM TO PRODUCE ALTERNATIVE ENERGY, TREAT THE AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL WASTE, AND PROTECT AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY. CAES RESEARCHERS WILL BE INVOLVED IN MULTISTATE CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECT TO STUDY THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE IN SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND COMMUNITY OF COLOR. RESEARCHERS WILL BE DEVELOPING THE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION SOLUTION TO IMPROVE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES AND WILL BE PROPOSING POLICIES TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND CLIMATE CHANGE. EXTENSION WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT SMALL SCALE PRODUCERS AND LANDOWNERS IN THEIR EFFORT TO DEVELOP WOODLOT MANAGEMENT PLANS WHILE ALSO INTEGRATING TECHNIQUES AND PRACTICES SUCH AS SILVOPASTURE PRODUCTION AND RIPARIAN BUFFERS

TITLE: RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM PURE MAPLE SYRUP IS ONE OF THE MOST ICONIC NON-TIMBER FOREST PRODUCTS IN THE UNITED STATES. THE PRODUCTION OF PURE MAPLE SYRUP REQUIRES ACCESS TO ENOUGH HEALTHY, MATURE TREES AT A DENSITY TO ALLOW FOR THE EFFICIENT AND ECONOMIC COLLECTION OF SAP. FORESTS MANAGED FOR MAPLE SAP PRODUCTION ARE COMMONLY REFERRED TO AS “SUGARBUSHES.” PRODUCTION TECHNOLOGY HAS CHANGED DRAMATICALLY OVER THE PAST 40 YEARS HOWEVER THE RESOURCES TO SUPPORT FORESTERS, MAPLE PRODUCERS AND FOREST LANDOWNERS HAVE NOT ENJOYED THE SAME AMOUNT OF INNOVATION. GOAL 1: ASSIST PROFESSIONAL FORESTERS, MAPLE SYRUP PRODUCERS, AND FOREST LANDOWNERS IN ACTIVELY MANAGING LANDS WITH KNOWLEDGE OF FOREST ECOSYSTEM PROCESSES AND HOW SPECIFIC SUGARBUSH MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES PRODUCE DIFFERENT COMBINATIONS OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. 2: ASSIST MAPLE SYRUP PRODUCERS, AND FOREST LANDOWNERS IN UNDERSTANDING THE ROLE DIFFERENT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES HAVE ON COMMUNITY WELL-BEING. OBJECTIVES ECOSYSTEM SERVICES SHORT- AND MEDIUM-TERM OUTCOMES: - INCREASE PROFESSIONAL FORESTER, MAPLE SYRUP PRODUCER, AND FOREST LANDOWNER KNOWLEDGE TO ACHIEVE THESE OUTCOMES, THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE DEVELOPMENT AND DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION ON FOREST/SUGARBUSH MANAGEMENT, MAPLE PRODUCTION, AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES TO OUR TARGET AUDIENCES THROUGH DIRECT AND INDIRECT METHODS. WE WILL CONTINUE TO UTILIZE ALREADY-ESTABLISHED DELIVERY METHODS AND AUDIENCES TO DELIVER THE LATEST EDUCATION AND RESEARCH RELATED TO OUR GOALS. ANOTHER OUTPUT OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE TO GENERATE FACT-BASED, EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS THAT HIGHLIGHT HOW CAREFUL SUGARBUSH MANAGEMENT CAN PRODUCE SAP AND A SUITE OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES. THESE MATERIALS WILL ALLOW FOR A MORE INFORMED DIALOG WITH FOREST LANDOWNERS, FORESTRY PROFESSIONALS AND MAPLE PRODUCERS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT FOR SMITH LEVER RREA CAPACITY GRANT UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING EXTENSION WYOMING IS THE LEAST POPULATED STATE IN THE NATION WITH 576,851 PEOPLE SPREAD OUT ACROSS 97,089 SQUARE MILES, 99.8 PERCENT OF WHICH IS RURAL. CHEYENNE, THE CAPITAL AND LARGEST CITY, HAS A POPULATION OF 65,132 AND IS LOCATED IN THE SOUTHEAST CORNER OF WYOMING. THE STATE IS DIVIDED INTO 23 COUNTIES AND THE WIND RIVER INDIAN RESERVATION. MOST OF THE STATE’S ECONOMY IS CONCENTRATED IN THREE SECTORS: AGRICULTURE, MINERALS, AND TOURISM. WYOMING’S LAND USE IS ALMOST HALF AGRICULTURAL, AT 48.6% WITH 30,169,526 ACRES. ACCORDING TO THE 2017 CENSUS OF AGRICULTURE, WYOMING PRODUCERS OPERATED THE LARGEST FARMS AND RANCHES IN THE U.S. WITH AN AVERAGE OF 2 ,430 ACRES PER FARM, OVER FIVE TIMES THE NATIONAL AVERAGE SIZE. NINETY PERCENT (90%) OF WYOMING’S AGRICULTURAL LAND IS CLASSIFIED AS RANGELANDS. THE WYOMING STATE AND PRIVATE FORESTRY FACT SHEET IN 2021 INDICATED THERE ARE 10,556,536 ACRES OF FOREST LAND IN WYOMING. LESS THAN 20% OF WYOMING FORESTS ARE OWNED BY NONINDUSTRIAL PRIVATE ENTITIES. WYOMING’S RANGELANDS PROVIDE A WIDE VARIETY OF GOODS AND SERVICES TO LOCAL ECONOMIES, INCLUDING CLEAN WATER, WILDLIFE HABITAT, DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK GRAZING, ENERGY EXTRACTION, TOURISM, AND RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES. MOST LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION OCCURS ON WYOMING’S RANGELANDS AND ACCOUNTS FOR 74% OF ALL CASH RECEIPTS FROM AGRICULTURE IN WYOMING. RANGELAND USE DRAWS THE ATTENTION OF DIVERSE AUDIENCES: RANCHERS, SMALL ACREAGE LANDOWNERS, RECREATIONIST, CONSERVATION GROUPS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, AND BUSINESSES. AS SUCH, SUSTAINABLE RANGELAND MANAGEMENT EQUATES TO ECONOMIC STABILITY IN WYOMING. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF UW EXTENSION PROGRAMMING FOR RANGELAND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IS TO SUSTAIN OR IMPROVE RANGELAND HEALTH AND RANCHES PROFITABILITY. A SIGNIFICANT ISSUE FACING RANCHERS AND RANCH MANAGERS IS INCREASED CLIMATE VARIABILITY. CHANGES IN PRECIPITATION EFFECT MANY ASPECTS OF RANGE MANAGEMENT. RANCHERS AND RANCH MANAGERS MUST UNDERSTAND AND IMPLEMENT EFFECTIVE DROUGHT MANAGEMENT PLANS, MANAGEMENT OF INTENSIVE GRAZING STRATEGIES, AND TECHNIQUES TO CONTROL INVASIVE AND NOXIOUS WEEDS. AS A RESULT OF EXTENSION’S EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND OTHER RESOURCES WHICH SUPPORT EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS PRODUCERS AND MANAGERS WILL ADOPT PRACTICES THAT IMPROVE PRODUCTIVITY ON RANGELANDS. EXAMPLES OF EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS ARE HIGHLIGHTED BELOW: • INVASIVE WEEDS CAN CHANGE THE ECOLOGY OF A LANDSCAPE BY REPLACING NATIVE VEGETATION WHICH WILL HAVE ADVERSE EFFECTS ON SOIL HEALTH, WILDLIFE BOTH INVERTEBRATES AND VERTEBRATES, AND LIVESTOCK. LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS ALREADY RECOGNIZE THAT INVASIVE WEEDS CAUSE A REDUCTION IN FORAGE AND SEEK EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AND TRIALS TO CONTROL THE SPREAD OF INVASIVE WEEDS. LANDOWNERS AND LAND MANAGERS PARTICIPATING IN UWE PROGRAMS WILL SEE REDUCED AREAS INFESTED WITH INVASIVE AND NOXIOUS WEEDS. • REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE PRACTICES IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND FUNCTION OF SOIL. THESE BENEFITS LEAD TO BETTER NUTRIENT CYCLING, IMPROVED WATER INFILTRATION AND MORE CONSISTENT YIELDS OVER TIME. ADDITIONALLY, COVER CROPS SUPPRESS WEEDS, PREVENT EROSION, CONTROL DISEASES AND PESTS AS WELL AS HELP POLLINATORS. REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE PRACTICES ARE ALSO USED TO PROVIDE FORAGE FOR LIVESTOCK. WHEN COVER CROPS ARE GRAZED, ATTENTION MUST BE PAID TO THE SPECIES THAT WILL BENEFIT SOIL HEALTH, BE PALATABLE AND SAFE AS FORAGE FOR LIVESTOCK, AND THE ABILITY TO BE FLEXIBLE WITH STOCKING RATES DUE TO THE VARIABILITY IN COVER CROP PRODUCTIVITY. EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS ASSIST PRODUCERS IN GATHERING RESOURCES ON COVER CROP OPTIONS, HOW TO PLANT AND STRATEGIES FOR USE. INTEREST IN REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE PRACTICES HAS GROWN AS PRODUCERS HAVE SEEN INCREASED FORAGE SUPPLY, GROWING FORAGES IN PLACES THAT HAD BEEN UNPRODUCTIVE, AND IN WEED CONTROL EFFORTS ON RANGELANDS. • GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE ANNUAL OPERATING INSTRUCTIONS FOR GRAZING PERMITS ON FEDERAL LANDS. THIS WILL LEAD TO AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS AND/OR RANCH MANAGERS WHO STAY IN COMPLIANCE WITH GRAZING PERMITS ON FEDERAL LANDS. • WHEN PUBLIC SPACE IS CONCERNED, THE DECISION MAKER CAN BE ANYONE. UNDERSTANDING HOW THE SHARED RESOURCE IS USED AND MANAGED CAN HELP NAVIGATE CONFLICT RESULTING FROM DIFFERENT EXPECTATIONS OF USER GROUPS. EXAMPLES OF UNDERSTANDING BASIC CAUSE AND EFFECT WITH THE ECOSYSTEM INCLUDE WHY IT’S IMPORTANT TO ‘SHUT THE GATE’, OR A RECREATIONAL FISHERMAN UNDERSTANDING THE SENSITIVITIES OF A RIPARIAN ZONE. • MULTIPLE USER GROUPS REQUIRE AND/OR VALUE ACCESS TO UNMODIFIED RANGELANDS IN THE WESTERN US. MANY RANCHERS RELY ON THE OPPORTUNITY TO GRAZE LARGE ACREAGES OF PUBLIC LAND TO MAINTAIN THE VIABILITY OF THEIR BUSINESS. INCREASINGLY, RECREATIONISTS (TO INCLUDE HUNTERS, HIKERS, WILDLIFE VIEWERS, ETC.) ARE VALUING THE WIDE-OPEN SPACES THAT RANGELANDS PROVIDE. WHILE USE AND PUBLIC INTEREST IN RANGELANDS IS INCREASING, PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE ABOUT DIFFERENCES IN HOW DIFFERENT LANDS ARE MANAGED HAS NOT KEPT PACE. • KNOWLEDGE OF DISASTER RESOURCES, DEVELOPMENT OF DISASTER PLANS, AND EFFECTIVE DECISION-MAKING STRATEGIES WILL ALSO PREPARE INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES TO MITIGATE POTENTIAL DISASTERS AND ENGAGE APPROPRIATE RESPONSES TO REDUCE THEIR VULNERABILITY TO DISASTERS. ANOTHER ISSUE AFFECTING WYOMING IS THE INCREASING NUMBER OF SMALL ACREAGE OWNERS. THOUSANDS OF ACRES OF FORMER RANCH, FARM OR WILDLANDS ARE BEING SUBDIVIDED INTO SMALL ACREAGE PARCELS WITH LANDOWNERS WHO HAVE LIMITED EXPERIENCE MANAGING RANGELANDS. THIS LACK OF EXPERIENCE LEADS TO SOIL EROSION, DECREASED AND FRAGMENTED WILDLIFE HABITAT, INVASIVE NOXIOUS WEED INFESTATIONS, AND GRASSLAND DEGRADATION. THE SMALL ACREAGE OUTREACH PROJECT PROVIDES SMALL ACREAGE LANDOWNERS WITH INFORMATION NEEDED TO SUSTAINABLY MANAGE THEIR LAND. ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES FOR SMALL ACREAGE LANDOWNERS INCLUDE: • INCREASE IN KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE NUMBER OF LIVESTOCK DIFFERENT SIZES OF PROPERTIES CAN SUPPORT WITHOUT DECREASING PASTURE HEALTH AND INCREASING WEEDS. THIS WILL ALLOW SMALL ACREAGE OWNERS TO BETTER MANAGE THEIR PASTURES. • LEARN TACTICS TO PROPERLY ID AND CONTROL INVASIVE WEEDS AND IMPLEMENT THESE TACTICS. MORE EFFECTIVE CONTROL OF INVASIVE WEEDS WILL CREATE HEALTHIER RANGELANDS AND PASTURES. • GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HOW FENCING CHOICES IMPACT WILDLIFE MOVEMENT. SMALL ACREAGE LANDOWNERS WILL CONSIDER WILDLIFE MOVEMENT WHEN INSTALLING OR REPLACING FENCING. • LEARN ABOUT THE EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES AVAILABLE IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND THROUGH OUR MATERIALS TO HELP THEM BE BETTER LAND STEWARDS.

SUSTAINING FOREST RESOURCES IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS THE ECONOMY OF THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS IS PREDOMINANTLY DEPENDENT UPON THE TOURISM INDUSTRY. OUR NATURAL RESOURCES ARE CRITICAL COMPONENTS OF THE ECONOMY AND ARE ALSO IMPORTANT FOR OUR QUALITY OF LIFE. THE NEED EXISTS, THEREFORE, TO DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN A SUSTAINABLE ECOSYSTEM THAT CAN PROVIDE BENEFITS FOR RESIDENTS AND VISITORS. THERE ARE MANY COMPETING DEMANDS FOR OUR LIMITED LAND RESOURCES. POLICYMAKERS ARE FACED WITH TOUGH DECISIONS AS THEY TRY TO FIND A DELICATE BALANCE BETWEEN THE INCREASED NEEDS AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS RELATED TO LAND FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND HOUSING. THIS USUALLY RESULTS IN FURTHER FOREST FRAGMENTATION AND THE ASSOCIATED NEGATIVE CONSEQUENCES. PRIVATE LANDOWNERS ARE FORCED TO MAKE FINANCIAL DECISIONS REGARDING THE USE AND MANAGEMENT OF THEIR PROPERTIES. MANY OF THESE LANDOWNERS ARE NOT FAMILIAR WITH PROPER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR TREES AND FORESTS. THEY MUST BECOME AWARE OF THE BENEFITS OF PROPER LAND STEWARDSHIP AND HOW IT SUPPORTS OUR NATURAL RESOURCES. THEY ALSO NEED TO BE MADE AWARE OF THE VALUE OF TREES/FORESTS AND WHAT THEY PROVIDE TO LOCAL ECONOMIES - INCLUDING THE VALUABLE CONTRIBUTIONS MADE TO THE TOURISM INDUSTRY AND THE QUALITY OF LIFE OF RESIDENTS. TREES/FORESTS MUST BE APPRECIATED FOR ENCOURAGING BIODIVERSITY, PROVIDING OPEN SPACES AND RECREATIONAL OPPO RTUNITIES. PROPER TREE ESTABLISHMENT, CARE AND MAINTENANCE ARE SOME OF THE TOPICS THAT WILL BE EMPHASIZED. PARTNERSHIPS WITH OTHER GROUPS AND INDIVIDUALS WILL ASSIST IN GETTING INFORMATION TO OUR STAKEHOLDERS. THIS WILL HELP TO IMPROVE THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS. THE INFORMATION WILL BE PRIMARILY PROVIDED THROUGH WORKSHOPS, SITE VISITS, DEMONSTRATIONS, WEBPAGES AND SEMINARS. STAKEHOLDERS WILL ALSO BE MADE AWARE OF THE NEGATIVE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON WEATHER, ESPECIALLY DROUGHTS, FLOODING, THE SEVERITY OF TROPICAL STORMS/HURRICANES AND HOW BEST TO MITIGATE THESE EFFECTS. THE HURRICANE SEASON LASTS FOR SIX MONTHS EACH YEAR. DURING THIS TIME OUR TREES/URBAN FORESTS ARE VULNERABLE TO DAMAGE CAUSED BY THE PASSAGE OF STORMS OF VARYING INTENSITIES. WE WILL FOCUS ON STRATEGIES THAT PREPARE OUR URBAN FORESTS TO WITHSTAND DIVERSE/EXTREME WEATHER CONDITIONS AND HOW TO RECOVER FROM SUCH EVENTS. THE RECYCLING OF FALLEN TREES AND PARTS OF TREES INTO VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS WILL ALSO BE INCLUDED. THE LOCAL GOVERNMENT HAS INITIATED A PROGRAM TO RECYCLE GREEN WASTE INTO COMPOST AND MULCH, WE WILL PARTNER WITH THIS PROGRAM IN THE EDUCATIONAL ASPECT. THE PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON THE CRITICAL ISSUES OF PUBLIC AWARENESS AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT, ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, ENHANCING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON FORESTS AND PROVIDING INCREASED ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES. THE CROSS-CUTTING ISSUES WILL BE CLIMATE VARIABILITY, URBANIZATION AND INVASIVE SPECIES. THE MAIN OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1) COMMUNICATE THE ECONOMIC BENEFITS AND OPPORTUNITIES THAT CAN BE DERIVED FROM TREE POPULATIONS AND ASSOCIATED NATURAL RESOURCES; 2) DEVELOP PARTNERSHIPS WITH COOPERATING STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, ORGANIZATIONS, BUSINESSES, AND LANDOWNERS TO REACH AND ENGAGE S TAKEHOLDERS MORE EFFECTIVELY; 3) EDUCATE LANDOWNERS, NATURAL RESOURCE EXTENSION AND OTHER PROFESSIONALS, AND YOUTH ABOUT THE BENEFITS OF APPLYING PRACTICES THAT S USTAIN TREE POPULATIONS; 4) DELIVER RESEARCH-BASED EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES THAT WILL HELP GUIDE DECISION-MAKING PROCESSES THAT ENHANCE WORKING LANDSCAPES. THE TARGET AUDIENCE FOR THE PROJECT CONSISTS OF LANDOWNERS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, OTHER EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS, URBAN FORESTERS, FORESTRY PROFESSIONALS, POLICYMAKERS, GOVERNMENTAL AGENCY PERSONNEL, NGOS, YOUTH AND YOUTH GROUPS, FORESTRY COUNCIL MEMBERS, AGRICULTURE ADVISORY GROUPS, LANDSCAPERS, WOODWORKERS/WOOD ARTISANS AND RESIDENTS. THE PROJECT WILL UTILIZE THE FOLLOWING OUTPUTS AS EDUCATIONAL STRATEGIES TO ACHIEVE THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: WORKSHOPS; SITE VISITS; CONSULTATIONS; TRAINING SESSIONS; SEMINARS AND COUNSELING. THESE WILL BE TARGETED TO: LANDOWNERS; NATURAL RESOURCES AND OTHER PROFESSIONALS; URBAN AND OTHER FORESTERS. THEY WILL BE CONDUCTED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES ALONG WITH NONGOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES AND OTHER GROUPS, ORGANIZATIONS AND INDIVIDUALS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE AN INCREASE IN: PARTICIPATION OF LANDOWNERS IN EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES; THE NUMBER OF LANDOWNERS AND PROPERTY MANAGERS WITH IMPROVED DECISIONS MAKING SKILLS; KNOWLEDGE OF LANDOWNERS AND RESIDENTS ABOUT PROPERLY MANAGING TREE POPULATIONS; KNOWLEDGE OF LANDOWNERS AND RESIDENTS ABOUT THE BENEFITS OF TREE POPULATIONS; KNOWLEDGE OF LANDOWNERS AND RESIDENTS ABOUT NATIVE, NATURALIZED AND INVASIVE TREE SPECIES AND INCOME OF WOODWORKERS RECYCLING TREE PARTS INTO VALUE-ADDED ITEMS. FOR EACH OBJECTIVE, THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON DEVELOPING, PROMOTING AND DELIVERING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS IN VARIOUS FORMATS INCLUDING: WORKSHOPS; HANDS-ON DEMONSTRATIONS; SHORT COURSES; INFORMAL CLASSROOM INSTRUCTION; EDUCATIONAL DISPLAYS; INTERNET WEBPAGES; TOURS; AND SEMINARS ALONG WITH WEBINARS, ONLINE TRAINING AND VIDEOS. EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS WILL BE DEVELOPED AND DISSEMINATED TO THE TARGET AUDIENCE. PARTNERSHIPS WILL BE DEVELOPED AND MAINTAINED WITH STAKEHOLDER GROUPS AND ORGANIZATIONS INCLUDING GOVERNMENTAL DEPARTMENTS/AGENCIES AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS. COMMUNITY DECISION-MAKING WILL BE PROMOTED THROUGH INCREASING THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTANDING AND INVOLVEMENT. THIS WILL ALLOW STAKEHOLDERS TO RECOGNIZE PROBLEMS AND BECOME INVOLVED IN THE PROCESS TO RESOLVE THEM. THE MEDIA WILL BE UTILIZED TO PROMOTE THE ACTIVITIES OF THE PROGRAM. SPECIAL EMPHASIS WILL BE PLACED ON THE PARTICIPATION OF YOUTH IN THE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS. EXTENSION STAFF AND OTHER PROFESSIONALS WILL BE THE FOCUS OF PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES. THE OUTCOME OF THE PROJECT WILL BE MEASURED THROUGH THE NUMBER OF PERSONS WHO: GAINED AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE AND PROBLEM-SOLVING SKILLS; INCREASED THEIR UNDERSTANDING; AND CHANGED THEIR ASSUMPTIONS, HABITS AND PRACTICES BASEDUPON THEIR INCREASED KNOWLEDGE. THIS WILL BE DONE THROUGH EVALUATIONS CONSISTING PRIMARILY OF PRE AND POST-TESTS. OTHER METHODS THAT WILL BE USED INCLUDE: OBSERVATIONS; VISUAL EVIDENCE; ANECDOTAL EVIDENCE; SURVEYS; GROUP DISCUSSIONS; TESTIMONIALS; END-OF-EVENT ANALYSIS; AND QUESTIONNAIRES.

PROJECT ABSTRACT FOR FY2023 RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW HAMPSHIRE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION WILL USE THE RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT (RREA) FUNDING TO ENCOURAGE LONG-TERM STEWARDSHIP OF FAMILY FORESTS AND COMMUNITY TREES AND FORESTS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE BY WORKING ONE-ON-ONE AND IN WORKSHOP SETTINGS WITH LANDOWNERS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, COMMUNITY DECISION-MAKERS AND VOLUNTEERS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED; DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES; AND INTENDED BENEFICIARIES 10 WORKSHOPS AND WEBINARS ON CARING FOR FORESTS IN NEW HAMPSHIRE, BOTH BROADLY AND WITH SPECIFIC CONTENT ON TOPICS OF INTEREST TO LANDOWNERS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, MUNICIPALITIES, AND CONSERVATION GROUPS. 200 LANDOWNER WOODLOT SITE VISITS TO ENCOURAGE AND GUIDE FOREST MANAGEMENT ON 10,000 ACRES. TRAIN AND SUPPORT A GROUP OF MORE THAN 900 VOLUNTEERS WHO ACTIVELY MANAGE 100,000 ACRES AND WHO REACH 10,000 PEOPLE WITH A MESSAGE OF SOUND FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION.

RREA  AUBURN UNIVERSITY BACKGROUND: FOREST RESILIENCY, ESPECIALLY AS IT RELATES TO FOREST HEALTH IS A TOPIC OF GROWING CONCERN ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST. ALREADY POSING SIGNIFICANT THREATS TO FORESTED ECOSYSTEMS, THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE SPECIES ARE EXPECTED TO INCREASE WITH CLIMATE VARIATION AND MORE FREQUENT EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS. POSITIONING LANDOWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS TO MINIMIZE THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE SPECIES IS CRUCIAL. MANAGED FORESTS, NATURAL AREAS, URBAN GREEN SPACES, PASTURES, WATERWAYS, ROADSIDES AND RIGHT OF WAYS ARE ALL IMPACTED BY INVASIVE SPECIES. SPECIFICALLY, INVASIVE PLANTS DISPLACE NATIVE PLANT SPECIES AND THE WILDLIFE AND INSECTS THAT DEPEND ON THEM. FIRE REGIMES, WATER CYCLES, NUTRIENT CYCLES, AND FOREST REGENERATION ARE NEGATIVELY IMPACTED BY INVASIVE SPECIES. THREATS ARE COMPOUNDED WITH DISTURBANCES CREATED BY EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS. CONSEQUENTLY, INVASIVE SPECIES POSE AN INCREASING THREAT TO FOREST PRODUCTIVITY, FOREST MANAGEMENT OPTIONS, WILDLIFE HABITAT, OUTDOOR RECREATION, AND OVERALL ECOSYSTEM HEALTH. IN ADDITION TO THE COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH HARM TO THE ENVIRONMENT AND REDUCED PRODUCTIVITY, INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL IS EXPENSIVE. ACROSS THE COUNTRY COSTS MOUNT TO BILLIONS OF DOLLARS EACH YEAR. PREVENTING THE ESTABLISHMENT OF INVASIVE PLANTS AND FINDING AND TREATING INFESTATIONS WHEN STILL SMALL ARE THE MOST COSTEFFECTIVE WAYS TO SLOW THE SPREAD AND REDUCE THE IMPACT OF INVASIVE PLANTS ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE. PREVENTION, EARLY DETECTION AND ADVANCE TREATMENT ARE ALSO IMPORTANT TOOLS FOR MINIMIZING IMPACTS OF INVASIVE SPECIES FOLLOWING EXTREME WEATHER EVENTS AND OTHER LANDSCAPE DISTURBANCES. STAKEHOLDERS CONSISTENTLY IDENTIFY INVASIVE SPECIES AS A TOP NATURAL RESOURCE ISSUE OF CONCERN. OBJECTIVES: LANDOWNER EDUCATION AND CONTINUING EDUCATION FOR NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS ARE KEY TO REDUCING THE IMPACTS OF INVASIVE PLANTS AND IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF ALABAMA FORESTS. OUR PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IS TO EXPAND AWARENESS OF INVASIVE SPECIES, INCREASING KNOWLEDGE OF INVASIVE PLANT IDENTIFICATION, IMPACTS, AND CONTROL OPTIONS. A SECONDARY, BUT CLOSELY ALIGNED OBJECTIVE IS TO MAINTAIN STATE AND REGIONAL PARTNERSHIPS WITH RELEVANT PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTOR ORGANIZATIONS ADDRESSING ISSUES RELATED TO ASSESSMENT, MAPPING, MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL, RESEARCH, AND EDUCATION. INVASIVE PLANTS WILL BE OUR MAIN FOCUS, BUT EMERGING INVASIVE INSECT AND ANIMAL PESTS MAY ALSO BE ADDRESSED. TARGET AUDIENCE: THE PRIMARY TARGET AUDIENCES ARE FOREST LANDOWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROFESSIONALS (E.G., FORESTERS, LOGGERS, WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS) AND STUDENTS OF NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. BECAUSE NONNATIVE PLANTS USED IN LANDSCAPING ARE A MAJOR SOURCE OF THE INVASIVE PLANTS THAT INVADE FORESTS, A SECONDARY AUDIENCE IS HOMEOWNERS, MASTER GARDENERS, THE GENERAL PUBLIC, AND K12 EDUCATORS. DELIVERABLES COMMUNICATION PRODUCTS: PRIMARY COMMUNICATION PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE EXTENSION PUBLICATIONS ADDRESSING INVASIVE PLANT IDENTIFICATION AND CONTROL; FREQUENT POSTS TO THE ALABAMA EXTENSION INVASIVE PLANT FACEBOOK PAGE THAT WE ADMINISTER; BLOGS AND SHORT ARTICLES FOR POPULAR PRESS AND THE TEAM NEWSLETTER; CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE ALABAMA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SYSTEM (ACES) FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE WEBPAGE; AND CONTRIBUTIONS OF HIGH DEFINITION PHOTOGRAPHS OF INVASIVE PLANTS FOR USE IN EDUCATIONAL PRODUCTS AND OTHER OUTREACH NEEDS. EVENTS: OUTREACH EVENTS WILL INCLUDE COCHAIRING THE STATEWIDE ANNUAL ALABAMA INVASIVE PLANT COUNCIL CONFERENCE; ORGANIZING AND PARTICIPATING IN ACES WORKSHOPS AND FIELD DAYS; PROVIDING SEMINARS AND WEBINARS FOR FOREST INDUSTRY, FOREST AND WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AGENCIES, MASTER GARDENERS, CIVIC GROUPS AND OTHERS AS REQUESTED (TYPICALLY ABOUT 20 EVENTS A YEAR.) MANY OF THESE EVENTS PROVIDE CONTINUING EDUCATION CREDITS FOR NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS. SERVICES AND ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES: QUESTIONS FROM LANDOWNERS, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS, EXTENSION AGENTS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC ARE FIELDED EACH YEAR. MOSTINVOLVEPLANT IDENTIFICATION AND TREATMENT OPTIONS FOR INVASIVE PLANTS. WELL OVER ONE HUNDRED QUESTIONS ARE ADDRESSED EACH YEAR VIA PHONE, EMAIL, TEXT AND SOCIAL MEDIA. WE ALSO TEACH A SECTION ON INVASIVE PLANTS TO AUBURN UNIVERSITY FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE STUDENTS, LEAD THE EFFORT TO UPDATE THE ALABAMA INVASIVE PLANT COUNCIL (ALIPC) INVASIVE PLANT LIST (A NONREGULATORY STATE LIST), AND PROVIDE SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTISE TO LOCAL INVASIVE PLANT CONTROL EFFORTS. BUILDING CAPACITY: COLLABORATING WITH STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES AND OTHER STAKEHOLDER PARTNERS STRENGTHENS EDUCATION AND OUTREACH EFFORTS. SERVING ON STATEWIDE INVASIVE PLANT TASK FORCES AND COMMITTEES AND MAINTAINING A LEADERSHIP ROLE WITHIN THE ALABAMA INVASIVE PLANT COUNCIL ARE IMPORTANT AVENUES FOR EFFECTIVE COLLABORATION. REGIONAL PUBLICATIONS AND EVENTS ARE PERIODICALLY ORGANIZED THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH SOUTHERN REGION EXTENSION FORESTRY AND OTHER COLLEAGUES IN THE REGION. INVOLVEMENT IN ONE REGIONAL EFFORT IS LEADING TODEATE BENEFIT IS IMPROVED FOREST HEALTH THROUGH REDUCED SPREAD AND IMPACTS OF INVASIVE PLANTS. A CHANGE IN KNOWLEDGE WILL BE REFLECTED THROUGH AN INCREASED NUMBER OF LANDOWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS WHO KNOW HOW TO IDENTIFY INVASIVE PLANTS AND KNOW WHERE TO ACCESS SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION AND RESOURCES; INCREASED NUMBER OF LANDOWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS WITH KNOWLEDGE OF EFFECTIVE OPTIONS FOR INVASIVE PLANT PREVENTION AND CONTROL; AND INCREASED AWARENESS OF EDDMAPS. A CHANGE IN ACTION WILL BE REFLECTED THROUGH AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF LANDOWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS WHO MONITOR FOR, AND INITIATE OR CONTINUE INVASIVE PLANT MONITORING AND CONTROL EFFORTS, LEADING TO AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF ACRES TREATED; A REDUCTION IN BEHAVIORS THAT SPREAD INVASIVE PLANTS; FEWER HOMEOWNERS AND LAND MANAGERS USING RISKY NON-NATIVE PLANTS IN LANDSCAPING AND WILDLIFE PLANTINGS; AND AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF PEOPLE WHO USE EDDMAPS TO REPORT INVASIVE PLANTS. ULTIMATELY, THE EXPECTED OUTCOME IS IMPROVED FOREST HEALTH AND RESILIENCY THROUGH REDUCED USE OF NON-NATIVE PLANTS IN LANDSCAPING AND WILDLIFE PLANTINGS; REDUCTIONS IN BEHAVIORS THAT SPREAD INVASIVE PLANTS; AND EARLIER AND MORE EFFECTIVE TREATMENT OF INVASIVE PLANTS. EFFORTS TO IMPROVE INVASIVE PLANT LISTING AND MAPPING WILL IMPROVE THE ACCURACY OF DISTRIBUTION MAPS TO BETTER REFLECT OF INVASIVE PLANT POPULATIONS ACROSS THE STATE, BETTER INFORMING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

ENGAGING UNDERSERVED MISSISSIPPI SMALL-SCALE FARMERS AND WOODLAND OWNERS IN FOREST FARMING MISSISSIPPI IS AMONG THE TOP-TEN FOREST STATES IN THE UNITED STATES (US) WITH 65% OF ITS LAND IN FORESTS AND OVER 70% OF THIS LAND OWNED BY NON-INDUSTRY PRIVATE FOREST LANDOWNERS. EVEN WITH THE RICH MIXED HARDWOOD FOREST RESOURCES, MUSHROOM PRODUCTION AMONG THE UNDERSERVED FARMERS AND FOREST LANDOWNERS (UFFLOS) IS SCARCELY CONSIDERED AS A SOURCE OF FRESH FOODS AND/OR AN ECONOMIC ENDEAVOR TO BOOST ADDITIONAL INCOME WHILE WAITING FOR TIMBER TO MATURE. THE CULTIVATION OF SPECIALTY CROPS SUCH AS SHIITAKE (LENTINULA EDODES) AND OYSTER (PLEUROTUS OSTREATUS) MUSHROOMS COULD BE A POTENTIAL SOURCE OF FRESH FOOD THAT CAN MINIMIZE THE IMPACT OF FOOD INSECURITY IN MISSISSIPPI. EDIBLE MUSHROOMS ARE GLOBALLY CONSIDERED AS HEALTHY FOOD, LOW IN CALORIES WITH EXCELLENT NUTRITIVE MEDICINAL PROPERTIES, AND ARE FUNDAMENTAL IN FOOD SECURITY MUSHROOMS ARE DESIRABLE IN AREAS WITH FOOD INSECURITY BECAUSE THEY CONVERT INFERIOR LIGNOCELLULOSIC WASTE LEFT IN FORESTS AFTER TIMBER HARVESTING INTO HIGHLY NUTRITIOUS AND HEALTHY FOOD. THE TECHNOLOGY OF MUSHROOM CULTIVATION IS ONE OF THE FEW MICROBIAL TECHNOLOGIES FOR BIOCONVERSION OF INFERIOR WASTE WOOD AND AGRICULTURAL RESIDUES TO FUNCTIONAL FOODS THUS, THE ULTIMATE GOAL FOR THE PROJECT IS TO EDUCATE OUR TARGET AUDIENCE ON THE ECONOMIES AND TECHNOLOGY REGARDING THE CULTIVATION OF VARIOUS OUTDOOR EDIBLE MUSHROOMS USING WASTE WOOD AND AGRICULTURAL RESIDUES. AMONG THE OUTDOOR MUSHROOMS EXPECTED TO BE PROMOTED IN THIS PROJECT INCLUDE LENTINULA EDODES, PHOLIOTA NAMEKO, STROPHARIA RUGOSO-ANNULATA, AGARICUS SUBRUFESCENS, CLITOCYBE NUDA, INCLUDING OYSTER SPECIES. ALL THESE EDIBLE MUSHROOMS HAVE MEDICINAL PROPERTIES FOR CHRONIC DISEASE, ARE NUTRITIOUS, WITH MANY VITAMINS, AND ALSO ARE EXCELLENT SOURCE OF FIBER AND MINERALS. BESIDES, UFFLOS WILL BE EDUCATED ON THE ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE/OPPORTUNITIES OF OTHER AGROFORESTRY COMPONENTS SUCH AS ALLEY CROPPING, SILVOPASTURE, RIPARIAN BUFFERS, AND WINDBREAKS INCLUDING SOIL QUALITY AMELIORATION AND FOREST HEALTH. WORKSHOPS WILL ALSO BE CONDUCTED ON USDA GOOD AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES HARMONIZED FOOD SAFETY STANDARDS AND POSTHARVEST AUDIT CERTIFICATION. THIS CERTIFICATION AFFORDS PARTICIPANTS THE OPPORTUNITY TO SELL THEIR PRODUCE TO RETAIL AND OTHER OUTLET MARKETS. THEREFORE, THIS PROJECT WILL: 1) EDUCATE OUR TARGET AUDIENCES- THE UFFLOS ON THE ECONOMIES AND TECHNOLOGY REGARDING THE CULTIVATION OF VARIOUS OUTDOOR EDIBLE MUSHROOMS USING WASTE WOOD AND AGRICULTURAL RESIDUES. 2) EDUCATE UFFLOS ON THE ECONOMIC IMPORTANCE/OPPORTUNITIES OF OTHER AGROFORESTRY COMPONENTS SUCH AS ALLEY CROPPING, SILVOPASTURE, RIPARIAN BUFFERS, AND WINDBREAKS TARGETED AUDIENCES 1. EXTENSION AND OUTREACH PERSONNEL (IN-SERVICE TRAINING), 2. UNDERSERVED AND LIMITED RESOURCES FARMERS AND LANDOWNERS, 3. FORESTRY AND OTHER USDA PERSONNEL, AND 4. PUBLIC POLICY MAKERS. IMPACT/OUTCOME INDICATORS: INCREASE NUMBER OF UNDERSERVED FARMERS AND LANDOWNERS ATTENDING FIELD DAYS AND WORKSHOPS IN AGROFORESTRY PRACTICES; 2. INCREASE NUMBER OF WOODLAND OWNERS WHO HAVE ADOPTED AGROFORESTRY SYSTEMS REGARDING THE CULTIVATION OF MUSHROOMS USING WASTE WOOD AND AGRICULTURAL RESIDUES; 3. INCREASE THE NUMBER OF UFFLOS WHO OBTAIN GAP AND POSTHARVEST AUDIT CERTIFICATION.

THE PRIMARY INDUSTRY IN SC IS AGRICULTURE, WITH 25,000 FARMS ACROSS 4.7 MILLION ACRES THAT CONTRIBUTES OVER $46 BILLION TO THE STATE'S ANNUAL ECONOMY AND PROVIDES OVER 247,000 JOBS. FORESTRY IS ALSO AN IMPORTANT ECONOMIC DRIVER IN SC, CONTRIBUTING OVER $21.2 BILLION ANNUALLY. WITH SUCH DIVERSE NATURAL RESOURCES ACROSS THE STATE, TOURISM IS ALSO A MAJOR ECONOMIC FORCE, ACCOUNTING FOR EXPENDITURES OF $24.4 BILLION IN 2019. THE 5.1 MILLION PEOPLE LIVING IN SC ARE CRUCIAL TO MAINTAINING THE QUALITY OF LIFE AND CONSERVATION OF THE NATURAL BEAUTY IN SC, PARTICULARLY YOUTH, SINCE THEY ARE OUR FUTURE STEWARDS OF THE STATE. THE LIVELIHOOD AND QUALITY OF LIFE FOR SC RESIDENTS IS WHAT DRIVES THE PROGRAMMING AND RESEARCH FOCUSES FOR CLEMSON UNIVERSITY AND SOUTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY (SC STATE). THE PLAN OF WORK REFLECTS RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES TO BENEFIT AGRIBUSINESS, COMMUNITIES, AND CITIZENS OF SC. FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE ADVANCING THE COMPETITIVENESS OF THE AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY,ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, SAFEGUARDING THE FOOD SUPPLY, PRESERVING NATURAL RESOURCES, AND PREPARING THE YOUNGER GENERATIONS TO BECOME PRODUCTIVE CITIZENS. INCREASE THE ADOPTION OF PRACTICES THAT REDUCE NUISANCE AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS THROUGH EDUCATION IN THE AREAS OF CONTROL OF ODORS AND VECTORS, PROTECTION OF WATER QUALITY, NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT, CITING OF FACILITIES, AND ALTERNATIVE WASTE HANDLING PRACTICES WITH AN EMPHASIS ON CONFINED ANIMAL PRODUCTION FACILITIES. 2. EMERGING TOOLS AND PRACTICES TO INCREASE CROP PRODUCTION, DECREASE OPERATING COSTS, AND REDUCE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS FOR SPECIFIC FARM CONDITIONS TO ENSURE FARM PROFITABILITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY.
