RREA PROPOSAL FOR FY 2023 TITLE: LASTING LEGACIES: OUTREACH WITH WOODLAND OWNERS IN OHIO TO FACILITATE STEWARDSHIP, BUILD NETWORKS, AND PROMOTE LEGACY PLANNING NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY FOOD AND AGRICULTURE IS OHIO’S LARGEST INDUSTRY AND CONTRIBUTE MORE THAN $124 BILLION IN ANNUAL ECONOMIC IMPACT. THAT TOTAL INCLUDES MUCH OF THE $26 BILLION GENERATED BY THE FOREST SECTOR AND SOUTHEAST OHIO REPRESENTS 46% OF THE STATE’S FOREST RESOURCES. THE 17-COUNTY SOUTHEAST OHIO FOREST AREA HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS PRIORITY OAK MANAGEMENT BY FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES AND HAS THE STATE’S ONLY NATIONAL FOREST (WAYNE NATIONAL FOREST), 17 STATE FORESTS, AND 34 WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS. HOWEVER, 76% OF THE FORESTED LAND IN THE AREA IS PRIVATELY OWNED BY SMALL-SCALE WOODLAND OWNERS, MAKING EDUCATION AN IMPORTANT PART OF MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. AS PART OF THE APPALACHIAN REGION, THESE COUNTIES ALSO REPRESENT THE HIGHEST PER-CAPITA POVERTY RATE IN THE STATE AND ARE A FOCUS FOR CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION. AS AN 1890 LAND-GRANT INSTITUTION, THE PROGRAMMING PRIORITY IS TO ENGAGE WITH UNDERSERVED AND UNDERREPRESENTED POPULATIONS. THE CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT FUNDS WILL BE FUNDAMENTAL IN PROVIDING FORESTRY PROGRAMMING TO SMALL-SCALE WOODLAND OWNERS IN SOUTHEAST OHIO. THE CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION FOREST OUTREACH COORDINATOR IS IN THE APPALACHIAN REGION TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES AND WORK WITH THE OHIO INTERAGENCY FORESTRY TEAM. THE TEAM CONSISTS OF FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL AGENCIES, INCLUDING EXTENSION, TO PROVIDE UNIFIED OUTREACH TO CONSERVE OAK ECOSYSTEMS. THE OAK DOMINATED FOREST ECOSYSTEMS LARGELY REMAIN INTACT, BUT THEY ARE AT A TIPPING POINT – REGENERATION OF OAK IS ABSENT FROM MANY STANDS AND BEING REPLACED BY SHADE TOLERANT SPECIES SUCH AS RED MAPLE AND TULIP POPLAR. WHITE OAK IS A PARTICULAR ECONOMIC BENEFIT TO THE APPALACHIAN REGION AND FOREST STEWARDSHIP TO PROMOTE FUTURE GROWTH OF THIS SPECIE AND OTHER OAK IS VITAL TO THE LOCAL ECONOMIC FUTURE. FOREST STEWARDSHIP THAT MAINTAINS THE OAK ECOSYSTEM IS THE BASIS FOR CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION PROGRAMMING IN THE REGION. EQUITY FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED POPULATIONS IS A FOCUS FOR CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION, SO PROGRAMS WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR WOMEN WOODLAND OWNERS. THESE PROGRAMS WILL FOCUS ON EMPOWERING WOMEN TO TAKE AN ACTIVE ROLE IN WOODLAND MANAGEMENT. FROM 2006 TO 2013, THE PERCENTAGE OF WOMEN IN THE PLACE OF MAKING PRIMARY DECISIONS FOR FAMILY FOREST OWNERSHIPS DOUBLED. HOWEVER, THIS INCREASE HAS NOT RESULTED IN INCREASED NUMBER OF WOMEN TAKING AN ACTIVE ROLE IN MANAGEMENT. WOMEN TEND TO NOT ATTEND FOREST STEWARDSHIP EDUCATIONAL EVENTS CITING TRADITIONAL LANDOWNER PROGRAMMING AS NOT DIRECTED TO THEM BUT TO THEIR MALE COUNTERPARTS. CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION IS PART OF THE LEADERSHIP TEAM FOR THE SOUTHEAST OHIO CHAPTER OF WOMEN OWNING WOODLANDS, A GROUP FOCUSED ON EMPOWERING WOMEN TO BECOME ACTIVE IN WOODLAND MANAGEMENT THROUGH PEER-LEARNING,NETWORKING, AND PROGRAMMING TO INCREASE SELF-EFFICACY TO ATTAIN EQUITY FOR WOMEN IN MANAGING WOODLANDS. CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION IS ALSO PROVIDING LEADERSHIP IN SOUTHEAST OHIO TO DEVELOP CURRICULUM AND PROGRAMMING FOR FOREST LEGACY PLANNING. AS THE POPULATION OF WOODLAND OWNER AGES, PLANNED TRANSITION OF WOODLAND TO THE NEXT GENERATION OR OWNERS IS CRITICAL TO PROTECTING OAK ECOSYSTEMS THROUGH SUSTAINED FOREST STEWARDSHIP. CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION CURRICULUM AND PROGRAMMING WILL FOCUS ON CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR FAMILIES TO PLAN FOR THE FUTURE AND IDENTIFY CHALLENGES SUCH AS HEIRS’ PROPERTY. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 1. CONDUCT PROGRAMMING FOR SMALL-SCALE WOODLAND OWNERS TO IDENTIFY BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR OAK REGENERATION TO IMPROVE ECONOMIC POTENTIAL FOR MULTIPLE AND WORK IN COOPERATION WITH AGENCIES IN THE FOREST INTERAGENCY TEAM 2. PROVIDE LEADERSHIP AND PROGRAMMING GUIDANCE TO THE SOUTHEAST OHIO CHAPTER OF WOMEN OWNING WOODLANDS TO EMPOWER WOMEN TO TAKE AN ACTIVE ROLE IN WOODLAND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. 3. DEVELOP CURRICULUM AND PROGRAMMING FOR FOREST LEGACY PLANNING TO HELP SMALL WOODLAND OWNERS PASS THEIR LEGACY TO THE NEXT GENERATION WITH SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT AND ADDRESS HEIRS PROPERTY CHALLENGES  METHODOLOGY OBJECTIVE 1: CONDUCT PROGRAMMING FOR SMALL-SCALE WOODLAND OWNERS TO IDENTIFY BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR OAK REGENERATION TO IMPROVE ECONOMIC POTENTIAL FOR MULTIPLE GENERATIONS AND WORK IN COOPERATION WITH AGENCIES IN THE FOREST INTERAGENCY TEAM • PARTICIPATION BY THE FOREST OUTREACH COORDINATOR IN THE MIDDLE MANAGERS COMMITTEE FOR THE FOREST INTERAGENCY TEAM TO PROVIDE LEADERSHIP AND COOPERATION WITH FORESTRY PROGRAMMING IN SOUTHEAST OHIO • PARTICIPATION AND LEADERSHIP WITH DAY IN THE WOODS FORESTRY EXTENSION PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES FIELD DAYS TO PROMOTE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR FOREST STEWARDSHIP. FIELD DAYS ARE HELD IN SOUTHEAST OHIO. • DEVELOPMENT OF A FACT SHEET REGARDING OAK REGENERATION AND BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR FOREST STEWARDSHIP AUTHORED BY FOREST OUTREACH COORDINATOR • SMALL-SCALE WOODLAND OWNER PROGRAMS CONDUCTED BY FOREST OUTREACH COORDINATOR AND CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION REGIONAL EDUCATORS IN SOUTHEAST OHIO. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: • SMALL-SCALE WOODLAND OWNER PROGRAMS WILL GENERATE A 30% INCREASE IN KNOWLEDGE OF SMALL-SCALE WOODLAND OWNER BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR OAK REGENERATION FOR PARTICIPANTS ATTENDING THE PROGRAMS. • ONE FACT SHEET WITH BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO PROMOTE OAK REGENERATION FOR PUBLICATION ON CESTA/1890 LAND GRANT EXTENSION WEBSITE AND TO BE DISTRIBUTED THROUGH PROGRAMMING.  OBJECTIVE 2: PROVIDE LEADERSHIP AND PROGRAMMING GUIDANCE TO THE SOUTHEAST OHIO CHAPTER OF WOMEN OWNING WOODLANDS TO EMPOWER WOMEN TO TAKE AN ACTIVE ROLE IN WOODLAND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. • FOREST OUTREACH COORDINATOR PROVIDES LEADERSHIP TO PLANNING GROUP FOR WOMEN OWNING WOODLANDS TO PROVIDE WORKSHOPS THROUGHOUT THE YEAR • DEVELOP WORKSHOPS TO ADDRESS EQUITY ISSUES FOR WOMEN IN FOREST MANAGEMENT TO EMPOWER THEM TO BE ACTIVE IN MANAGEMENT DECISIONS EXPECTED OUTCOMES: • HOLD AT LEAST 8 PROGRAMS FOR WOMEN OWNING WOODLANDS ADDRESSING ISSUES AND OBSTACLES TO EMPOWER WOMEN • WOMEN PARTICIPATING IN THE CHAPTER WILL INCREASE THEIR SELF-EFFICACY BY 30% TO PROVIDE ACTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THEIR WOODLANDS.  OBJECTIVE 3: DEVELOP CURRICULUM AND PROGRAMMING FOR FOREST LEGACY PLANNING TO HELP SMALL WOODLAND OWNERS PASS THEIR LEGACY TO THE NEXT GENERATION WITH SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT AND ADDRESS HEIRS’ PROPERTY CHALLENGES • DEVELOP CURRICULUM FOR FOREST LEGACY PLANNING TO ADDRESS ISSUES AND CHALLENGES SUCH AS SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT, OAK REGENERATION, AND HEIRS’ PROPERTY • PILOT CURRICULUM WITH SMALL SCALE WOODLAND OWNERS IN SOUTHEAST OHIO EXPECTED OUTCOMES • PRODUCE CURRICULUM FOR FOREST LEGACY PLANNING • HOLD FOUR WORKSHOPS WITH SMALL-SCALE WOODLAND OWNERS AND RECEIVE FEEDBACK ON EFFECTIVENESS OF CURRICULUM • UPDATE CURRICULUM WITH FEEDBACK TO PRODUCE CURRICULUM TO USE THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF OHIO REFERENCES: BUTLER, S. RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT FY 2023 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: DR. ADRIAN ANDREI TITLE: PROFESSOR EMAIL ADDRESS: ANDREIA@LINCOLNU.EDU PHONE NUMBER: 573-681-5451 GOALS FARMERS, EXTENSION SPECIALISTS, AND STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCY PERSONNEL REPORT INCREASED CHALLENGES FACED BY SMALL MISSOURI FARMS, WHERE NON-NATIVE PLANTS SUCH AS BUSH HONEYSUCKLE, RUSSIAN OLIVE, SERICEA LESPEDEZA AND MANY OTHERS ARE INCREASINGLY COMMON AND WIDESPREAD, DAMAGING GRASSLANDS AND FORESTS AND REDUCING THE ECONOMIC VIABILITY OF FARMS. LOSS OF BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY AND PRODUCTIVITY OF FORESTS AND GRASSLANDS ARE UNDESIRABLE, BUT THEY MAY BE PARTICULARLY SO ON ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED SMALL FARMS. THE GOAL OF OUR PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF DISADVANTAGED AND MINORITY FARMERS WHO OWN SMALL FARMS IN CENTRAL AND SOUTHEASTERN MISSOURI BY OFFERING INFORMATION AND TRAINING NEEDED FOR ENHANCING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON FORESTS AND RANGELANDS. WE WILL PROMOTE CONSERVATION OF BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY AND INCREASE ECONOMIC RESILIENCE OF SMALL FARMS BY PROVIDING INFORMATION AND SUPPORT FOR CONTROL AND PREVENTION OF EMERGING NON-NATIVE INVASIVE PLANTS. BECAUSE MOST CENTRAL AND SOUTHEASTERN MISSOURI FARMS ARE RELATIVELY SMALL AND CONSIST OF A MIX OF GRASSLAND, FOREST, AND SOMETIMES CROPLAND, WE PROPOSE AN INTEGRATED APPROACH. WE PROPOSE TO PRODUCE FACT SHEETS, BROCHURES, AND TRAINING WORKSHOPS ON SUBJECTS SUCH AS PRESCRIBED FIRE, TIMBER STAND IMPROVEMENTS, AND ENHANCEMENT OF NATIVE PLANTS FOR GRASSLANDS AND FORESTS, AND CONTROL AND PREVENTION OF INVASIVE PLANTS. WE AIM TO REACH AS MANY FARM OWNERS AS POSSIBLE, DIRECTLY AND INDIRECTLY, THROUGH TRAINING WORKSHOPS AND PUBLICATIONS, RESPECTIVELY. FOR FY 2023, OUR OBJECTIVES ARE TO: 1. INCREASE THE NUMBER OF FARMERS WHO UNDERSTAND AND USE MODERN METHODS FOR PREVENTING OR REDUCING DAMAGE TO FORESTS AND GRASSLANDS CAUSED BY NON-NATIVE INVASIVE PLANTS AND INCREASE THE NUMBER OF ACRES WHERE SUCH METHODS ARE USED; 2. INCREASE THE NUMBER OF FARMERS WHO USE PRESCRIBED FIRE IN GRASSLANDS AND FORESTS TO PROMOTE BIOLOGICAL PRODUCTIVITY AND DIVERSITY AND THE NUMBER OF ACRES IMPROVED BY THIS METHOD; 3. INCREASE THE NUMBER OF FARMERS WHO USE NATIVE PLANTS TO ENHANCE PRODUCTIVITY AND DIVERSITY OF THEIR FORESTS AND GRASSLANDS AND THE NUMBER OF ACRES WHERE SUCH PLANTS ARE SEEDED OR PLANTED; AND 4. EVALUATE THE OUTCOMES AND IMPACT OF OUR PROJECT. PRODUCTS EVENTS: WE PROPOSE TO OFFER TRAINING ON INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF GRASSLANDS AND FOREST, THROUGH USE OF PRESCRIBED FIRE, BIOLOGICAL PEST CONTROL, PLANTING NATIVE PLANTS, ROTATIONAL GRAZING, AND CONTROL OF NON-NATIVE INVASIVE PLANTS. WE WILL ALSO PRODUCE BROCHURES AND FACT SHEETS TO INFORM ABOUT DAMAGING INVASIVE PLANTS. TRAINING WILL BE OFFERED IN COLLABORATION WITH STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCY SPECIALISTS FROM MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION, USDA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION SERVICE, MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, ETC. EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE GOALS OF OUR PROJECT ARE TO ENHANCE BIOLOGICALDIVERSITY ON SMALL FARMS AND TO IMPROVE PRODUCTIVITY AND HEALTH OF FORESTS AND GRASSLANDS BY INCREASING KNOWLEDGE ABOUT DAMAGING INVASIVE SPECIES. OUR OUTCOMES WILL BE: 1. INCREASED NUMBER OF FARMS AND ACRES WHERE ROTATIONAL GRAZING, PRESCRIBED FIRE, TIMBER STAND IMPROVEMENTS, NATIVE PLANTS, AND CONTROL OF INVASIVE SPECIES ARE USED; 2. INCREASED NUMBER OF LANDOWNERS WITH KNOWLEDGE ABOUT MANAGEMENT METHODS THAT LEAD TO CONTROL OF NON-NATIVE INVASIVE PLANTS; 3. INCREASED NUMBER OF LANDOWNERS WHO UNDERSTAND AND APPLY METHODS FOR CONTROLLING DAMAGING FOREST AND GRASSLAND INVASIVE PLANTS. AUDIENCE MISSOURI LANDOWNERS WHO OWN GRASSLANDS, PASTURES, AND FORESTS, INCLUDING UNDERREPRESENTED SMALL FARM OWNERS.

RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM ABSTRACT NEW MEXICO RANGELANDS HAVE EXPERIENCED A VARIETY OF PRECIPITATION LEVELS THROUGHOUT THE STATE. EXTREME DROUGHT IN SOME REGIONS WITH ABOVE AVERAGE PRECIPITATION LEVELS BEING EXPERIENCED IN OTHER REGIONS. THE DIVERSE IMPACTS OF THESE EVENTS HAS LED THE PROGRAMMATIC EFFORTS IN A MANNER THAT ADDRESSES PRODUCERS FACING THESE SITUATIONS. THE PROGRAMMATIC EFFORTS HAVE ENGAGED PRODUCERS IN THE REALM OF MANAGING RANGELAND RESOURCES IN A FORWARD THINKING MANNER, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON THE ABILITY TO REMAIN A SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION UNIT. THE ULTIMATE GOAL FOR EACH PROGRAMMATIC EFFORT IS TO PROVIDE GREATER INSIGHT FOR AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS, LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES AND EDUCATIONAL FACULTY INTO THE IMPACT THAT FORWARD THINKING MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS WILL HAVE ON THE AGGREGATE RANGELAND HEALTH AND RESOURCES FOUND THROUGHOUT NEW MEXICO. THIS GAINED KNOWLEDGE WILL BENEFIT ALL RESOURCE MANAGERS IN A MANNER THAT WILL BROADEN THEIR ABILITIES TO UNDERSTAND, MANAGE, AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT PLANS IN PERIODS OF EXTREME AND SUSTAINED DROUGHT. DETERMINING THE CONTENT AND VIABILITY OF A BROAD ARRAY OF FORAGES ACROSS THE STATE HAS BEEN AN OBJECTIVE AND GOAL OF THE PROGRAMMATIC EFFORTS EMPLOYED. THE ABILITY TO CONVEY THE PROTEIN CONTENT, DIGESTIBLE NUTRIENTS, AND THE AGGREGATE VALUE OF THE PLANT AT DIFFERENT STAGES OF GROWTH IS A VALUABLE TOOL FOR PRODUCERS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS ACROSS NEW MEXICO. EMPLOYING THE APPROPRIATE TIMING FOR THE OPTIMAL USE OF EACH RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM HELD IN THE STATE IS A BENEFICIAL PROCESS FOR LIVESTOCK, WILDLIFE, AND RESOURCE MANAGERS THAT ARE IN PLACE ON THESE LANDSCAPES. THESE PRINCIPLES ARE ESSENTIAL TO THE CONTINUED HEALTH AND MANAGEMENT OF NEW MEXICO RANGELANDS AND FOREST HEALTH ISSUES FACING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS AND RESOURCE MANAGERS ACROSS THE STATE IN TODAY’S VARYING CONDITIONS.

MSU RREA ABSTRACT MISSISSIPPI CONTAINS OVER 19.5 MILLION ACRES OF FOREST LAND, WHICH ACCOUNTS FOR 65% OF THE STATE'S TOTAL LAND AREA, AND 81% OF MISSI SSIPPI'S FOREST LAND IS PRIVATELY OWNED BY NONINDUSTRIAL LANDOWNERS. OVER 80% OF PRIVATE FOREST OWNERSHIP IS IN PARCELS OF 100 ACRES OR LESS. EDUCATING PRIVATE FAMILY FOREST OWNERS ABOUT FOREST MANAGEMENT, HARVESTING, AND MARKETING PRACTICES AND TECHNIQUES IS ESSE NTIAL TO THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THE FOREST RESOURCE. THESE FAMILY FOREST LANDS ARE NOT ALWAYS MANAGED IN A WAY THAT MAXIMIZES PRIVATE AND ASSOCIATED PUBLIC BENEFITS THAT CAN INCLUDE TIMBER PRODUCTS AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES, RECREATION AND WATER QUALITY BENEFITS. MANY FAMILY FOREST OWNERS DO NOT HAVE THE KNOWLEDGE OR SKILLS TO MANAGE FORESTS TO MEET THEIR OWN OBJECTIVES. THE RREA PROGRAM ALLOWS MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION SERVICE TO GIVE SPECIAL ATTENTION TO HELPING FAMILY FOREST OWNERS MANAGE THEIR FORESTLANDS FOR MAXIMUM BENEFIT. THUS, THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECTIS TO INCREASE AND IMPROVE THE LEVELS OF FOREST MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES BEING CONDUCTED ON MISSISSIPPI FORESTLAND SO AS TO ENHANCE ALL THE BENEFITS SOCIETY RECEIVES FROM WELL MANAGED FORESTS. THE CORE GOALS OF THE FORESTRY EXTENSION PROGRAM AS SUPPORTED BY RREA ARE TO INCREASE THE PRODUCTIVITY, EFFECTIVENESS, EFFICIENCY, AND PROFITABILITY OF OUR CLIENTELE, AS WELL AS AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE MANY VALUES OF THEIR FORESTS. NEW RESEARCH AND TECHNOLOGIES ARE DISSEMINATED TO CLIENTELE STATEWIDE THROUGH FORESTRY EXTENSION PROGRAMS AND MATERIALS.

RREA ABSTRACT GEORGIA'S FOREST RESOURCE CREATES A 12.7-BILLION-DOLLAR DIRECT ECONOMIC IMPACT IN THE STATE (ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT INSTITUTE-GA TECH). THERE ARE MILLIONS OF DOLLARS AVAILABLE IN COST-SHARE PROGRAMS FUNDED BY USDA TO ASSIST THESE PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN SUSTAINING THEIR NATURAL RESOURCE OPERATION. SEVERAL RESEARCH STUDIES HAVE DOCUMENTED THAT MINORITY AND LIMITED RESOURCE LANDOWNERS ARE OFTEN NOT AWARE OF FEDERAL AND STATE OPPORTUNITIES TO MAINTAIN AND/OR INCREASE THEIR LAND PRODUCTIVITY. THESE MINORITY FOREST LANDOWNERS IN MOST CASES HAVE NOT RECEIVED ANY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND/OR INFORMATION THAT WILL ASSIST THEM IN THEIR OPERATION OF MAINTAINING AND MANAGING THEIR FORESTLANDS TO MAXIMIZE THEIR OPERATION'S INCOME. TO ENSURE THAT THE NEEDS OF THE LIMITED RESOURCE AND MINORITY LANDOWNERS ARE ADDRESSED, THE FVSU COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM THROUGH THIS PROJECT WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM, USDA RURAL DEVELOPMENT, USDA FOREST SERVICE, AND THE GEORGIA FORESTRY COMMISSION, GEORGIA HEIRS PROPERTY LAW CENTER, AND GEORGIA APPLE SEED, INC. THE OVERALL PURPOSE OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE OUTREACH, AWARENESS AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO MINORITY AND LIMITED RESOURCE FOREST LANDOWNERS ABOUT LAND MANAGEMENT AND ITS VALUE. THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE THE FOLLOWING: • INCREASING OUTREACH, AWARENESS, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO MINORITY LANDOWNERS IN THE AREAS OF SUSTAINABLE NATURAL RESOURCE PRACTICES AND EFFECTIVE ESTATE PLANNING. • ENSURING HEALTHY FOREST ECOSYSTEMS BY PROVIDING TRAININGS TO LANDOWNERS, LAND MANAGERS, AND OTHER NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS ON SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES INCLUDING EFFECTIVE ESTATE PLANNING.

THROUGH THE RENEWABLE RESOURCE EXTENSION ACT FUNDS RECEIVED BY OKLAHOMA STATE UNIVERSITY, OUR EXTENSION SPECIALISTS' GOAL IS TO ENHANCE NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON WORKING LANDSCAPES. SPECIFICALLY, WE CARRY OUT EXTENSION PROGRAMS AIMED AT RESTORING FIRE REGIMES IN THE GREAT PLAINS WHICH INCREASES ENDEMIC WILDLIFE HABITAT, MAINTAINS FORAGE AND TIMBER PRODUCTION, SUPPORTS HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION, AND REDUCES CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE RISK. WE PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE SCIENCE-BASED INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC BOTH DIRECTLY AND THROUGH EXISTING STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCY AND NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATION PERSONNEL THAT HAVE CONTACT WITH LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS. OUR WORK DIRECTLY ADDRESSES FOREST AND RANGELAND STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH, AND FOREST AND RANGELAND WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES RESOURCES. TO CARRY THIS OUT OUR GOAL, WE HAVE ESTABLISHED THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES. 1. DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS RELATED TO WOODY PLANT ENCROACHMENT, PRESCRIBED FIRE ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT FOR RANGELAND, FOREST, AND WILDLIFE STEWARDSHIP CARRIED OUT THROUGH COOPERATIVE EXTENSION, THE GREAT PLAINS FIRE SCIENCE EXCHANGE, PRESCRIBED FIRE COUNCILS, AND OTHER GRANT-FUNDED PROJECTS. 2. CREATE AND FACILITATE PARTNERSHIPS WITH AGENCIES AND NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT GROUPS TO EFFECTIVELY DISSEMINATE KNOWLEDGE AND ASSIST WITH LAND MANAGEMENT THROUGH A TRAIN-THE-TRAINER STRATEGY. THIS APPROACH MAXIMIZES IMPACT AND DIVERSIFIES THE CLIENTELE WE REACH. 3. MEASURE THE OUTPUTS, OUTCOMES, AND IMPACT OF OUR EXTENSION PROGRAMMING AND REPORT IMPACTS TO NIFA. PRODUCTS/OUTPUTS WE PRODUCE AND CARRY OUT INCLUDE: SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS, NEWSLETTERS, GUIDES, FACT SHEETS, VIDEOS, TECHNICAL REPORTS, ON-LINE TRAINING MODULES, FIELD DAYS, WORKSHOPS, DEMONSTRATION SITES, AND WEBSITES. SPECIFIC OUTPUTS PLANNED INCLUDE: THREE SCIENCE-BASED INFOGRAPHIC SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS PER WEEK ACROSS THREE PLATFORMS (FACEBOOK, TWITTER, LNSTAGRAM); WOODY PLANT ENCROACHMENT MANAGEMENT TRAININGS FOR AGENCIES AND LANDOWNERS; NRCS PRESCRIBEDFIRE TRAININGS; DEMONSTRATION SITES FOR PLANT COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE; CREATION OF A NEW FACTSHEET ON CONVERTING INTRODUCED FORAGES TO NATIVE RANGELAND; AND FORMATION OF NEW PRESCRIBED FIRE COOPERATIVES THROUGHOUT THE REGION. OUR INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LANDOWNERS, MANAGERS, LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCY AND NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATION PERSONNEL AS WELL AS THE GENERAL PUBLIC THROUGH OUR TELEVISION SEGMENTS AND SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN. OUR COLLABORATIONS WITH THE NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE, FARM SERVICE AGENCY, OKLAHOMA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE CONSERVATION, OKLAHOMA FORESTRY SERVICE, OKLAHOMA PRESCRIBED BURN ASSOCIATION AND BROAD NETWORK OF EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS HELP US TO AFFECT MANAGEMENT ON ~1.5 MILLION ACRES ACROSS THE STATE WITH THE HELP OF OUR RREA FUNDS.

MUCH OF OREGON IS FORESTLAND AND RANGELAND, AND MUCH OF THIS ACREAGE IS MANAGED BY PRIVATE OWNERS OF NON-INDUSTRIAL OPERATIONS. RREA FUNDS PROVIDED TO OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY (OSU) ARE USED TO SUPPORT EFFORTS OF OSU EXTENSION FACULTY AND STAFF TO ASSIST THESE LANDOWNERS IN THEIR RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, AND TO ASSIST OTHERS IN UNDERSTANDING HOW DECISIONS REGARDING MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RANGELAND RESOURCES INFLUENCE THE ECONOMIC AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THESE LANDS PROVIDE. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO OREGONIANS THAT ASSISTS THEM IN UNDERSTANDING HOW DECISIONS REGARDING MANAGEMENT OF FOREST AND RANGELAND RESOURCES INFLUENCE THE HEALTH, PRODUCTIVITY, AND RESILIENCY OF THESE LANDS. OUR AIM IS TO ENSURE HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS, INCREASE ECONOMIC BENEFITS, BUILD CAPACITY THROUGH ENHANCED CONNECTIONS, AND IN THE LONG TERM ENSURE SUSTAINABLE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON WORKING FORESTS AND RANGELANDS. THIS PROJECT HAS SEVERAL OBJECTIVES. OBJECTIVE ONE IS TO INCREASE AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF OWNERS AND MANAGERS OF PRIVATE NON- INDUSTRIAL FOREST AND RANGELAND OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES SO AS TO ENABLE THEM TO MEET THEIR MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES WHILE ENSURING HEALTHY FOREST AND RANGELANDS. OBJECTIVE TWO IS TO INCREASE AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF HOW LAND USE AND LAND MANAGEMENT DECISIO NS INFLUENCE HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF FISH AND WILDLIFE SPECIES TO ENSURE PRODUCTIVE POPULATIONS AND HIGH LEVELS OF BIODIVERSITY ACROSS ECOSYSTEMS. OBJECTIVE THREE IS TO INCREASE AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF HOW CLIMATE CHANGE IS LIKELY TO INFLUENCE FOREST AND R ANGELAND RESOURCES (E.G., INCREASED SUMMER TEMPERATURES, PROLONGED DROUGHT, WIDESPREAD INSECT AND DISEASE OUTBREAKS, LARGER WILDFIRES), TO FOSTER EFFORTS THAT REDUCE THE THREATS IMPOSED BY THESE CHANGES. TARGET AUDIENCES INCLUDE FOREST AND RANGELAND OWNERS; NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS SUCH AS FORESTERS, FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE BIOLOGISTS, RESTORATION SPECIALISTS, AND RANGELAND MANAGERS; FOREST WORKERS SUCH AS LOGGERS, TREE PLANTERS, FIREFIGHTERS; RANCHERS AND FARMERS; FORMAL AND INFORMAL EDUCATORS; POLICYMAKERS; AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC. EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS SUPPORTED BY RREA FUNDS ARE GUIDED BY NEEDS ASSESSMENTS AND ARE TAILORED TO BEST MEET THE NEEDS OF THE SPECIFIC AUDIENCES AND SITUATIONS THEY ARE INTENDED TO ADDRESS. STANDARDIZED CURRICULUM AND EDUCATIONAL PRODUCTS ARE DEVELOPED AND DELIVERED TO IMPROVE FOREST AND RANGELAND HEALTH, ENSURE HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, REDUCE RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH CHANGING CLIMATE, AND EDUCATE COMMUNITIES AND POLICYMAKERS OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTIONS AND VALUE OF OUR WORKING FOREST AND RANGELAND LANDSCAPES. SOME EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS ARE REPEATED REGULARLY ACROSS YEARS, WHILE OTHERS ARE CONDUCTED ONLY ONCE AND ONLY IN A SINGLE REGION TO MEET ACUTE NEEDS. SOME USE STANDARDIZED CURRICULUM (ADAPTED TO LOCAL AUDIENCES), WHILE OTHERS ARE DESIGNED TO MEET URGENT, IMMEDIATE NEEDS. SOME ARE LED DIRECTLY BY EXTENSION FACULTY OR STAFF, WHILE OTHERS USE A TRAIN-THE-TRAINER APPROACH TO ACHIEVE MORE WIDESPREAD IMPACTS THROUGH NETWORKS OF TRAINED VOLUNTEERS. EDUCATION EFFORTS ENCOMPASS A WIDE VARIETY OF MODALITIES. WRITTEN MATERIALS INCLUDE PUBLICATIONS AND NEWSLETTERS. ONLINE MATERIALS INCLUDE WEBSITES, BLOGS, WEBINARS, VIDEOS, AND PRE-RECORDED LEARNING MODULES. IN-PERSON EVENTS INCLUDE SITE VISITS, FIELD DAYS, TOURS, SEMINARS, WORKSHOPS, AND SHORT-COURSES. OTHER DELIVERY METHODS INCLUDE HYBRID (PARTIALLY ONLINE AND PARTIALLY IN-PERSON) AND PODCASTS. MANY EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS THAT TRADITIONALLY OCCURRED SOLELY IN PERSON WERE ADAPTED TO A FULLY REMOTE FORMAT TO ENSURE HUMAN HEALTH DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND EXPECT TO EVOLVE FURTHER IN THE FUTURE TO BEST MEET THE INTERESTS AND NEEDS OF CLIENTELE. EXTENSION PERSONNEL FROM FORESTRY AND NATURAL RESOURCES, RANGELAND RESOURCES ECOLOGY AND MANAGEMENT, AND FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES RECEIVE BASE PROGRAM SUPPORT THROUGH RREA FUNDING. IN ADDITION, ALLOCATIONS ARE PROVIDED TO SUB-PROJECTS THAT ADDRESS A VARIETY OF STAKEHOLDER NEEDS AND PROMOTE BOTH THE ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF FOREST AND RANGELANDS ACROSS THE STATE. RREA FUNDS ARE LEVERAGED WITH BOTH EXTERNAL GRANT FUNDS AND UNIVERSITY EXTENSION SUPPORT. DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A WIDE VARIETY OF EDUCATIONAL PRODUCTS AND TRAININGS THAT RESULT IN GAINS IN AWARENESS, GAINS IN KNOWLEDGE, INC REASES IN ACREAGE OVER WHICH RECOMMENDED PRACTICES ARE IMPLEMENTED, AND ULTIMATELY IMPROVED ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. ALL EXTENSION FACULTY AND STAFF REPORT ON THE ACTIVITIES PERFORMED AND OUTCOMES ACHIEVED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS.

PROJECT ABSTRACT IOWA'S LANDSCAPE IS RAPIDLY CHANGING. WOODLAND ACRES (APPROXIMATELY 3.0 MILLION ACRES, USFS, FIA) DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE TO THE AGRICULTURAL ECONOMY OF IOWA BY SUPPORTING WOODLOT OWNER'S INCOME THROUGH IMPROVED MANAGEMENT AND DEVELOPING SUSTAINABLE INCOME-GENERATING OPPORTUNITIES WITH FOREST OR WILDLIFE RESOURCES. INDIRECT BENEFITS INCLUDE ECOSYSTEM BENEFITS TO FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS; PROTECTING RESOURCES THAT ARE THREATENED BY INVASIVE SPECIES; ADDRESSING LAND FRAGMENTATION AND PARCELIZATION; IMPROVING LANDSCAPE HYDROLOGY AND WATER QUALITY; AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY THAT CAUSES TREE INJURY AND STRESS TO PLANTS AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS. IOWA'S EXTENSION EDUCATION PROGRAMS ARE RESEARCH-BASED AND STAKEHOLDER-DRIVEN EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS CRITICAL TO ACHIEVING LONG-TERM, SUSTAINABLE, AND RENEWABLE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN IOWA’S FORESTED LANDSCAPES. WE WILL EDUCATE LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS ABOUT SUSTAINABLE WOODLAND MANAGEMENT TO MEET VARIOUS DEMANDS INCLUDING SUSTAINED TIMBER HARVEST, BIOMASS PRODUCTION, WILDLIFE AND FISH HABITAT, RECREATION, AND QUALITY OF LIFE. RENEWABLE RESOURCE HEALTH IS IMPORTANT FOR IOWA RESIDENTS AND LANDOWNERS. EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE A RANGE OF CONFERENCES, SPECIALIZED WORKSHOPS, PUBLICATIONS, WEBINARS AND OTHER MEDIA TO PROVIDE RESEARCH-BASED PROGRAMS. MATERIALS TARGET ENHANCING RENEWABLE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT AND INCLUDE A RANGE OF BASIC PROGRAMS; FROM IDENTIFICATION OF TREE, PLANT, INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, AND BASIC BIOLOGY, TO ADVANCED PROGRAMS. COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAMMING IS ORGANIZED THROUGH THE MASTER WOODLAND MANAGER AND MASTER CONSERVATIONIST PROGRAMS THAT OFFER PARTICIPANTS AN OPPORTUNITY FOR INTENSIVE LEARNING AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. WE WILL PARTNER WITH OTHER EDUCATIONAL AND MANAGEMENT ENTITIES IN THE STATE, INCLUDING THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND LOCAL CONSERVATION BOARDS, NON-PROFITS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS TO PROVIDE A DIVERSITY OF EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES TO MEET A VARIETY OF LEARNING STYLES. LANDOWNERS’ OBJECTIVES CAN INCLUDE RECREATIONAL, TIMBER HARVESTING, PROVIDING WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES HABITAT, WATER QUALITY ENHANCEMENT, AND OTHER CONSERVATION GOALS. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO PROVIDE AN INTEGRATED PROGRAM FOR WOODLAND LANDOWNERS THAT ADDRESS INDIVIDUAL OBJECTIVES AND LARGER SCALE ISSUES INCLUDING INVASIVE SPECIES AND NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP. A VARIETY OF APPROACHES TO MEET EDUCATIONAL NEEDS WILL INCLUDE FACE-TO-FACE WORKSHOPS, PUBLICATIONS, FIELD DAYS, AND SHORT-COURSES. WE WILL MAKE USE OF ELECTRONIC MEANS TO TRAIN LANDOWNERS, INCLUDING UPDATED AND ENHANCED INTERACTIVE WEBSITES, EMAIL, AND MORE FORMAL INVOLVEMENT OF LANDOWNERS. WE WILL CONDUCT EDUCATION TO HELP LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS DETERMINE EXTENT AND IMPACT OF INVASIVE SPECIES AND TRAIN THEM IN APPROPRIATE MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES. INVASIVE PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES CAN DISPLACE NATIVE SPECIES, DISRUPTING A COMPLEX ECOSYSTEM, REDUCING ECONOMIC BENEFIT AND PROFITABILITY BY REPLACING VALUABLE SPECIES, AND REQUIRE COSTLY AND OFTEN LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT. IDENTIFICATION OF DESIRED AND INVASIVE PLANT AND WILDLIFE SPECIES CAN RESULT IN LANDOWNERS' ABILITY TO INVENTORY AND ASSESS THEIR RESOURCES AND TAKE RESPONSIBILITY FOR MANAGEMENT. OUR EDUCATIONAL AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT WORK WILL ENSURE IOWA’S FOREST RESOURCES CONTINUE TO CONFER BENEFITS TO ALL IOWANS THROUGH THE PROVISIONING A WIDE RANGE OF ECOSYSTEM GOODS AND SERVICES.

RREA KSU NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY IN 2020 THE KENTUCKY FOREST SECTOR PROVIDED “AN ESTIMATED $9.55 BILLION IN DIRECT CONTRIBUTION AND A TOTAL ECONOMIC CONTRIBUTION OF $13.97 BILLION” ACCORDING TO THE 2020 KENTUCKY FORESTRY ECONOMIC IMPACT REPORT (AS ESTIMATED BY IMPLAN DATA FOR KENTUCKY AND THE KENTUCKY FOREST PRODUCTS INDUSTRY DIRECTORY). MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT PROMOTE HEALTHY FOREST ECOSYSTEMS FOR KENTUCKY'S SMALL WOODLAND OWNERS ARE CRITICAL TO THE CONTINUED PROTECTION AND UTILIZATION OF KENTUCKY'S FORESTS. COMPLEX ECOSYSTEMS WITH BIOTIC INTERACTIONS AMONG PLANTS, ANIMALS, AND MICROORGANISMS AS WELL AS ABIOTIC, PHYSICAL, AND CHEMICAL INTERACTIONS CAN GREATLY AFFECT THE HEALTH OF FORESTS, WATERSHEDS, AND AGRICULTURAL ECOSYSTEMS. FOREST HEALTH, IN TERMS OF FUNCTION OF RIPARIAN/WETLAND VEGETATION, CAN BE ENHANCED THROUGH SILVICULTURE AND AGROFORESTRY APPROACHES THAT SUPPORT NATIVE PLANT POPULATIONS, REDUCE INVASIVE SPECIES, PROMOTE THE HEALTH OF RIPARIAN ZONES, AND INCREASE WATER QUALITY. ALMOST HALF (48%) OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF KENTUCKY’S LAND IS COVERED IN FOREST. THERE ARE 467,000 SMALL PRIVATE WOODLAND OWNERS. MUCH OF THE STATE’S REMAINING LAND IS OCCUPIED BY 12.9 MILLION ACRES OF FARMLAND, WITH NEARLY 75,000 FARMS, MOST BEING SMALL-SCALE, FAMILY OPERATIONS. WITH SUCH FRAGMENTED OWNERSHIP, ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND ADEQUATE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT CAN BE DIFFICULT TO ACHIEVE. THEREFORE, PROGRAMS THAT HELP LANDOWNERS AND NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS UNDERSTAND AND IMPLEMENT HEALTHY FOREST AND RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE ESSENTIAL FOR THE IMPROVEMENT AND PROTECTION OF KENTUCKY’S LANDS, WATERS, WILDLIFE, AND ECONOMIC RESOURCES. KENTUCKY STATE UNIVERSITY (KSU) WILL PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS, FOREST LANDOWNER AND PROFESSIONAL TRAINING WORKSHOPS, AND PRESENTATIONS FOCUSING ON: RREA GOAL 1: ENSURING HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS 1. INVASIVE SPECIES (KA 213 WEEDS AFFECTING PLANTS) 2. WETLAND RESOURCES (KA 112 WATERSHED PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT) 3. CLIMATE VARIABILITY (KA 132 WEATHER AND CLIMATE) RREA GOAL 2: ENHANCING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON WORKING FORESTS AND RANGELANDS 1. FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH (KA 112 WATERSHED PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT, KA 123 MANAGEMENT AND SUSTAINABILITY OF FOREST RESOURCES, KA 213 WEEDS AFFECTING PLANTS). 2. WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES RESOURCES (KA 112 WATERSHED PROTECTION AND MANAGEMENT, KA 135 AQUATIC AND TERRESTRIAL WILDLIFE, AND KA 136 CONSERVATION OF BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY). RREA GOAL 3: BUILDING CAPACITY THROUGH ENHANCED CONNECTIONS 1. COMMUNICATION, EDUCATION, AND INFORMATION DELIVERY (KA 903 COMMUNICATION, EDUCATION, AND INFORMATION DELIVERY). THIS EXTENSION PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARD A NUMBER OF RREA GOALS USING PROGRAMING THAT PROMOTES HEALTHY FOREST ECOSYSTEMS THROUGH INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT, WETLAND MANAGEMENT, FOREST STEWARDSHIP, WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT, AND ENHANCING CONNECTIONS TO THE NATURAL RESOURCES AND LANDOWNER COMMUNITIES. THE STAFF OF THE CENTER WILL EMPLOY THEIR EXPERTISE AS WELL AS THAT OF OTHER EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS TO PROVIDE IMPACTFUL EXPERIENCES FOR VISITORS SEEKING CONSERVATION INFORMATION AND TRAINING. THESE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO K-16 STUDENTS, EDUCATORS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, LANDOWNERS AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC TO ENCOURAGE THEM TO UNDERSTAND AND ADOPT CONSERVATION PRACTICES AND TO ENGAGE IN CONSERVATION. THE FIELD-BASED, HANDS-ON NATURE OF THE PROGRAMMING PROVIDED BY THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO EMPOWER INDIVIDUALS WITH THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO POSITIVELY IMPACT THE MILLIONS OF ACRES OF THE COMMONWEALTH THAT IS CURRENTLY FORESTED. THE OVERALL EXPECTATION IS THAT KSU AFFECTS THE CONSERVATION AWARENESS, KNOWLEDGE, AND FUTURE BEHAVIORS OF AT LEAST 80% OF PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS. ADDITIONALLY, AT LEAST 55 ACRES OF LAND PER YEAR WILL BE POSITIVELY IMPACTED THROUGH PROGRAMS AND PRESENTATIONS RELATED TO THIS INITIATIVE. PROJECT INFORMATION METHODOLOGY THE KSU ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND RESEARCH CENTER (EERC) IS ON 307 ACRES OF LAND, APPROXIMATELY 15 MILES NORTH OF THE KSU CAMPUS IN HENRY COUNTY, KENTUCKY. THE EERC IS LOCATED AT THE WESTERN END OF THE APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN REGION, LARGELY DOMINATED BY HARDWOOD FOREST TREES WELL ADAPTED TO HILLY TERRAIN. MANY STREAMS AND CREEKS THAT DRAIN MULTIPLE RURAL AREAS CAN BE FOUND IN THESE FORESTED ACRES AND ARE PART OF THE KENTUCKY RIVER WATERSHED. THE EERC HAS A 1.25-ACRE POND, 6.5 MILES OF WALKING TRAILS, AND SITES THAT ARE USED FOR TEACHING PURPOSES AND FOR CONDUCTING RESEARCH PROJECTS IN A WIDE VARIETY OF DISCIPLINES INCLUDING AQUATIC SCIENCES, FORESTRY, BIOLOGY, AND SCIENCE EDUCATION. MANY KSU UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS CONDUCT A WIDE VARIETY OF APPLIED RESEARCH AND PARTICIPATE IN CLASSES HOSTED BY THE EERC, MAKING THIS CENTER A HIGH PRIORITY FOR FACILITY IMPROVEMENT AND LONG-TERM COMMITMENT. THE EERC IS MANAGED WITH DEMONSTRABLE ENVIRONMENTALLY-SOUND STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES AND PROVIDES A UNIQUE PERSPECTIVE ON LAND USE AND IMPACTS ON WATER QUALITY. KSU WILL ACCOMPLISH THE PROJECT GOALS USING THE EERC AS THE PLATFORM FOR THIS PROJECT. THE EERC WILL FACILITATE K-16 AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT LEARNING WITH ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND PRESENTATIONS. ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION THAT PROVIDES HANDS-ON LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES IN THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT PROVIDES STUDENTS OF ALL AGES THE TOOLS TO DEVELOP BONDS WITH THE ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH THEY LIVE WHILE REINFORCING THE BONDS AMONG COMMUNITIES WHICH THEY CALL HOME. IT IS A PLACE FOR LEARNERS OF ALL BACKGROUNDS TO GAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE ENVIRONMENT AND WHAT CAN BE DONE TO IMPROVE AND MAINTAIN IT. THESE EVENTS WILL PREDOMINANTLY INCORPORATE EXPERIENTIAL, FIELD-BASED TRAINING AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION TOPICS DESIGNED FOR LANDOWNERS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, EDUCATORS, STUDENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WITH INTEREST IN THESE TOPICS. PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WHO ARE NOT LANDOWNERS WILL BE INTRODUCED TO COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES TO ENGAGE IN COMMUNITY CLEANUPS, PLANTINGS, AND INVASIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT. KSU WILL HOST MONTHLY NATURE HIKES AT THE EERC (MAR-NOV, WEATHER PERMITTING) FOCUSING ON NATIVE FLORA. SEASONAL PUBLIC EDUCATIONAL EVENTS WILL BE HOSTED FOCUSING ON OTHER ASPECTS OF NATIVE ECOLOGY. KSU WILL IMPLEMENT UP TO FOUR PROGRAMS OR FIELD DAYS PER YEAR AT THE EERC THAT INCLUDE EDUCATION ON CLIMATE VARIABILITY AND MITIGATION STRATEGIES FOR STUDENTS AND LANDOWNERS. KSU WILL ALSO CONDUCT ONE TRAINING SPECIFICALLY DESIGNED FOR NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS ON HOW TO TEACH ABOUT CLIMATE VARIABILITY, PROJECTED IMPACTS, AND ADAPTATION STRATEGIES. KSU WILL PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS FOR FOREST LANDOWNERS THROUGH PROFESSIONAL TRAINING WORKSHOPS, AND PRESENTATIONS. ADDITIONALLY, UP TO SIX TRAINING WORKSHOPS OR FIELD DAYS WILL FOCUS ON THE IMPLEMENTATION AND UNDERSTANDING OF HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. KSU INTENDS TO REACH A MINIMUM OF 100 STUDENTS, CITIZENS, NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS, AND FOREST LANDOWNERS. KSU WILL ALSO HOST A COMMUNITY DELIBERATION AND DIALOGUE SESSION FOCUSING ON WATER STEWARDSHIP IN THE COMMONWEALTH. THE CONFERENCE CENTER AT THE KSU HAROLD R. BENSON RESEARCH AND DEMONSTRATION FARM WILL BE USED TO DELIVER UP TO TWO PROGRAMS PER YEAR ON CONTENT AND ACTIVITIES OCCURRING AT THE EERC. TO MEASURE PROGRESS TOWARD THE ACHIEVEMENT OF GOALS AND OBJECTIVES, PROGRAM AND PRESENTATION PARTICIPANTS ARE ASKED TO COMPLETE EVALUATION FORMS. THE FORMS COLLECT DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION, EVALUATE THE FACILITY AND THE PROGRAMMING OFFERED, AS WELL AS TRACK SHORT-TERM KNOWLEDGE AND BEHAVIORAL AND LIFE STYLE CHANGES RESULTING FROM THE PROGRAMS.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY OVERVIEW K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION (KSRE) IS A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF EDUCATORS SHARING UNBIASED, RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION AND EXPERTISE ON ISSUES IMPORTANT TO KANSANS. THE KSRE NETWORK INCLUDES OFFICES IN ALL 105 COUNTIES, ALONG WITH FOUR REGIONAL EXTENSION OFFICES, FIVE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH CENTERS DISTRIBUTED THROUGHOUT THE STATE TO ENCOMPASS VARIABILITY IN CLIMATE AND SOILS, FOUR SATELLITE UNITS, FOUR AGRONOMY EXPERIMENT FIELDS AND FOUR HORTICULTURE CENTERS AND EXPERIMENT FIELDS. IN ADDITION, KSRE FUNDS RESEARCH PROJECTS IN 20 DEPARTMENTS ACROSS FIVE COLLEGES. A UNIQUE FEATURE WITHIN THE K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ORGANIZATION IS THE CLOSE ALIGNMENT OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION. IN 1996, K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WAS FORMED BY ALIGNING THE KANSAS AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (KAES) AND THE KANSAS COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE. THE STRATEGIC INTENT OF THIS ALIGNMENT WAS TO ACHIEVE GREATER EFFICIENCY AND SYNERGY BETWEEN DISCOVERY AND OUTREACH EFFORTS. ONE ANCILLARY BENEFIT OF THIS ALIGNMENT IS THAT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH WILL LEAD TO RAPID EXTENSION PROGRAMMING AND APPLICATION IN THE FIELD. THIS ALIGNMENT ALSO ALLOWS MORE FLUID COMPLIANCE WITH MULTI-STATE AND INTEGRATED COMPONENTS OF AREERA. K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION IS FOCUSING ITS EFFORTS ON FIVE GRAND CHALLENGES (CRITICAL ISSUES) THAT DIRECTLY OR INDIRECTLY AFFECT ALL KANSANS: GLOBAL FOOD SYSTEMS, WATER AND NATURAL RESOURCES, HEALTH, DEVELOPING TOMORROW'S LEADERS, AND COMMUNITY VITALITY. THESE GRAND CHALLENGES WERE DETERMINED THROUGH A SERIES OF MEETINGS WITH STAKEHOLDERS AND DEFINE AREAS OF EMPHASIS FOR AGENTS, SPECIALISTS, AND RESEARCHERS. EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS AT THE LOCAL, REGIONAL AND STATE LEVEL WORK TO DEVELOP REGIONAL AND STATEWIDE SIGNATURE PROGRAMS ALONG WITH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR ITS MEMBERS THROUGH 11 PROGRAM FOCUS TEAMS – ADULT DEVELOPMENT AND AGING; COMMUNITY VITALITY; CROP PRODUCTION; FAMILY AND CHILD DEVELOPMENT; FAMILY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT; FARM MANAGEMENT; HORTICULTURE; LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION; NATURAL RESOURCES; NUTRITION, FOOD SAFETY AND HEALTH; AND YOUTH DEVELOPMENT. IN ADDITION, TWO TRANSDISCIPLINARY TEAMS WERE CREATED TO ADDRESS COMPLEX ISSUES TO KANSANS - LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS AND STRESS AND RESILIENCY. THE WORK OF THESE TEAMS FALLS WITHIN THE OVERALL UMBRELLA OF THE FIVE GRAND CHALLENGES. K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CANNOT SOLVE THESE CHALLENGES ALONE. KSRE'S STATEWIDE PRESENCE LENDS ITSELF TO COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS WITH ORGANIZATIONS, PRIVATE BUSINESS AND INDUSTRY, LOCAL GROUPS, STATE AND FEDERAL ORGANIZATIONS, AND COLLEAGUES IN OTHER STATES. QUALITY FACULTY DRAW BUSINESSES AND FUNDING TO K-STATE AND TO KANSAS INCLUDING: - K-STATE IS THE ONLY UNIVERSITY IN THE WORLD WITH ACCESS TO A FULL CONTINUUM OF BIOSECURITY LABORATORIES LOCATED ON OR ADJACENT TO CAMPUS. THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE WILL PROVIDE PLANT DISEASE DIAGNOSTICS, RESEARCH, SURVEILLANCE, AND TRAINING IN DISEASE VECTOR BIOLOGY. THE LABORATORIES WILL OFFER EMERGENCY RAPID TESTING AND MANUFACTURING TO PROTECT THE NATION'S ANIMAL HEALTH AND FOOD SUPPLY DURING A CRISIS. - KANSAS PRIDE IS DEDICATED TO SERVING COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE TO ENCOURAGE AND ASSIST LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND VOLUNTEERS IN MAKING THEIR COMMUNITY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE AND WORK. THE KANSAS PRIDE PROGRAM IS A PARTNERSHIP OF K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION, THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE, KANSAS MASONS AND KANSAS PRIDE, INC. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, LOCAL COMMUNITIES IDENTIFY WHAT THEY WOULD LIKE TO PRESERVE, CREATE, OR IMPROVE FOR THEIR FUTURE. THEN, WORKING WITH THE RESOURCES OF K-STATE RESEARCH <(>&<)> EXTENSION AND THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE, COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS PULL TOGETHER TO CREATE THEIR IDEAL COMMUNITY FUTURE. - EXTENSION’S RESEARCH CENTERS, EXPERIMENT FIELDS AND HIGHLY SKILLED SCIENTISTS AND STAFF, COMBINED WITH THE CLIMATE AND SOIL VARIABILITY ACROSS THE STATE, PROVIDE UNIQUE OPPORTUNITIES FOR AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND CORPORATE AND PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS. - FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES IS A PARTNER OF THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT FOR AGING AND DISABILITY SERVICES TO PROVIDE HEALTH INSURANCE EDUCATION TO MEDICARE ELIGIBLE KANSANS. APPROXIMATELY 1/3 OF THE CONTACTS OF THOSE SERVED ARE VULNERABLE BENEFICIARIES WITH INCOMES BELOW 150% OF THE POVERTY LEVEL. - KANSAS 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT WAS AWARDED A CONTRACT BY THE KANSAS DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION FOR $4.2 MILLION OVER THE NEXT THREE SUMMERS TO PROVIDE HANDS-ON, PROJECT-BASED 4-H SUMMER PROGRAMMING OPPORTUNITIES TO ADDRESS COVID-19-RELATED LEARNING LOSS IN COUNTIES ACROSS THE STATE. BUILDING UPON THE LONG RECORD OF SUCCESSFUL PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND LEVERAGING THE STATE'S LARGEST YOUTH DEVELOPMENT NETWORK REACHING ALL 105 COUNTIES, KANSAS 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT WILL USE SUMMER ENRICHMENT PROGRAMS TO ADDRESS THE ACADEMIC, SOCIAL, EMOTIONAL AND MENTAL HEALTH NEEDS OF YOUTH AS A PART OF THE AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN — ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOL EMERGENCY RELIEF PLAN. - K-STATE - IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FOUR OTHER UNIVERSITIES AND SEVERAL INDUSTRY PARTNERS HAVE JOINED EFFORTS TO CREATE THE IRRIGATION I NNOVATION CONSORTIUM, A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH EFFORT TO ACCELERATE THE DEVELOPMENT AND ADOPTION OF EFFICIENT IRRIGATION TECHNOLOGIES AND PRACTICES. - K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION WILL ADDRESS THE HEALTH OF KANSANS THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATIONAL COOPERATIVE EXTENSION’S FRAMEWORK FOR HEALTH EQUITY AND WELL-BEING WHICH INCLUDES A FOCUS ON HEALTH EQUITY, SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND COALITIONS AND COMMUNITY HEALTH ASSETS. THE DEMOGRAPHICS OF KANSAS CONTINUE TO CHANGE. KSRE IS REACHING OUT TO BOTH UNDERSERVED AND TRADITIONAL AUDIENCES THROUGH NEW VENUES. TO INCREASE MULTICULTURAL COMPETENCY AND SENSITIVITY AMONG OUR WORKFORCE, K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION AND THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE/KSRE DIVERSITY PROGRAMS OFFICE PROVIDES REGULAR NAVIGATING DIFFERENCE TRAINING FOR NEW EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO BRING SYSTEMIC CHANGE AND DIVERSITY TO THE KSRE TEAM AND PROVIDE CULTURAL COMPETENCY AWARENESS AND SKILLS THAT THEY CAN PRACTICALLY APPLY IN THEIR DAY-TO-DAY WORK. OTHER EFFORTS INCLUDE: - THE MULTICULTURAL UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE SUMMER RESEARCH FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM TARGETS UNDER-REPRESENTED POPULATIONS OF STUDENTS WITH THE GOAL TO ESTABLISH NETWORKING RELATIONSHIPS BACK TO THEIR RESPECTIVE HOME INSTITUTIONS, AS WELL AS K-STATE FACULTY. THIS PROGRAM HAS A SPECIFIC GOAL OF GROWING THE MINORITY POPULATIONS OF STUDENTS WITHIN GRADUATE PROGRAMS IN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND ACROSS OTHER PARTNER COLLEGES REPRESENTED WITHIN K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION. - LOCAL UNIT EXTENSION COUNCIL MEMBERS REVIEW PARITY STATISTICS ANNUALLY AND SPEND TIME DETERMINING STRATEGIC EFFORTS NECESSARY TO REACH UNDERSERVED AND AT-RISK AUDIENCES. - K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION IS IN THE PROCESS OF DEVELOPING A LANGUAGE ACCESS PLAN AND SECURING SERVICES THROUGH LANGUAGE LINE SERVICES TO BRING GREATER ACCESS TO LIMITED ENGLISH PROFICIENT AUDIENCES. - THIS FALL, A NEW COMMUNITY LIAISON WILL BE ON STAFF TO HELP LINK KSRE’S RESOURCES TO THE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES IN NORTHEAST KANSAS. GLOBAL FOOD SYSTEMS AS THE STATE'S LARGEST EMPLOYER, AGRICULTURE DRIVES THE KANSAS ECONOMY. IN 2020, THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY CONTRIBUTED $70.3 BILLION TO THE KANSAS ECONOMY. AGRICULTURE IS THE LARGEST EMPLOYER IN THE STATE, WITH 250,058 PEOPLE ACCOUNTING FOR 13 PERCENT OF THE ENTIRE WORKFORCE. WE ARE IMPROVING FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS TO FEED THE WORLD'S GROWING POPULATION, WHICH WILL ECONOMICALLY BENEFIT KANSAS. TO FEED AND SUSTAIN A GROWING POPULATION, K-STATE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION IS FOCUSED ON DEVELOPING INNOVATIVE PRACTICES TO HELP FARMERS, RANCHERS, AND AGRIBUSINESSES IMPROVE PROFITABILITY, EFFICIENCY AND SUSTAINABILITY FOR KANSAS, OUR NATION, AND THE WORLD THROUGH CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH IN AREAS SUCH AS GENETICS, DISEASE PREVENTION, FOOD SECURITY AND FARM BILL EDUCATION. PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • DEVELOPING AND TESTING NEW CROP, VEGETABLE, AND TREE VARIETIES SUITED TO THE KANSAS CLIMATE. • IMPROVING THE EFFICIENCY OF FEED AND WATER USE, REPRODUCTION AND ANIMAL HEALTH. • REDUCING FOOD WASTE CAUSED BY INSECTS, POOR STORAGE, AND PROCESSING TECHNIQUES. • CREATING SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS THAT INTENSIFY PRODUCTIVITY. • IDENTIFYING WAYS TO MAINTAIN CATTLE RANGELAND THREATENED BY VARIATIONS IN CLIMATE. • LEADING NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL TEAMS TO SOLVE GLOBAL FOOD ISSUES. • HELPING FAMILIES STRETCH THEIR FOOD DOLLARS. WATER AND NATURAL RESOURCES WATER QUALITY IN CENTRAL AND EASTERN KANSAS AND WATER QUANTITY IN WESTERN KANSAS ARE IMPORTANT ISSUES. CURRENT IRRIGATION TRENDS COULD DEPLETE 69 PERCENT OF THE GROUNDWATER IN THE OGALLALA AQUIFER WITHIN 50 YEARS, DRASTICALLY AFFECTING THE KANSAS ECONOMY. SEDIMENT AND SILT ARE WASHING INTO LARGE RESERVOIRS THAT SUPPLY DRINKING WATER AND RECREATION TO MANY KANSANS. TO ENSURE FUTURE GENERATIONS HAVE A RELIABLE SOURCE OF CLEAN WATER, OUR FOCUS WILL BE TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROGRAMS TO HELP KANSANS MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY. THESE INCLUDE PIONEERING NEW PRACTICES AND TECHNIQUES; RESEARCHING HIGH-PRIORITY WATER ISSUES; FACILITATING MEETINGS AMONG LOCAL, STATE, AND FEDERAL OFFICIALS AND EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATING RESEARCH RESULTS. PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • BREEDING NEW DROUGHT-TOLERANT CROP VARIETIES THAT CAN BE USED FOR HUMAN AND PET FOOD, LIVESTOCK FEED, AND FUEL. • IDENTIFYING BEST-ADAPTED TURF SPECIES AND CULTIVARS FOR KANSAS. • DEVELOPING MORE EFFICIENT IRRIGATION AND WATER MONITORING SYSTEMS FOR HOME AND FARM USE. • REDUCING RUNOFF AND SEDIMENTATION INTO RESERVOIRS. • IMPROVING LIVESTOCK GENETICS TO INCREASE FEEDING EFFICIENCY, WHICH REDUCES FEED AND WATER NEEDS. • WORKING WITH THE STATE OF KANSAS AND PARTNERING WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES IDENTIFIED IN THE 50- YEAR VISION FOR THE FUTURE OF WATER PLAN. • BALANCING THE USE AND PROTECTION OF THE STATE’S NATURAL AND RECREATIONAL RESOURCES THAT LEAD TO SIGNIFICANT ECOLOGICAL, MEDICAL, E CONOMIC AND CULTURAL BENEFITS. HEALTH THIRTY-FIVE PERCENT OF KANSAS ADULTS ARE OBESE, AND 16.7 PERCENT OF KANSAS CHILDREN LIVE IN POVERTY. TARGETING THE DIVERSITY OF KANSANS, OUR PROGRAMS ADDRESS QUALITY OF LIFE, HEALTHY DEVELOPMENT, AND HEALTHY BEHAVIORS ACROSS LIFE STAGES FOR ALL SOCIOECONOMIC GROUPS. PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • IDENTIFYING AND IMPLEMENTING PRACTICES TO HELP PREVENT ADULT AND CHILDHOOD OBESITY • PROVIDING OPTIONS TO HELP FAMILIES AND PRACTITIONERS UNDERSTAND HEALTH-CARE CHOICES FOR ELDERLY KANSANS. • EDUCATING CONSUMERS ON SAFE FOOD HANDLING WITH FOOD PREPARATION, FOOD PRESERVATION, FOOD SERVICE AND MORE. COMMUNITY VITALITY RURAL, SUBURBAN, AND URBAN COMMUNITIES THROUGH KANSAS FACE MANY CHALLENGES. WHEN CITIZENS ARE ENCOURAGED TO COMBINE THEIR EXPERIENCES AND SKILLS TO WORK TOGETHER, EVERYONE IN THE COMMUNITY BENEFITS. PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • HELPING COMMUNITIES OF ALL SIZES MAINTAIN NECESSARY SERVICES, SUCH AS GROCERY STORES, THAT HIRE LOCALLY AND GENERATE LOCAL SALES TAX. • WORKING DIRECTLY WITH FARMERS, RANCHERS, AND FAMILIES TO DEVELOP BETTER FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. • ENGAGING COMMUNITY GROUPS AND LOCAL BUSINESSES BY PROVIDING LEADERSHIP, RESEARCH-BASED EXPERTISE AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO MAKE COMMUNITIES BETTER PLACES TO LIVE AND WORK. • ADVANCING THE HEALTH AND WELFARE OF COMPANION ANIMALS • ASSISTING COMMUNITIES, ALONG WITH NEW AND EXISTING BUSINESS, BY COORDINATING SUPPORT AND TRAINING EFFORTS, CREATING SUPPORT NETWORKS AND INCREASING ACCESS TO UNIVERSITY RESOURCES. DEVELOPING TOMORROW'S LEADERS THE COMPLEX GLOBAL SOCIETY OF THE FUTURE WILL REQUIRE LEADERS WITH EFFECTIVE TEAMWORK AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS. WE NEED TO PREPARE LEADERS OF ALL AGES, SO THEY MAY CONTRIBUTE TO A VIBRANT KANSAS ECONOMY FOR YEARS TO COME. PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WOULD INCLUDE: • BUILDING OUTSTANDING LEADERS WITH MARKETABLE SKILLS TO SUCCEED IN TODAY’S GLOBAL SOCIETY AND WORKPLACE. 4-H MEMBERS ARE TWICE AS LIKELY TO ATTEND COLLEGE AND PURSUE CAREERS IN SCIENCE, ENGINEERING AND COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY. • MEETING THE NEEDS OF MILITARY YOUTH AND THEIR FAMILIES AT KANSAS MILITARY INSTALLATIONS AND FAMILIES OF DEPLOYED MEMBERS OF THE NATIONAL GUARD AND ARMY RESERVE • TRAINING KANSANS OF ALL AGES TO BE BETTER CITIZENS AND LEADERS.

PURPOSE THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES AT PENN STATE WILL PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE SUPPORT TO PENNSYLVANIA RESIDENTS THROUGH THE PENNSYLVANIA AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION (AES) AND PENN STATE EXTENSION (PSE) ACTIVITIES. WE WILL BE RESPONSIVE TO STAKEHOLDER NEEDS THROUGH TRANSLATIONAL RESEARCH AND DELIVERY OF SCIENCE‐BASED PROGRAMS TO CLIENTELE. WE WILL ALSO CONDUCT INTERNATIONALLY RELEVANT FUNDAMENTAL RESEARCH THAT GENERATES BASELINE DATA TO SOLVE FUTURE PROBLEMS AND ACTIVELY SEEK NEW AND BETTER WAYS TO COMMUNICATE OUR PROGRAMS TO NEW AUDIENCES. OUR FACULTY AND STAFF, SUPPORTED BY FEDERAL BASE FUNDING, WILL EFFECTIVELY LEVERAGE THIS INVESTMENT AGAINST MANY OTHER FUNDING SOURCES TO CONDUCT PROGRAMS OF THE HIGHEST CALIBER. WE ARE COMMITTED TO EXCELLENCE IN RESEARCH, EDUCATING THE NEXT GENERATION OF AGRICULTURAL PROFESSIONALS AND CITIZENS, AND PROMOTING LIFE‐LONG LEARNING AMONG THE CITIZENS OF PENNSYLVANIA. OUR COLLEGE'S MISSION IS CLEAR: "THE MISSION OF THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES IS TO DISCOVER, INTEGRATE, TRANSLATE, AND DISSEMINATE KNOWLEDGE TO ENHANCE THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM, NATURAL RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, AND ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL WELL‐BEING, THEREBY IMPROVING THE LIVES OF PEOPLE IN PENNSYLVANIA, THE NATION, AND THE WORLD." AGRICULTURE FACES CHALLENGES OF RISING ENERGY COSTS, WEATHER EXTREMES, AN EXPANDING HUMAN POPULATION, ENVIRONMENTAL DEGRADATION, LOSS OF BIODIVERSITY, AND LABOR SHORTAGES. THE COVID‐19 PANDEMIC ADDED TO THE CHALLENGES: DISRUPTIONS TO FOOD CHAINS, WORKFORCE CHALLENGES, IMPACTS ON YOUTH EDUCATION, AND BUSINESS INTERRUPTIONS. WE MUST ADDRESS THESE ISSUES TO MITIGATE FUTURE WIDESPREAD DISRUPTIONS THAT IMPACT ALL OF SOCIETY. ACTIVITIES TO HELP MEET THESE CHALLENGES, WE ARE DEVELOPING A CONCEPTUAL FRAMEWORK BASED ON THE SCIENCE OF AGRICULTURAL SUSTAINABILITY‐‐DEFINED AS THE INTEGRATION OF NATURAL AND SOCIAL SCIENCES TO INFORM PRACTICE AND POLICY FOR PRODUCTIVE, WORKING LANDSCAPES, HEALTHY WATERSHEDS, AND RESILIENT ECONOMIES. THIS INNOVATIVE APPROACH TO AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH, ENGAGEMENT, AND EDUCATION CENTERS ON THE IMPACTS AND SYNERGIES OF CONTIGUOUS RURAL AND URBAN LANDSCAPES. PENN STATE EXTENSION PROVIDES ACCESS TO FACE‐TO‐FACE AND ONLINE SCIENCE‐BASED EDUCATION TO OUR CUSTOMERS TO HELP THEM ADDRESS PROBLEMS AND TAKE ADVANTAGE OF OPPORTUNITIES FOR IMPROVEMENT AND INNOVATION. WE MAKE A DIFFERENCE LOCALLY THROUGH FOCUSED ENGAGEMENT AND, MORE WIDELY, TO CUSTOMERS CONNECTING IN THE DIGITAL LANDSCAPE. INITIATIVES ENSURE THE STABILITY OF THE FOOD SYSTEM IN THE COMMONWEALTH AND OUR EFFORTS TO PROVIDE A BROAD‐BASED ONLINE LEARNING PLATFORM FOR NONCREDIT PROGRAMMING AND DIGITAL EDUCATION. THE WORK OF AES AND PSE IN OUR COLLEGE IS BUILT ON THE THREE INTEGRATED PILLARS OF INTENSIFICATION, RESILIENCE, AND REGENERATION OF AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPES AS SOLUTIONS TO SOME OF THE MOST VEXING PROBLEMS CONFRONTING PENNSYLVANIA AND SIMILAR MOSAIC LANDSCAPES WORLDWIDE. OUR CRITICAL ISSUES CAPTURE THE SYSTEMS APPROACH WE IDENTIFIED AS ESSENTIAL FOR GENERATING IMPACT. THEY CUT ACROSS DISCIPLINES, UNITING OUR RESEARCH EFFORTS WITH OUR EXTENSION EDUCATION CAPACITY. THIS INTERDISCIPLINARY PHILOSOPHY HAS REINFORCED THE NATURAL TENDENCY OF OUR FACULTY AND EXTENSION EDUCATORS TO WORK COOPERATIVELY TO SOLVE PROBLEMS. COUPLED WITH THE JOINT RESEARCH‐EXTENSION APPOINTMENTS OF MANY OF OUR COLLEGE FACULTY, OUR WORK, AS REPRESENTED IN OUR PLAN OF WORK, WILL EFFECTIVELY UNITE FUNDAMENTAL KNOWLEDGE WITH PRACTICAL SOLUTIONS DELIVERED TO STAKEHOLDERS, EMPOWERING THEM TO ADDRESS IMPORTANT AND EMERGING ISSUES USING RELEVANT SCIENCE‐BASED RESOURCES. THE NET RESULT WILL BE A TANGIBLE BENEFIT IN ECONOMIC PROSPERITY AND QUALITY OF LIFE FOR PENNSYLVANIA CITIZENS.

PROJECT SUMMARY RENEWABLE RESOURCE EXTENSION ACT URBAN FORESTRY EXTENSION PROVIDES VALUABLE, EXPERT INFORMATION ON TREE AND URBAN LANDSCAPE CARE AND MAINTENANCE FOR PRIVATE CITIZENS, MUNICIPALITIES, AND INDUSTRY. NORTHWEST FLORIDAS URBAN FORESTS IS ONE OF ITS GREATEST ASSETS AND THE CITIZENS HOLD THEM IN HIGH REGARD. TREES PROVIDE MUCH TO ITS CITIZENS INCLUDING ENERGY CONSERVATION, IMPROVED AIR QUALITY, STORM WATER RETENTION, WILDLIFE HABITAT, AESTHETICS, REAL ESTATE VALUE AND A SINCE OF COMMUNITY. TREES CAN ALSO HELP REDUCE WIND DAMAGE DURING STORMS AND UNFORTUNATELY CAN CAUSE DAMAGE IF THEY FALL ON PROPERTY. IT IS THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM TO HELP PEOPLE GET THE GREATEST BENEFIT AND THE LEAST LIABILITY FROM THIS TREE RESOURCE. ADDITIONALLY, AND AS A SECOND GOAL, PROPER LANDSCAPE TRAINING CAN HELP THE PUBLIC TO DEVELOP A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THEIR LANDSCAPING OPTIONS IN ORDER TO UTILIZE THE BEST QUALITY OF MATERIALS, PROPER INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE TECHNIQUES TO ASSURE HEALTHIER PLANTS, AND TO HELP THEM DETERMINE WHAT THE RIGHT PLANT IN THE RIGHT PLACE MEANS. THE GREEN INDUSTRY  BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ARE A SCIENCEBASED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS THAT TEACH ENVIRONMENTALLY SAFE TREE MANAGEMENT AND LANDSCAPING PRACTICES THAT HELP CONSERVE AND PROTECT FLORIDAS GROUND AND SURFACE WATERS. THEY CAN ALSO SAVE THE FLORIDA HOMEOWNER MONEY, TIME, AND EFFORT; INCREASE THE BEAUTY OF THE HOME LANDSCAPE; AND PROTECT THE HEALTH OF YOUR FAMILY, PETS, AND THE ENVIRONMENT. FAMUS RREA FIVEYEAR PLAN WILL LOOK AT EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE HOMEOWNERS, CORPORATE, GOVERNMENTAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL PERSONNEL THE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR TREES AND LANDSCAPE.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY 8,000 CHARACTERS CUCE RREA PLAN OF WORK 2022-2024 SUSTAINING THE PRODUCTIVITY OF NY'S PRIVATE WOODLANDS RREA AT CORNELL HAS SUFFICIENT STAFF AND RESOURCES TO FOCUS ON THREE PRIMARY ISSUES: FOREST MANAGEMENT FOR DIVERSE OUTPUTS, WILDLIFE RESOURCES, AND FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY PARTICULARLY AS RELATES TO AGROFORESTRY ENTERPRISES OF FOREST FARMING AND SILVOPASTURE. NEW YORK IS APPROXIMATELY 63 PERCENT FORESTED AND HALF OF THE STATE IS IN PRIVATE WOODLAND OWNERSHIP. THE AVERAGE PARCEL SIZE IS LESS THAN 30 ACRES, AND THE MAJORITY OF ACREAGE IS LESS THAN 50 ACRES. THE CONSERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES DEPENDS ON MANY WOODLAND OWNERS MAKING INFORMED DECISIONS THAT SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE OUTCOMES. THE DECISIONS ARE MADE ON SMALL PARCELS BUT AGGREGATE FOR AN ACCUMULATED IMPACT. PRIVATE OWNERS LACK AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE TO INTEGRATE BEST PRACTICES. SPECIALISTS AND PRACTITIONERS IDENTIFY KNOWLEDGE GAPS OR SEEK TECHNICAL SUPPORT. EXTENSION EDUCATORS SEEK SUPPORT WITH COMPLEXPROBLEMS AT COUNTY AND MULTI-COUNTY SCALES. PRIVATE WOODLANDS ARE CENTRAL TO MULTIPLE DESIRED OUTCOMES THAT SUPPORT THE MATERIAL NEEDS OF FOREST PRODUCTS INDUSTRY, PRIVATE OWNER TANGIBLE AND INTANGIBLE OUTPUTS, RESILIENCE AGAINST STRESSORS OF THE FOREST, LOCALLY PRODUCED FOOD, AND MOST RECENTLY AN EXPECTATION FOR INCREASED AND SUSTAINED SEQUESTRATION AND STORAGE OF CARBON AS AN OFFSET TO THE STATE’S GREENHOUSE GAS MITIGATION TARGETS. WHILE MANY OF THESE OUTPUTS ARE COMPLEMENTARY, THEIR MUTUAL SUCCESS DEPENDS ON CONSIDERATION OF MULTIPLE CRITERIA AND REFINED MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. THE GOAL FOR THE FOREST ISSUE IS TO ENSURE THAT FORESTS ARE SUSTAINABLY MANAGED FOR OPTIMAL OUTPUTS OF DESIRED GOODS AND SERVICES. THE OBJECTIVES TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL ARE TO INCREASE OWNER AWARENESS OF INFORMATION, GAIN ACCESS TO TECHNICAL SPECIALISTS THAT SUPPORT THEIR INFORMED DECISION MAKING, AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO TECHNICAL SPECIALISTS AND PRACTITIONERS BASED ON APPLIED RESEARCH. THE GOAL FOR WILDLIFE RESOURCES IS TO SUSTAIN AND ENHANCE THE BIODIVERSITY AND HEALTH OF NATIVE WILDLIFE POPULATIONS IN BALANCE WITH THE RESOURCES AVAILABLE IN THEIR ECOSYSTEMS. THE OBJECTIVE FOR THIS GOAL IS TO USE APPLIED RESEARCH TO INFORM THE DECISION MAKING OF WOODLAND OWNERS, WILDLIFE SPECIALISTS AND PRACTITIONERS. THE GOAL FOR FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY IS TO EXPAND THE AVAILABILITY OF LOCALLY PRODUCED FOREST-BASED FOODS, AND TO ENSURE THAT THE PRODUCERS ARE FINANCIALLY AND ECOLOGICALLY SUSTAINABLE. THE OBJECTIVE FOR THIS GOAL IS TO DEMONSTRATE BEST PRACTICES, ACCESS APPLIED RESEARCH ON PRIMARY FOODS (E.G., MAPLE SYRUP) AND RELATED FOOD DERIVATIVES, AND PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES THAT SUPPORT NEW AND ESTABLISHED FOREST-FOOD BASED ENTERPRISES. THE ACTIVITIES DESCRIBED IN THE METHODS SECTION REFLECT A STRATEGY THAT RECOGNIZES STAKEHOLDERS ARRIVE AT DIFFERENT LEVELS OF AWARENESS, HAVE PREFERRED AND SOMETIMES ESSENTIAL MODES OF LEARNING, AND BENEFIT FROM MULTIPLE EXPOSURES TO SIMILAR INFORMATION,OPTIMALLY DEMONSTRATED TO ALLOW THEM TO VISUALIZE THE OUTCOME. IN RESPONSE TO DIFFERENT LEVELS OF AWARENESS, OUR PROGRAM MATERIALS RANGE FROM INTRODUCTORY TO MODERATELY COMPLEX. HIGHLY COMPLEX MATERIAL IS PROVIDED AS PEER REVIEWED SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS OR TECHNICAL REPORTS AND LARGELY OUTSIDE THE SCOPE OF RREA. WE ADDRESS PREFERRED LEARNING MODES BY CREATING MULTIPLE OUTLETS AND FORMATS THAT RANGE FROM SOCIAL MEDIA TO FACT SHEETS TO YOUTUBE TO FIELD TOURS AND DEMONSTRATION SITES. THE POWER OF VISUALIZATION IS REMARKABLE IN ITS CAPACITY TO CONVEY THE OPPORTUNITIES OF A PARTICULAR ACTION. THAT POWER, HOWEVER, CARRIES THE OBLIGATION TO ENSURE THAT THE ASSUMPTIONS OF WHAT’S DEMONSTRATED ARE CLEARLY DEFINED RELATIVE TO FACTORS THAT MIGHT BE DIFFERENT ELSEWHERE AND RESULT IN A DIFFERENT OUTCOME. DEMONSTRATIONS ARE CREATED TO ALLOW FOR DIRECT ENGAGEMENT, BUT ALSO THROUGH VIDEO, PICTURES, AND ILLUSTRATIONS. METHODOLOGY 8,000 CHARACTERS 1. ONLINE: A VARIETY OF ONLINE MEDIA WILL BE USED. WEBINARS WILL BE OFFERED MONTHLY, WITH ADDITIONAL SPECIAL FEATURE WEBINARS ON AN AS NEEDED BASIS. THE BASE PAGE FOR THE PROGRAM, WWW.FORESTCONNECT.INFO WILL INCLUDE ALL PROGRAM-RELEVANT EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS. VIDEO WILL BE UPLOADED TO YOUTUBE AND DISTRIBUTED THROUGH THE SOCIAL NETWORK. FACEBOOK PAGES WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT A COMMUNITY OF INTEREST. THE SOCIAL NETWORK SITE HTTP://CORNELLFORESTCONNECT.NING.COM AND HTTP://SILVOPASTURE.NING.COM WILL BE FURTHER DEVELOPED FOR INTERACTIONS AMONG STAKEHOLDERS AND TO SHARE RESOURCES. RREA FUNDS AS NECESSARY WILL ENSURE ADEQUATE COMPUTER HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE. 2. PEER-VOLUNTEERS: MASTER FOREST OWNER VOLUNTEERS WILL CONTINUE TO CONNECT WITH PRIVATE WOODLAND OWNERS. MASTER NATURALISTS WILL WORK IN THEIR COMMUNITIES THROUGH A VARIETY OF NETWORKS. ANNUALLY THERE WILL BE A NEW VOLUNTEER TRAINING, REGIONAL REFRESHERS, AND/OR OPPORTUNITIES FOR THESE TRAINED PARTICIPANTS TO CONTINUE TO DEVELOP PROFESSIONALLY. SELECT CCE EDUCATORS WILL SERVE AS REGIONAL DIRECTORS, AND THEY WILL ASSIST WITH PROGRAM MANAGEMENT. 3. DEMONSTRATION SITES: UNIVERSITY AND PRIVATE WOODLANDS WILL BE USED, AND MAY DEMONSTRATE PRACTICES SUCH AS, MANAGEMENT OF INTERFERING VEGETATION, MAPLE SYRUP PRODUCTION, SILVOPASTURE, WOODY BIOMASS HARVESTS, DEER IMPACTS, AND SILVICULTURAL PRACTICES. AREAS WHERE TEAMS OF MASTER NATURALIST VOLUNTEERS COMPLETE PROJECTS WILL BE INCLUDED ON SOCIAL MEDIA. 4. APPLIED RESEARCH: APPLIED RESEARCH WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF DIRECT SUPPORT OF EXTENSION EDUCATION WILL ADDRESS ISSUES AND QUESTIONS THAT LACK AN ADEQUATE RESEARCH BASIS. RREA FUNDS WILL AT MOST PROVIDE A MINIMAL SUPPLEMENT TO APPLIED RESEARCH FUNDS. TOPICS MAY INCLUDE VEGETATION MANAGEMENT, CONTROLLING DEER IMPACTS, FOREST CARBON MANAGEMENT, AND SILVICULTURAL MANIPULATIONS. 5. WORKSHOPS, TOURS AND FIELD DAYS: FIELD-BASED EVENTS WILL BE HELD WITH CCE EDUCATORS ON CORNELL AND PRIVATE LANDS TO DESCRIBE, DEMONSTRATE AND ILLUSTRATE SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES. 6. CONFERENCES AND SEMINARS: INDOOR EVENTS WILL PROVIDE AUDIENCES WITH SEMINAR STYLE LEARNING ON A VARIETY OF TOPICS. 7. MASS MEDIA: A MARKETING CAMPAIGN WILL DRAW ATTENTION TO EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM RESOURCES. 8. EDUCATOR IN-SERVICE: AN ANNUAL FORESTRY-MAPLE TRAINING FOR CCE EDUCATORS WILL PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO SHARE PROGRAM STRATEGIES, AND INTERACT WITH CAMPUS SPECIALISTS. 9. WRITTEN MATERIALS: STAFF AND SPECIALISTS, WITH COLLEAGUES, WILL DEVELOP FACT SHEETS, BULLETINS, AND ARTICLE SERIES ON RREA TOPICS. WRITTEN MATERIALS WILL TYPICALLY BE AVAILABLE ONLINE. 10. ORGANIZATIONAL SUPPORT: STAFF WILL WORK WITH PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS, FOR EXAMPLE THE NEW YORK FOREST OWNERS ASSOCIATION AND THE STATE FORESTRY AGENCY, ON PROJECTS OF MUTUAL INTEREST AND THAT ENHANCE WORKING FOREST CONDITIONS. 11. EVALUATION OF PROGRAM ACTIVITIES WILL HAPPEN THROUGH INFORMAL EXIT SURVEYS, DOCUMENTATION OF PARTICIPATION AT EVENTS, WEB-BASED ANALYTICAL SOFTWARE, AND CALCULATIONS THAT PROJECT BEHAVIOR CHANGES. WE WILL ALSO CONDUCT FORMAL SURVEYS OF PEOPLE WHO USE PROGRAMS TO UNDERSTAND THEIR RESPONSE, AND TO HELP ADJUST OUR ESTIMATES OF CHANGES FROM NON-SURVEYED PROGRAM ACTIVITIES.

RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROJECT ABSTRACT FEDERAL AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDING IS TO ASSIST STATES IN CARRYING OUT AN EXTENSION PROGRAM DESIGNED TO ASSIST FOREST AND RANGE LANDOWNERS AND MANAGERS IN MAKING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS BASED ON RESEARCH FINDINGS. FOREST AND RANGELAND RESOURCES INCLUDE VEGETATION, WATER, FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE, SOIL, AND RECREATION. PROJECTS MUST ADDRESS THE RREA STRATEGIC ISSUES IDENTIFIED IN THE 2018-2022 RREA STRATEGIC PLAN. THE RREA IS ALIGNED WITH THE FOLLOWING USDA STRATEGIC GOALS FOR 2022 – 2026: 1. STRATEGIC GOAL 1 – COMBAT CLIMATE CHANGE TO SUPPORT AMERICA’S WORKING LANDS, NATURAL RESOURCES AND COMMUNITIES 2. STRATEGIC GOAL 2 – ENSURE AMERICA’S AGRICULTURAL SYSTEM IS EQUITABLE, RESILIENT AND PROSPEROUS 3. STRATEGIC GOAL 3 – FOSTER AN EQUITABLE AND COMPETITIVE MARKETPLACE FOR ALL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS 4. STRATEGIC GOAL 5 – EXPAND OPPORTUNITIES FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVE QUALITY OF LIFE IN RURAL AND TRIBAL COMMUNITIES ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: IN THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA-LINCOLN (UNL) INSTITUTE OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES (IANR), WE ARE ALL ABOUT PEOPLE AND THE FOOD, WATER AND NATURAL RESOURCES THAT SUSTAIN THEM. IANR INNOVATION IN RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND EXTENSION EDUCATION PLACES NEBRASKA ON THE LEADING EDGE OF FOOD PRODUCTION, ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP, HUMAN NUTRITION, BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT, AND YOUTH ENGAGEMENT. COMPOSED OF THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES AND NATURAL RESOURCES (CASNR), THE AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH DIVISION (ARD), NEBRASKA EXTENSION, AND THE ARD AND EXTENSION COMPONENTS OF THREE DEPARTMENTS IN THE COLLEGE OF EDUCATION AND HUMAN SCIENCES; IANR IS COMMITTED TO GROWING THE FUTURE OF NEBRASKA'S PEOPLE, BUSINESSES, AND COMMUNITIES. STRATEGIC PLANNING IS INTEGRAL TO IANR'S FUNCTION AS A LAND-GRANT INSTITUTION, AND IT PRIDES ITSELF ON WORKING AS AN INTEGRATED SYSTEM AND COLLABORATIVE ENVIRONMENT ACROSS THE THREE MISSION AREAS. IANR STRIVES TO COMBINE RESEARCH, TEACHING AND EXTENSION IN A MULTIDISCIPLINARY, COLLABORATIVE ENVIRONMENT THAT ENCOURAGES THE BEST THINKING AND EXPERTISE FROM ACROSS THE UNIVERSITY AND PRIVATE ENTERPRISE TO ENSURE NEBRASKA’S COMPETITIVENESS IN A WORLD OF CHANGE AND CHALLENGE. IANR UTILIZES RREA FUNDING TO SUPPORT BOTH FORESTRY AND RANGELAND RESOURCES. FORESTRY: NEBRASKA’S FOREST RESOURCE EXPERIENCES AN ARRAY OF CHALLENGES POSED BY SEVERE WEATHER, LAND-USE CONVERSION, INVASIVE SPECIES ENCROACHMENT, PEST AND DISEASE SPREAD, AND THE INCREASING THREAT OF LARGE WILDFIRES. INDIVIDUALLY, ANY ONE OF THESE FORCES CAN PLACE ENORMOUS PRESSURE ON FORESTS AND THE SPECIES THAT UTILIZE TREES FOR SURVIVAL. IF ASSESSED AS AN AGGREGATE, GIVEN PREDICTED SHIFTS IN CLIMATE BY NEBRASKA RESEARCHERS, THE STATE’S TREES AND FORESTS FACE PRESSURES THAT HAVE NOT BEEN OBSERVED IN MODERN HISTORY. COMMUNITY FOREST ARE IMPORTANT TO OUR CITIZENS AS NEARLY 66% OF NEBRASKANS LIVE IN URBAN, SUBURBAN OR COMMUNITY AREAS. TREES HAVE SIGNIFICANT BENEFIT TO THEHEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF PEOPLE IN OUR COMMUNITIES. IN NE THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY, 470,000 ACRES OF COMMUNITY FORESTS. NE'S COMMUNITY FORESTS IMPROVE AIR AND WATER QUALITY; REDUCE NOISE POLLUTION; IMPROVE HUMAN COMFORT, HEALTH AND PSYCHOLOGICAL WELL-BEING, INCREASE PROPERTY VALUES AND IMPROVE A COMMUNITY'S "SENSE OF PLACE." NE'S RURAL FORESTS INCLUDE NATIVE FORESTLAND, AS WELL AS CONSERVATION PLANTINGS, SUCH AS WINDBREAKS AND RIPARIAN FOREST BUFFERS. THE YIELDS OF CROPS AND LIVESTOCK INCREASE IN AREAS SURROUNDED BY TREES. TREES, PROTECT OUR WATER RESOURCES BY FILTERING SEDIMENT AND RUNOFF AND TREES PROTECT OUR RIPARIAN SYSTEMS BY REDUCING EROSION AND BY FILTERING WATER. RANGELAND: RANGELANDS OCCUPY ABOUT 46% OF NEBRASKA HAS 49.5 MILLION ACRES, THE SINGLE LARGEST CATEGORY OF LAND AREA IN THE STATE. WITHIN THE STATE, RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM TYPES ARE DIVERSE, RANGING FROM SUB-HUMID TALLGRASS PRAIRIE IN THE EAST TO SEMI-ARID SHORTGRASS PRAIRIE IN THE EXTREME WEST. OVER 95 PERCENT OF THE RANGELAND IN THE STATE IS PRIVATELY OWNED AND IS THE PRIMARY FORAGE SOURCE FOR THE STATES 6.4 MILLION BEEF CATTLE. A PRIMARY ISSUE IS THE ADAPTATION OF GRAZING MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT ENHANCE OR SUSTAIN THE RANGELAND RESOURCES. NUMEROUS FACTORS, SUCH AS DROUGHT, ENCROACHMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES (EASTERN REDCEDAR), OR LACK OF RANGELAND MANAGEMENT SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE WILL RESULT IN REDUCED RANGELAND HEALTH AND PRESENT CHALLENGES FOR LAND MANAGERS. ALTHOUGH RURAL (LANDOWNER) CLIENTELE ARE THE PRIMARY GROUP SERVED, ALL CITIZENS OF THE STATE MAY BE INDIRECTLY AFFECTED THROUGH SUCH THINGS AS WATERSHED QUALITY, RECREATION, AESTHETICS, AND THE RURAL ECONOMY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE RANGELAND MANAGERS WITH THE NECESSARY TOOLS, INFORMATION, AND EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES NEEDED TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE THEIR LANDS IN WAYS THAT SUSTAIN THE RESOURCE AND PROVIDE OPTIMUM ECONOMIC VALUE. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: FORESTRY: • INCREASE TREE PLANTING TO IMPROVE ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND AIR AND WATER QUALITY; ADDRESS CHALLENGES POSED BY EMERALD ASH BORER • MITIGATE THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF CLIMATIC CHANGE THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS. • PROMOTE WOOD PRODUCTS DEVELOPMENT AND OTHER WOOD UTILIZATION OPTIONS. • IMPROVE FOREST HEALTH TO IMPROVE FOREST RESILIENCY. • ENCOURAGE LONG-TERM CONSERVATION EFFORTS TO KEEP FORESTS IN RURAL AND COMMUNITY SETTINGS • ENGAGE RURAL AND COMMUNITY LANDOWNERS ABOUT CURRENT ISSUES IN FOREST MANAGEMENT AND FOREST HEALTH. • IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF BOTH RURAL AND URBAN TREES AND FORESTS VIA OUTREACH, EDUCATION AND DIAGNOSIS OF TREE PESTS AND PROBLEMS. EARLY DETECTION OF INVASIVE TREE PESTS. • PROMOTE ACTIVE AND SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF NEBRASKA’S FOREST RESOURCES TO ENSURE A CONTINUED STREAM OF ENVIRONMENTAL, ECONOMIC, SOCIAL, AND HUMAN HEALTH BENEFITS. RANGELAND: • TEACHING AND DEMONSTRATING SUSTAINABLE RANGELAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES • NEBRASKA RANCH PRACTICUM INSTRUCTORS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING AND UPDATING CURRICULA AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS NEEDED FOR THE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS AS WELL AS PROGRAM DELIVERY • THERE ARE MANY METHODS OF OUTREACH THAT CAN USED TO PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS TO CLIENTELE (SOCIAL MEDIA, PODCASTS, VIDEOS, WE BINARS). KEEPING THESE MATERIALS CURRENT AND CREATIVE NEEDS TO BE AN ONGOING EFFORT TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE AUDIENCES. • THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOME FOR EDUCATIONAL PROJECTS AND PROGRAMS WILL BE LAND MANAGER ADOPTION OF ANY NEEDED OR RECOMMENDED RANGE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. SUBSEQUENTLY, IMPLEMENTATION OF SOME RANGE MONITORING WOULD BE IMPORTANT TO QUANTIFY BENEFICIAL CHANGES IN RANGE HEALTH. FOR A COMPREHENSIVE LIST OF ALL OUTCOMES, WE WELCOME THE REVIEW OF IANR’S ANNUAL REPORT OF ACCOMPLISHMENTS AND RESULTS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: AS NEBRASKA’S RESIDENTS ARE THE PRIMARY BENEFICIARIES AND STAKEHOLDERS, THERE IS AN ONGOING, TWO-WAY DIALOGUE TO ENSURE THAT IANR’S PRIORITIES REFLECT THE NEEDS OF THE STATE. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: N/A

PROJECT ABSTRACT – MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY: RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION HELPS IMPROVE PEOPLE’S LIVES THROUGH AN EDUCATIONAL PROCESS THAT APPLIES KNOWLEDGE TO CRITICAL ISSUES, NEEDS, AND OPPORTUNITIES. FOR MORE THAN 100 YEARS, MSU EXTENSION FACULTY AND STAFF MEMBERS HAVE BEEN ACTIVELY REACHING PEOPLE WHERE THEY ARE – IN THEIR HOMES, FARMS, BUSINESSES, AND COMMUNITIES – WITH RESEARCH DRIVEN EDUCATION. WE HELP PEOPLE PERFORM THEIR JOBS BETTER, RAISE HEALTHY AND SAFE FAMILIES, BUILD STRONGER COMMUNITIES, AND EMPOWER CHILDREN TO DREAM OF BRIGHTER FUTURES. WITH RENEWABLE RESOURCES EXTENSION ACT PROGRAM (RREA) FUNDING, MSU EXTENSION FOSTERS ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, IMPROVED QUALITY OF LIFE, A HEALTHY ENVIRONMENT, AND A PLENTIFUL AND SECURE FOOD SUPPLY FOR MICHIGAN RESIDENTS. MICHIGAN’S NATURAL RESOURCES ARE A FUNDAMENTAL ASSET FOR THE STATE’S FUTURE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES. CHALLENGES CONCERN HOW RESIDENTS OF THE STATE CAN BEST BENEFIT FROM ITS RICH NATURAL HERITAGE WITHOUT OVERBURDENING THE CARRYING CAPACITY OF ITS NATURAL SYSTEMS AND REDUCING OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS AND VISITORS ALIKE. OUR NATURAL RESOURCE PROGRAMS IMPROVE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING, HELP LANDOWNERS AND COMMUNITIES USE THOSE ASSETS FOR SUSTAINABLE LONG‐TERM SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, AND CONSERVE NATURAL RESOURCES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS. WE WILL DEVELOP TOOLS AND TECHNOLOGY TO HELP MICHIGAN'S NATURAL RESOURCE‐BASED TOURISM INDUSTRY GROW BY MEETING CONSUMER DEMANDS AND DETERMINE HOW WILDLIFE, FISHERIES, FOREST AND NATURAL RESOURCES AREAS RESPOND TO HABITAT MANAGEMENT TO ENCOURAGE MANAGEMENT FOR SUSTAINABLE BENEFITS.

FY 2023 RREA PROJECT PROJECT TITLE: ENHANCE CLIMATE CHANGE RESILIENCY AND RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP THROUGH EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES ABSTRACT OVER 80% OF THE U.S. POPULATION LIVES IN URBAN AND SUBURBAN COMMUNITIES. CONSEQUENTLY, INTEREST IN THE PRESERVATION OF THE URBAN ENVIRONMENT IS ON THE RISE. URBAN RESIDENTS ARE INCREASINGLY CONCERNED ABOUT ISSUES RELATED TO URBAN SPRAWL AT THE URBAN - WILD LAND INTERFACE AND THEIR EFFECTS ON RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES. HOWEVER, IN MANY UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THERE IS LITTLE OR NO KNOWLEDGE OF THE ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC BENEFITS OF SUSTAINABLE URBAN FOREST STEWARDSHIP AND HEALTH. LOCATED IN THE GULF COAST REGION, LOUISIANA IS EXTREMELY VENERABLE TO CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS, SUCH AS SEA LEVEL RISE, SALTWATER INTRUSION, INCREASE HURRICANE FREQUENCY, AND FLOODING. THE IMPACTS ARE DISPROPORTIONALLY HIGHER TO THE LOW-INCOME UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES ALONG THE COAST. THERE IS AN URGENT NEED FOR EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO HELP THESE COMMUNITIES IN CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION AND ADAPTATION. THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP EDUCATION AND OUTREACH MATERIALS, AND DISSEMINATE TECHNOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE ON FORESTRY, ENVIRONMENT, AND RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES TO DIVERSE AUDIENCES. THE MAJOR OBJECTIVES ARE: 1. OUTREACH AND EDUCATE THE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, ESPECIALLY YOUNG GENERATIONS ON HEALTHY URBAN FORESTS AND URBAN-WILDLAND ECOSYSTEMS, 2. OUTREACH AND EDUCATE THE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES ON CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS AND ADAPTATION STRATEGIES, AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICES, 3: DISSEMINATE TECHNOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES TO ENHANCE ENVIRONMENT AND RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT, AND 4: BUILDING OUTREACH AND EXTENSION CAPACITY THROUGH ENHANCED CONNECTIONS. WE WILL UTILIZE VIRTUAL/ONLINE PLATFORMS TO CONDUCT OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS DISTRIBUTING ELECTRONIC FLYERS, HOSTING VIRTUAL INFORMATIONAL SESSIONS, WEBINARS, DISCUSSION FORUMS, ETC. WE WILL ALSO UTILIZE FACE-TO-FACE METHODS, SUCH AS CLASSROOM VISITS, COMMUNITY VISITS, TRAINING SESSIONS, MEETINGS, WORKSHOPS, ETC., TO ACCOMPLISH THE PROJECT GOAL AND OBJECTIVES. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES FOR STUDENTS THROUGH DIRECT PROJECT INVOLVEMENT. THE TARGET AUDIENCES COMPRISE OF THE LOUISIANA COMMUNITIES SUCH AS HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, COLLEGE STUDENTS, FACULTY, RESIDENTS, FARMERS, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS , GREEN ORGANIZATIONS , MUNICIPAL ORGANIZATIONS AND NONPROFITS WORKING ON URBAN AND COMMUNITY FORESTRY ISSUES, ARBORISTS, URBAN FORESTERS, ETC. ELECTRONIC EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS FOR URBAN FORESTRY, ENVIRONMENT, AND RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES, AND PRINTED MATERIALS TO ENHANCE STAKEHOLDERS’ KNOWLEDGE, CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS, PAPER PUBLICATIONS, ETC. WE HOPE THAT OUR PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE COMMUNITIES’ AWARENESS ON URBAN FORESTRY SUSTAINABILITY, ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION, AND NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION; ENHANCE THE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY’S ABILITY IN CLIMATE CHANGE MITIGATION AND ADAPTATION; AND INCREASE YOUNG GENERATION’S INTERESTS AND THEIR DESIRE IN PLAYING AN ACTIVE ROLE IN ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP.

PROJECT ABSTRACT WISCONSIN IS A LARGELY FORESTED LANDSCAPE COVERING 16 MILLION ACRES, ABOUT 46% OF THE STATE'S LAND AREA. OVERALL, 57% OF THE FORESTLAND IS OWNED BY INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES, TOTALING 360,000 OWNERS. FOREST INDUSTRY IS VITAL TO THE STATE'S ECONOMY; THE STATE CONTINUES TO BE THE NUMBER ONE PAPER PRODUCING STATE IN THE COUNTRY, AND FOREST PRODUCT INDUSTRIES ARE SCATTERED THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THIS INDUSTRY RELIES HEAVILY ON FAMILY OWNED FORESTLAND. THE WDNR ESTIMATES THAT 10% OF THE 9.1 MILLION FORESTED ACRES, HELD BY FAMILY FOREST OWNERS, WILL BE SOLD, SUBDIVIDED OR CONVERTED TO NON‐FOREST USE IN THE NEXT 5 YEARS. IN A SIMILAR STUDY, THE SUSTAINING FAMILY FORESTS INITIATIVE (SFFI) FOUND THE HIGHEST CONCERN REPORTED BY 56% OF ALL LANDOWNERS WAS "KEEPING LAND INTACT FOR CHILDREN/HEIRS". INCIDENTALLY, THE SECOND HIGHEST CONCERN WAS "HIGH PROPERTY TAXES". A THIRD STUDY, BY GOBSTER AND RICKENBACH (2004) LOOKED AT PERCEPTIONS OF PARCELIZATION. THE PRIMARY DRIVERS INCLUDED ECONOMIC, DEMOGRAPHIC, VALUES <(>&<)> MOTIVATIONS, GLOBALIZATION <(>&<)> TECHNOLOGY, NATURAL CAPITAL, AND POLICIES. THUS EDUCATING LANDOWNERS ON RECOGNIZING THE BEST ECONOMIC RETURN ON TIMBER HARVESTS, UNDERSTANDING HOW DIVIDING PROPERTY AFFECTS THE ECOSYSTEM, AND WHAT POLICIES EXISTS TO ASSIST WITH MANAGEMENT WILL ASSIST WITH THESE ISSUES. OUR COMPREHENSIVE FORESTRY OUTREACH PROGRAM ZEROS IN ON THESE CONCERNS. DURING FFY2023, WISCONSIN RREA PROGRAMMING WILL ADDRESS RENEWABLE RESOURCES IN A VARIETY OF PROGRAMS AND PARTNERSHIPS TO ADDRESS STRATEGIC AND CROSS‐CUTTING NATIONAL ISSUES RELATING TO GOALS IDENTIFIED IN THE NIFA RREA STRATEGIC PLAN. GOAL 1‐ ENSURING HEALTHY ECOSYSTEMS AND GOAL 3 ‐ ENHANCING RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ON WORKING FORESTS AND RANGELANDS. THE PRIMARY CROSS‐CUTTING ISSUES WE WILL FOCUS ON INCLUDE FISH AND WILDLIFE R ESOURCES, CLIMATE VARIABILITY, AND INTERGENERATIONAL LAND AND OTHER LAND OWNERSHIP CHANGES. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO HELP LANDOWNERS DEVELOP FUNDAMENTAL KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS AROUND WOODLAND ECOLOGY, HEALTHY FORESTS, TIMBER HARVEST PRACTICES AND SALES, HABITAT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT BENEFIT WILDLIFE, STRATEGIES FOR THREATS SUCH AS INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE VARIABILITY, LAND OWNERSHIP AND INTERGENERATIONAL TRANSFERS, AND TO IMPLEMENT PRACTICES TO ACHIEVE SUSTAINABLE FOREST RESOURCES AND TO MEET PERSONAL MANAGEMENT GOALS. THROUGH IN‐PERSON CLASSES, DISTANCE CLASSES, FIELD DAYS, AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WE ARE EXPECTING TO INCREASE LANDOWNERS' AND RESOURCES PROFESSIONALS' SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE TO AFFECT LONG‐TERM CHANGES IN ACTIVE MANAGEMENT BY WOODLAND OWNERS THAT WILL SUPPORT SUCCESSION TO FAMILY MEMBERS, REDUCE THE INCIDENCE OF PARCELIZATION THROUGH STABLE LAND OWNERSHIP, AND RETAIN FOREST COVER AND CONTRIBUTE SUSTAINABLY TO THE WOOD FUEL CYCLE THROUGH REGULAR PLANNED TIMBER SALES.
